{"uri": "2024-07-432666805", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "00:21:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T00:21:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T00:09:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://roanoke.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/biden-addressing-nation-on-his-decision-to-drop-his-2024-democratic-reelection-bid/article_ae42e49e-0cef-5c7a-8c6d-58fb76885600.html", "title": "Biden addressing nation on his decision to drop his 2024 Democratic reelection bid", "body": "ZEKE MILLER, SEUNG MIN KIM and WILL WEISSERT Associated Press\n\nWASHINGTON -- Insisting that \"the defense of democracy is more important than any title,\" President Joe Biden on Wednesday explained in an Oval Office address his decision to drop his bid for reelection and to throw his support behind Vice President Kamala Harris.\n\nThe address offered the public their first chance to hear directly from Biden his rationale for dropping out of the 2024 after weeks of insisting he believed himself to be the best candidate to take on former President Donald Trump, whom he has called an existential threat to the nation's democracy. It also gave Biden a chance to try to shape how history views his one and only term in office.\n\n\"The defense of democracy is more important than any title,\" Biden said. \"I draw strength, and find joy, in working FOR the American people. But this sacred task of perfecting our Union is not about me. It's about you. Your families. Your futures. It's about 'We the People.'\"\n\nBiden's candidacy faced a crisis of confidence from Democrats after his abysmal debate against Trump nearly a month ago, where he spoke haltingly, appeared ashen and failed to rebut his predecessor's attacks. It sparked a mutiny within his party over not just whether he was capable of beating Trump in November, but also whether at 81, he was still fit for the high-pressure job.\n\nBiden tried to outlast the skepticism and quell the concerns with interviews and tepid rallies, but the pressure to step aside only mounted from the party's political elites and from ordinary voters.\n\nOn Sunday afternoon, while isolating at his Rehoboth Beach, Delaware, home with COVID-19, Biden finally bowed in a letter posted to his account on X announcing his decision to leave the race, followed up later by an endorsement of Harris.\n\n\"I have decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation,\" Biden said. \"That is the best way to unite our nation.\"\n\nBiden's address was being carried by the major television news networks. He pledge to remain focused on being president until his term expires at noon on Jan. 20, 2025.\n\nThe president was hoping to use the address to outline the stakes in the election, which both Biden and Harris have framed as a choice between freedom and chaos, but was expected to try to steer clear of overt campaigning from his official office or even mentioning Trump by name.\n\n\"The great thing about America is here, kings and dictators do not rule,\" Biden said. \"The people do. History is in your hands. The power is in your hands. The idea of America -- lies in your hands.\"\n\nBiden was also looking to make the case for his legacy of sweeping domestic legislation and the renewal of alliances abroad. The way history will remember his time in office and his historic decision to step aside is intertwined with Harris' electoral result in November, particularly as the vice president runs tightly on the achievements of the Biden administration.\n\nHis advisers say he intends to hold campaign events and fundraisers benefiting Harris, albeit at a far slower pace than if he had remained on the ballot himself.\n\nHarris advisers will ultimately have to decide how to deploy the president, whose popularity sagged as voters in both parties questioned his fitness for office.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nBiden, aides say, knows that if Harris loses, he'll be criticized for staying in the race too long and not giving her or another Democrat time to effectively mount a campaign against Trump. If she wins, she'll ensure his policy victories are secured and expanded, and he'll be remembered for a Washingtonian decision to step aside for the next generation of leadership.\n\nPress secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said Wednesday that any question of Biden resigning his office -- which would allow Harris to run as an incumbent -- was \"ridiculous.\"\n\nJean-Pierre said Biden has \"no regrets\" about his decision to stay in the race as long as he did, or his decision to quit it over the weekend. She said Biden's decision had nothing to do with his health.\n\nRead more:\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up!\n\n* I understand and agree that registration {"uri": "8242147936", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "00:51:00", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T00:51:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T00:50:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://fortune.com/2024/07/24/biden-explains-decision-to-step-aside-kamala-harris-democracy-trump/", "title": "Biden explains decision to step aside: 'It's not about me, it's about you.'", "body": "The address offered the public their first chance to hear directly from Biden his rationale for dropping out of the 2024 after weeks of insisting he believed himself to be the best candidate to take on former President Donald Trump, whom he has called an existential threat to the nation's democracy. It also gave Biden a chance to try to shape how history views his one and only term in office.\n\n\"The defense of democracy is more important than any title,\" Biden said. \"Nothing, nothing can come in the way of saving our democracy. And that includes personal ambition.\"\n\nSaid Biden, \"I revere this office, but I love my country more.\" He added that his decision to bow out was made in good faith. \"It's not about me, it's about you.\"\n\nBiden's candidacy faced a crisis of confidence from Democrats after his abysmal debate against Trump nearly a month ago, where he spoke haltingly, appeared ashen and failed to rebut his predecessor's attacks. It sparked a mutiny within his party over not just whether he was capable of beating Trump in November, but also whether at 81, he was still fit for the high-pressure job.\n\nBiden tried to outlast the skepticism and quell the concerns with interviews and tepid rallies, but the pressure to step aside only mounted from the party's political elites and from ordinary voters.\n\nOn Sunday afternoon, while isolating at his Rehoboth Beach, Delaware, home with COVID-19, Biden finally bowed in a letter posted to his account on X announcing his decision to leave the race, followed up later by an endorsement of Harris.\n\n\"I have decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation,\" Biden said, saying he wanted to make room for \"fresh voices, yes, younger voices.\"\n\nHe added, \"That is the best way to unite our nation.\"\n\nBiden's address was being carried by the major broadcast and cable news networks. He pledge to remain focused on being president until his term expires at noon on Jan. 20, 2025, saying he would work to end the war between Israel and Hamas in Gaza, fight to boost government support to cure cancer, and call for Supreme Court reform.\n\nThe president was hoping to use the address to outline the stakes in the election, which both Biden and Harris have framed as a choice between freedom and chaos, but he tried to steer clear of overt campaigning from his official office and never mentioned Trump by name.\n\n\"The great thing about America is here, kings and dictators do not rule,\" Biden said. \"The people do. History is in your hands. The power is in your hands. The idea of America -- lies in your hands.\"\n\nBiden was also looking to make the case for his legacy of sweeping domestic legislation and the renewal of alliances abroad. The way history will remember his time in office and his historic decision to step aside is intertwined with Harris' electoral result in November, particularly as the vice president runs tightly on the achievements of the Biden administration.\n\nHis advisers say he intends to hold campaign events and fundraisers benefiting Harris, albeit at a far slower pace than if he had remained on the ballot himself.\n\nHarris advisers will ultimately have to decide how to deploy the president, whose popularity sagged as voters in both parties questioned his fitness for office.\n\nBiden, aides say, knows that if Harris loses, he'll be criticized for staying in the race too long and not giving her or another Democrat time to effectively mount a campaign against Trump. If she wins, she'll ensure his policy victories are secured and expanded, and he'll be remembered for a Washingtonian decision to step aside for the next generation of leadership.\n\nPress secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said Wednesday that any question of Biden resigning his office -- which would allow Harris to run as an incumbent -- was \"ridiculous.\"\n\nJean-Pierre said Biden has \"no regrets\" about his decision to stay in the race as long as he did, or his decision to quit it over the weekend. {"uri": "2024-07-432684585", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "00:58:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T00:58:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T00:15:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/biden-uses-oval-office-address-to-explain-his-decision-to-quit-2024-race-begins-to/article_594ac631-3577-55a9-b1b8-eec6231f4f0d.html", "title": "Biden uses Oval Office address to explain his decision to quit 2024 race, begins to shape legacy", "body": "By ZEKE MILLER, SEUNG MIN KIM and WILL WEISSERT - Associated Press\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- Insisting that \"the defense of democracy is more important than any title,\" President Joe Biden on Wednesday will explain in an Oval Office address his decision to drop his bid for reelection and to throw his support behind Vice President Kamala Harris.\n\nThe address offered the public their first chance to hear directly from Biden his rationale for dropping out of the 2024 after weeks of insisting he believed himself to be the best candidate to take on former President Donald Trump, whom he has called an existential threat to the nation's democracy. It also gave Biden a chance to try to shape how history views his one and only term in office.\n\n\"The defense of democracy is more important than any title,\" Biden said. \"Nothing, nothing can come in the way of saving our democracy. And that includes personal ambition.\"\n\nSaid Biden, \"I revere this office, but I love my country more.\"\n\nBiden's candidacy faced a crisis of confidence from Democrats after his abysmal debate against Trump nearly a month ago, where he spoke haltingly, appeared ashen and failed to rebut his predecessor's attacks. It sparked a mutiny within his party over not just whether he was capable of beating Trump in November, but also whether at 81, he was still fit for the high-pressure job.\n\nBiden tried to outlast the skepticism and quell the concerns with interviews and tepid rallies, but the pressure to step aside only mounted from the party's political elites and from ordinary voters.\n\nOn Sunday afternoon, while isolating at his Rehoboth Beach, Delaware, home with COVID-19, Biden finally bowed in a letter posted to his account on X announcing his decision to leave the race, followed up later by an endorsement of Harris.\n\n\"I have decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation,\" Biden said, saying he wanted to make room for \"fresh voices, yes, younger voices.\"\n\nHe added, \"That is the best way to unite our nation.\"\n\nBiden's address was being carried by the major broadcast and cable news networks. He pledge to remain focused on being president until his term expires at noon on Jan. 20, 2025, saying he would work to end the war between Israel and Hamas in Gaza, fight to boost government support to cure cancer, and call for Supreme Court reform.\n\nThe president was hoping to use the address to outline the stakes in the election, which both Biden and Harris have framed as a choice between freedom and chaos, but he tried to steer clear of overt campaigning from his official office and never mentioned Trump by name.\n\n\"The great thing about America is here, kings and dictators do not rule,\" Biden said. \"The people do. History is in your hands. The power is in your hands. The idea of America -- lies in your hands.\"\n\nBiden was also looking to make the case for his legacy of sweeping domestic legislation and the renewal of alliances abroad. The way history will remember his time in office and his historic decision to step aside is intertwined with Harris' electoral result in November, particularly as the vice president runs tightly on the achievements of the Biden administration.\n\nHis advisers say he intends to hold campaign events and fundraisers benefiting Harris, albeit at a far slower pace than if he had remained on the ballot himself.\n\nHarris advisers will ultimately have to decide how to deploy the president, whose popularity sagged as voters in both parties questioned his fitness for office.\n\nBiden, aides say, knows that if Harris loses, he'll be criticized for staying in the race too long and not giving her or another Democrat time to effectively mount a campaign against Trump. If she wins, she'll ensure his policy victories are secured and expanded, and he'll be remembered for a Washingtonian decision to step aside for the next generation of leadership.\n\nPress secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said Wednesday that any question of Biden resigning his office -- which would allow Harris to run as an incumbent -- was \"ridiculous.\"\n\nJean-Pierre said Biden has \"no regrets\" about his decision to stay in the race as long as he did, or his decision to quit it over the weekend. Biden is returning to the White House from his Rehoboth Beach home recovering from COVID-19 and after ending his 2024 campaign. (AP Photo/Manuel Balce Ceneta)WASHINGTON (AP) - Insisting that \"the defense of democracy is more important than any title,\"\u009d President Joe Biden on Wednesday explained in an Oval Office address his decision to drop his bid for reelection and to throw his support behind Vice President Kamala Harris. The address offered the public their first chance to hear directly from Biden his rationale for dropping out of the 2024 after weeks of insisting he believed himself to be the best candidate to take on former President Donald Trump, whom he has called an existential threat to the nation's democracy. It also gave Biden a chance to try to shape how history views his one and only term in office. \"The defense of democracy is more important than any title,\" Biden said. \"I draw strength, and find joy, in working FOR the American people. But this sacred task of perfecting our Union is not about me. It's about you. Your families. Your futures. It's about \"~We the People.'\"\u009d Biden's candidacy faced a crisis of confidence from Democrats after his abysmal debate against Trump nearly a month ago, where he spoke haltingly, appeared ashen and failed to rebut his predecessor's attacks. It sparked a mutiny within his party over not just whether he was capable of beating Trump in November, but also whether at 81, he was still fit for the high-pressure job. Biden tried to outlast the skepticism and quell the concerns with interviews and tepid rallies, but the pressure to step aside only mounted from the party's political elites and from ordinary voters. On Sunday afternoon, while isolating at his Rehoboth Beach, Delaware, home with COVID-19, Biden finally bowed in a letter posted to his account on X announcing his decision to leave the race, followed up later by an endorsement of Harris. \"I have decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation,\" Biden said. \"That is the best way to unite our nation.\"\u009d Biden's address was being carried by the major television news networks. He pledge to remain focused on being president until his term expires at noon on Jan. 20, 2025. The president was hoping to use the address to outline the stakes in the election, which both Biden and Harris have framed as a choice between freedom and chaos, but was expected to try to steer clear of overt campaigning from his official office or even mentioning Trump by name. \"The great thing about America is here, kings and dictators do not rule,\" Biden said. \"The people do. History is in your hands. The power is in your hands. The idea of America - lies in your hands.\" Biden was also looking to make the case for his legacy of sweeping domestic legislation and the renewal of alliances abroad. The way history will remember his time in office and his historic decision to step aside is intertwined with Harris' electoral result in November, particularly as the vice president runs tightly on the achievements of the Biden administration. His advisers say he intends to hold campaign events and fundraisers benefiting Harris, albeit at a far slower pace than if he had remained on the ballot himself. Harris advisers will ultimately have to decide how to deploy the president, whose popularity sagged as voters in both parties questioned his fitness for office. Biden, aides say, knows that if Harris loses, he'll be criticized for staying in the race too long and not giving her or another Democrat time to effectively mount a campaign against Trump. If she wins, she'll ensure his policy victories are secured and expanded, and he'll be remembered for a Washingtonian decision to step aside for the next generation of leadership. Press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said Wednesday that any question of Biden resigning his office - which would allow Harris to run as an incumbent - was \"ridiculous.\"\u009d Jean-Pierre said Biden has \"no regrets\"\u009d about his decision to stay in the race as long as he did, or his decision to quit it over the weekend. {"uri": "2024-07-432635817", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "23:12:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T23:12:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T22:35:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.aol.com/biden-oval-office-address-explain-223537584.html", "title": "Biden to use Oval Office address to explain his decision to quit 2024 race, begin to shape legacy", "body": "Biden to use Oval Office address to explain his decision to quit 2024 race, begin to shape legacy\n\nZEKE MILLER, SEUNG MIN KIM and WILL WEISSERT\n\nJuly 25, 2024 at 12:35 AM\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- Insisting that \"the defense of democracy is more important than any title,\" President Joe Biden on Wednesday will explain in an Oval Office address his decision to drop his bid for reelection and to throw his support behind Vice President Kamala Harris.\n\nThe address will offer the public their first chance to hear directly from Biden his rationale for dropping out of the 2024 after weeks of insisting he believed himself to be the best candidate to take on former President Donald Trump, whom he has called an existential threat to the nation's democracy. It will also give Biden a chance to try to shape how history views his one and only term in office.\n\n\"The defense of democracy is more important than any title,\" Biden will say according to excerpts released by the White House. \"I draw strength, and find joy, in working FOR the American people. But this sacred task of perfecting our Union is not about me. It's about you. Your families. Your futures. It's about 'We the People.'\"\n\nBiden's candidacy faced a crisis of confidence from Democrats after his abysmal debate against Trump nearly a month ago, where he spoke haltingly, appeared ashen and failed to rebut his predecessor's attacks. It sparked a mutiny within his party over not just whether he was capable of beating Trump in November, but also whether at 81, he was still fit for the high-pressure job.\n\nBiden tried to outlast the skepticism and quell the concerns with interviews and tepid rallies, but the pressure to step aside only mounted from the party's political elites and from ordinary voters.\n\nOn Sunday afternoon while isolating at his Rehoboth Beach, Delaware, home with COVID-19, Biden finally bowed in a letter posted to his account on X announcing his decision to leave the race, followed up later by an endorsement of Harris.\n\n\"I have decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation,\" Biden was set to say Wednesday. \"That is the best way to unite our nation.\"\n\nBiden's address is being carried by the major television news networks. He is set to pledge to remain focused on being president until his term expires at noon on Jan. 20, 2025.\n\nThe president was hoping to use the address to outline the stakes in the election, which both Biden and Harris have framed as a choice between freedom and chaos, but was expected to try to steer clear of overt campaigning from his official office or even mentioning Trump by name.\n\n\"The great thing about America is here, kings and dictators do not rule,\" Biden was set to say. \"The people do. History is in your hands. The power is in your hands. The idea of America -- lies in your hands.\"\n\nPress secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said Wednesday that any question of Biden resigning his office -- which would allow Harris to run as an incumbent -- was \"ridiculous.\"\n\nJean-Pierre said Biden has \"no regrets\" about his decision to stay in the race as long as he did, or his decision to quit it over the weekend. She said Biden's decision had nothing to do with his health.", "source": {"uri": "aol.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Aol"}, "authors": [{"uri": "zeke_miller@aol.com", "name": "Zeke Miller", {"uri": "2024-07-432627886", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "22:56:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T22:56:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T18:35:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/politics/articles/2024-07-24/biden-to-use-oval-office-address-to-explain-his-decision-to-quit-2024-race-begin-to-shape-legacy", "title": "Biden to Use Oval Office Address to Explain His Decision to Quit 2024 Race, Begin to Shape Legacy", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Insisting that \"the defense of democracy is more important than any title,\" President Joe Biden on Wednesday will explain in an Oval Office address his decision to drop his bid for reelection and to throw his support behind Vice President Kamala Harris.\n\nThe address will offer the public their first chance to hear directly from Biden his rationale for dropping out of the 2024 after weeks of insisting he believed himself to be the best candidate to take on former President Donald Trump, whom he has called an existential threat to the nation's democracy. It will also give Biden a chance to try to shape how history views his one and only term in office.\n\n\"The defense of democracy is more important than any title,\" Biden will say according to excerpts released by the White House. \"I draw strength, and find joy, in working FOR the American people. But this sacred task of perfecting our Union is not about me. It's about you. Your families. Your futures. It's about 'We the People.'\"\n\nBiden's candidacy faced a crisis of confidence from Democrats after his abysmal debate against Trump nearly a month ago, where he spoke haltingly, appeared ashen and failed to rebut his predecessor's attacks. It sparked a mutiny within his party over not just whether he was capable of beating Trump in November, but also whether at 81, he was still fit for the high-pressure job.\n\nBiden tried to outlast the skepticism and quell the concerns with interviews and tepid rallies, but the pressure to step aside only mounted from the party's political elites and from ordinary voters.\n\nOn Sunday afternoon while isolating at his Rehoboth Beach, Delaware, home with COVID-19, Biden finally bowed in a letter posted to his account on X announcing his decision to leave the race, followed up later by an endorsement of Harris.\n\n\"I have decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation,\" Biden was set to say Wednesday. \"That is the best way to unite our nation.\"\n\nBiden's address is being carried by the major television news networks. He is set to pledge to remain focused on being president until his term expires at noon on Jan. 20, 2025.\n\nThe president was hoping to use the address to outline the stakes in the election, which both Biden and Harris have framed as a choice between freedom and chaos, but was expected to try to steer clear of overt campaigning from his official office or even mentioning Trump by name.\n\n\"The great thing about America is here, kings and dictators do not rule,\" Biden was set to say. \"The people do. History is in your hands. The power is in your hands. The idea of America -- lies in your hands.\"\n\nPress secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said Wednesday that any question of Biden resigning his office -- which would allow Harris to run as an incumbent -- was \"ridiculous.\"\n\nJean-Pierre said Biden has \"no regrets\" about his decision to stay in the race as long as he did, or his decision to quit it over the weekend. She said Biden's decision had nothing to do with his health.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8242159087", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "01:06:00", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T01:06:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T01:05:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://nationalnewswatch.com/2024/07/24/biden-uses-oval-office-address-to-explain-his-decision-to-quit-2024-race-begins-to-shape-legacy", "title": "Biden uses Oval Office address to explain his decision to quit 2024...", "body": "The address offered the public their first chance to hear directly from Biden his rationale for dropping out of the 2024 after weeks of insisting he believed himself to be the best candidate to take on former President Donald Trump, whom he has called an existential threat to the nation's democracy. It also gave Biden a chance to try to shape how history views his one and only term in office.\n\n\"The defense of democracy is more important than any title,\" Biden said. \"I draw strength, and find joy, in working FOR the American people. But this sacred task of perfecting our Union is not about me. It's about you. Your families. Your futures. It's about 'We the People.'\"\n\nBiden's candidacy faced a crisis of confidence from Democrats after his abysmal debate against Trump nearly a month ago, where he spoke haltingly, appeared ashen and failed to rebut his predecessor's attacks. It sparked a mutiny within his party over not just whether he was capable of beating Trump in November, but also whether at 81, he was still fit for the high-pressure job.\n\nBiden tried to outlast the skepticism and quell the concerns with interviews and tepid rallies, but the pressure to step aside only mounted from the party's political elites and from ordinary voters.\n\nOn Sunday afternoon, while isolating at his Rehoboth Beach, Delaware, home with COVID-19, Biden finally bowed in a letter posted to his account on X announcing his decision to leave the race, followed up later by an endorsement of Harris.\n\n\"I have decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation,\" Biden said. \"That is the best way to unite our nation.\"\n\nBiden's address was being carried by the major television news networks. He pledge to remain focused on being president until his term expires at noon on Jan. 20, 2025.\n\nThe president was hoping to use the address to outline the stakes in the election, which both Biden and Harris have framed as a choice between freedom and chaos, but was expected to try to steer clear of overt campaigning from his official office or even mentioning Trump by name.\n\n\"The great thing about America is here, kings and dictators do not rule,\" Biden said. \"The people do. History is in your hands. The power is in your hands. The idea of America -- lies in your hands.\"\n\nBiden was also looking to make the case for his legacy of sweeping domestic legislation and the renewal of alliances abroad. The way history will remember his time in office and his historic decision to step aside is intertwined with Harris' electoral result in November, particularly as the vice president runs tightly on the achievements of the Biden administration.\n\nHis advisers say he intends to hold campaign events and fundraisers benefiting Harris, albeit at a far slower pace than if he had remained on the ballot himself.\n\nHarris advisers will ultimately have to decide how to deploy the president, whose popularity sagged as voters in both parties questioned his fitness for office.\n\nBiden, aides say, knows that if Harris loses, he'll be criticized for staying in the race too long and not giving her or another Democrat time to effectively mount a campaign against Trump. If she wins, she'll ensure his policy victories are secured and expanded, and he'll be remembered for a Washingtonian decision to step aside for the next generation of leadership.\n\nPress secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said Wednesday that any question of Biden resigning his office -- which would allow Harris to run as an incumbent -- was \"ridiculous.\"\n\nJean-Pierre said Biden has \"no regrets\" about his decision to stay in the race as long as he did, or his decision to quit it over the weekend. {"uri": "8242222337", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "02:20:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T02:20:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T02:19:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/ap/washington/biden-delivers-solemn-call-to-defend-democracy-as-he-lays-out-his-reasons-for-quitting/article_49b91d58-c165-59cf-994b-546b6241343d.html", "title": "Biden delivers solemn call to defend democracy as he lays out his reasons for quitting race", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- President Joe Biden on Wednesday delivered a solemn call to voters to defend the country's democracy as he laid out in an Oval Office address his decision to drop his bid for reelection and throw his support behind Vice President Kamala Harris.\n\nInsisting that \"the defense of democracy is more important than any title,\" Biden used his first public address since his announcement Sunday that he was stepping aside to deliver an implicit repudiation of former President Donald Trump. He did not directly call out Trump, whom he has called an existential threat to democracy. The 10-minute address also gave Biden a chance to try to shape how history will remember his one and only term in office.\n\n\"Nothing, nothing can come in the way of saving our democracy,\" Biden said, in a somber coda to his 50 years spent in public office. \"And that includes personal ambition.\"\n\nIt was a moment for the history books -- a U.S. president reflecting before the nation on why he was taking the rare step of voluntarily handing off power. It hasn't been done since 1968, when Lyndon Johnson announced he would not seek reelection in the heat of the Vietnam War.\n\n\"I revere this office,\" Biden said. \"But I love my country more.\"\n\nTrump, just an hour earlier at a campaign rally, revived his baseless claims of voter fraud in the 2020 presidential election, which he lost to Biden. His refusal to concede inspired the Capitol insurrection of Jan. 6, 2021, which Biden called \"the worst attack on our democracy since the Civil War.\"\n\nBiden skirted the political reality that brought him to that point: His abysmal performance in a debate against Trump nearly a month ago, where he spoke haltingly, appeared ashen and failed to rebut his predecessor's attacks, sparked a crisis of confidence from Democrats. Lawmakers and ordinary voters questioned not just whether he was capable of beating Trump in November, but also whether, at 81, he was still fit for the high-pressure job.\n\nBiden, who said he believed his record was deserving of another term in office, tried to outlast the skepticism and quell the concerns with interviews and tepid rallies, but the pressure to end his campaign only mounted from the party's political elites and from ordinary voters.\n\n\"I have decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation,\" Biden said, saying he wanted to make room for \"fresh voices, yes, younger voices.\"\n\nHe added, \"That is the best way to unite our nation.\"\n\nIt was a belated fulfillment of his 2020 pledge to be a bridge to a new generation of leaders -- and a bow to the drumbeat of calls from within his party to step aside.\n\nBiden's address was carried live by the major broadcast and cable news networks. He spooled out an weighty to-do list for his last six months in office, pledging to remain focused on being president until his term expires at noon on Jan. 20, 2025. He said he would work to end the war between Israel and Hamas in Gaza, fight to boost government support to cure cancer, address climate change and push for Supreme Court reform.\n\nToday's Top Headlines\n\nStory continues below\n\nLowes Foods to shutter a Moncks Corner grocery store Cafe Strudel owners are opening a new restaurant and market on Lake Murray Decades-old furniture store in Columbia's Vista set to close its doors Georgetown County wants to turn conservation land into homes. Now residents are suing. Hicks: Nikki Haley predicted the Republican Party's current predicament, and could've helped Bon voyage: Runaway cargo ship sails from Charleston after a 48-day detention Want to buy a plane from Clemson? University to sell jets used for athletics recruiting, fundraising More than 100 brewers and musicians coming to Greenville. Here's who will be there. This SC river was labeled 'endangered' earlier this year. Now it's in an extreme drought. Spend an afternoon with Stephen Colbert and his wife, Evie, talking about their favorite recipes\n\nThe president sought to use the address to outline the stakes in the election, which both Biden and Harris have framed as a choice between freedom and chaos, but he tried to steer clear of overt campaigning from his official office.\n\n\"The great thing about America is here, kings and dictators do not rule,\" Biden said. \"The people do. History is in your hands. The power is in your hands. The idea of America -- lies in your hands.\"\n\nBiden was also making the case for his legacy of sweeping domestic legislation and the renewal of alliances abroad. But the way history will remember his time in office and his historic decision to step aside is intertwined with Harris' electoral result in November, particularly as the vice president runs tightly on the achievements of the Biden administration.\n\nHis advisers say he intends to hold campaign events and fundraisers benefiting Harris, whom Biden praised as \"tough\" and \"capable,\" albeit at a far slower pace than if he had remained on the ballot himself.\n\nHarris advisers will ultimately have to decide how to deploy the president, whose popularity sagged as voters in both parties questioned his fitness for office.\n\nBiden, aides say, knows that if Harris loses, he'll be criticized for staying in the race too long and not giving her or another Democrat time to effectively mount a campaign against Trump. If she wins, she'll ensure his policy victories are secured and expanded, and he'll be remembered for a Washingtonian decision to step aside for the next generation of leadership.\n\nBiden said he's grateful to have served as president -- nowhere else would a kid with a stutter grow up to sit in the Oval Office.\n\n\"I've given my heart and my soul to our nation,\" he said. \"I've been blessed a million times in return.\"\n\nPress secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said Wednesday that any question of Biden resigning his office before the election -- which would allow Harris to run as an incumbent -- was \"ridiculous.\"\n\nJean-Pierre said Biden has \"no regrets\" about his decision to stay in the race as long as he did, or his decision to quit it over the weekend. She said Biden's decision had nothing to do with his health.\n\nTrump, who watched Biden's remarks from his private jet, posted on his social media platform that the president \"was barely understandable, and sooo bad!\"\n\nAs he spoke inside the Oval Office, Biden was joined off-camera by family members, including his wife, Jill, son Hunter, daughter Ashley and several grandchildren. Hundreds of administration aides held a watch party in the White House and gathered in the Rose Garden afterward to hear Biden thank them for their service. It also gave Biden a chance to try to shape how history views his one and only term in office.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\n\"The defense of democracy is more important than any title,\" Biden said. \"Nothing, nothing can come in the way of saving our democracy. And that includes personal ambition.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nSaid Biden, \"I revere this office, but I love my country more.\"\n\nBiden's candidacy faced a crisis of confidence from Democrats after his abysmal debate against Trump nearly a month ago, where he spoke haltingly, appeared ashen and failed to rebut his predecessor's attacks. It sparked a mutiny within his party over not just whether he was capable of beating Trump in November, but also whether at 81, he was still fit for the high-pressure job.\n\nBiden tried to outlast the skepticism and quell the concerns with interviews and tepid rallies, but the pressure to step aside only mounted from the party's political elites and from ordinary voters.\n\nOn Sunday afternoon, while isolating at his Rehoboth Beach, Delaware, home with COVID-19, Biden finally bowed in a letter posted to his account on X announcing his decision to leave the race, followed up later by an endorsement of Harris.\n\n\"I have decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation,\" Biden said, saying he wanted to make room for \"fresh voices, yes, younger voices.\"\n\nHe added, \"That is the best way to unite our nation.\"\n\nBiden's address was being carried by the major broadcast and cable news networks. He pledge to remain focused on being president until his term expires at noon on Jan. 20, 2025, saying he would work to end the war between Israel and Hamas in Gaza, fight to boost government support to cure cancer, and call for Supreme Court reform.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe president was hoping to use the address to outline the stakes in the election, which both Biden and Harris have framed as a choice between freedom and chaos, but he tried to steer clear of overt campaigning from his official office and never mentioned Trump by name.\n\n\"The great thing about America is here, kings and dictators do not rule,\" Biden said. \"The people do. History is in your hands. The power is in your hands. The idea of America -- lies in your hands.\"\n\nBiden was also looking to make the case for his legacy of sweeping domestic legislation and the renewal of alliances abroad. The way history will remember his time in office and his historic decision to step aside is intertwined with Harris' electoral result in November, particularly as the vice president runs tightly on the achievements of the Biden administration.\n\nHis advisers say he intends to hold campaign events and fundraisers benefiting Harris, albeit at a far slower pace than if he had remained on the ballot himself.\n\nHarris advisers will ultimately have to decide how to deploy the president, whose popularity sagged as voters in both parties questioned his fitness for office.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nBiden, aides say, knows that if Harris loses, he'll be criticized for staying in the race too long and not giving her or another Democrat time to effectively mount a campaign against Trump. "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9761289", "eventUri": "eng-9761289", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Washington (state)"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": {"uri": "8242199397", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "01:55:04", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T01:55:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T01:54:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://dailyprogress.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/biden-delivers-solemn-call-to-defend-democracy-as-he-lays-out-his-reasons-for-quitting/article_7cca7ee7-b0f7-55f6-9752-506f040f9920.html", "title": "Biden delivers solemn call to defend democracy as he lays out his reasons for quitting race", "body": "WASHINGTON -- President Joe Biden on Wednesday delivered a solemn call to voters to defend the country's democracy as he laid out in an Oval Office address his decision to drop his bid for reelection and throw his support behind Vice President Kamala Harris.\n\nInsisting that \"the defense of democracy is more important than any title,\" Biden used his first public address since his announcement Sunday that he was stepping aside to deliver an implicit repudiation of former President Donald Trump. He did not directly call out Trump, whom he has called an existential threat to democracy. The 10-minute address also gave Biden a chance to try to shape how history will remember his one and only term in office.\n\n\"Nothing, nothing can come in the way of saving our democracy,\" Biden said. \"And that includes personal ambition.\"\n\nIt was a moment for the history books -- a U.S. president reflecting before the nation on why he was taking the rare step of voluntarily handing off power. It hasn't been done since 1968, when Lyndon Johnson announced he would not seek reelection in the heat of the Vietnam War.\n\n\"I revere this office,\" Biden said. \"But I love my country more.\"\n\nTrump, just an hour earlier at a campaign rally, revived his baseless claims of voter fraud in the 2020 presidential election, which he lost to Biden. His refusal to concede inspired the Capitol insurrection of Jan. 6, 2021, which Biden called \"the worst attack on our democracy since the Civil War.\"\n\nBiden skirted the political reality that brought him to that point: His abysmal performance in a debate against Trump nearly a month ago, where he spoke haltingly, appeared ashen and failed to rebut his predecessor's attacks, sparked a crisis of confidence from Democrats. Lawmakers and ordinary voters questioned not just whether he was capable of beating Trump in November, but also whether, at 81, he was still fit for the high-pressure job.\n\nBiden tried to outlast the skepticism and quell the concerns with interviews and tepid rallies, but the pressure to step aside only mounted from the party's political elites and from ordinary voters.\n\n\"I have decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation,\" Biden said, saying he wanted to make room for \"fresh voices, yes, younger voices.\"\n\nHe added, \"That is the best way to unite our nation.\"\n\nIt was a belated fulfillment of his 2020 pledge to be a bridge to a new generation of leaders -- and a bow to the drumbeat of calls from within his party to step aside.\n\nBiden's address was carried live by the major broadcast and cable news networks. He spooled out an weighty to-do list for his last six months in office, pledging to remain focused on being president until his term expires at noon on Jan. 20, 2025. He said he would work to end the war between Israel and Hamas in Gaza, fight to boost government support to cure cancer and push for Supreme Court reform, among other things.\n\nThe president sought to use the address to outline the stakes in the election, which both Biden and Harris have framed as a choice between freedom and chaos, but he tried to steer clear of overt campaigning from his official office.\n\n\"The great thing about America is here, kings and dictators do not rule,\" Biden said. \"The people do. History is in your hands. The power is in your hands. The idea of America -- lies in your hands.\"\n\nBiden was also making the case for his legacy of sweeping domestic legislation and the renewal of alliances abroad. But the way history will remember his time in office and his historic decision to step aside is intertwined with Harris' electoral result in November, particularly as the vice president runs tightly on the achievements of the Biden administration.\n\nHis advisers say he intends to hold campaign events and fundraisers benefiting Harris, whom Biden praised as \"tough\" and \"capable,\" albeit at a far slower pace than if he had remained on the ballot himself.\n\nHarris advisers will ultimately have to decide how to deploy the president, whose popularity sagged as voters in both parties questioned his fitness for office.\n\nBiden, aides say, knows that if Harris loses, he'll be criticized for staying in the race too long and not giving her or another Democrat time to effectively mount a campaign against Trump. If she wins, she'll ensure his policy victories are secured and expanded, and he'll be remembered for a Washingtonian decision to step aside for the next generation of leadership.\n\nBiden said he's grateful to have served as president -- nowhere else would a kid with a stutter grow up to sit in the Oval Office.\n\n\"I've given my heart and my soul to our nation,\" he said. \"I've been blessed a million times in return.\"\n\nPress secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said Wednesday that any question of Biden resigning his office before the election -- which would allow Harris to run as an incumbent -- was \"ridiculous.\"\n\nJean-Pierre said Biden has \"no regrets\" about his decision to stay in the race as long as he did, or his decision to quit it over the weekend. She said Biden's decision had nothing to do with his health.\n\nRead more: Government-politics Harris steps into the limelight. And the coconut trees and memes have followed MEG KINNARD and CURTIS YEE Associated Press Government-politics Harris has support of enough Democratic delegates to become party's presidential nominee: AP survey ZEKE MILLER and SEUNG MIN KIM Associated Press Government-politics Harris gets a chance to press reset on the 2024 race against Trump CHRIS MEGERIAN Associated Press Government-politics Biden drops out of race, endorses VP Harris after disastrous debate inflamed age concerns COLLEEN LONG, ZEKE MILLER and DARLENE SUPERVILLE Associated Press Government-politics Trump's campaign quickly pivots to Harris after Biden announces decision to leave the race JILL COLVIN and MICHELLE L. {"uri": "8242176166", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "01:44:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T01:44:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T01:25:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13670125/Biden-use-Oval-Office-address-explain-decision-quit-2024-race-begin-shape-legacy.html", "title": "Biden to use Oval Office address to explain his decision to quit...", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) - Insisting that \"the defense of democracy is more important than any title,\" President Joe Biden on Wednesday will explain in an Oval Office address his decision to drop his bid for reelection and to throw his support behind Vice President Kamala Harris.\n\nThe address will offer the public their first chance to hear directly from Biden his rationale for dropping out of the 2024 after weeks of insisting he believed himself to be the best candidate to take on former President Donald Trump, whom he has called an existential threat to the nation's democracy. It will also give Biden a chance to try to shape how history views his one and only term in office.\n\n\"The defense of democracy is more important than any title,\" Biden will say according to excerpts released by the White House. \"I draw strength, and find joy, in working FOR the American people. But this sacred task of perfecting our Union is not about me. It\u00b4s about you. Your families. Your futures. It\u00b4s about 'We the People.\u00b4\"\n\nBiden's candidacy faced a crisis of confidence from Democrats after his abysmal debate against Trump nearly a month ago, where he spoke haltingly, appeared ashen and failed to rebut his predecessor's attacks. It sparked a mutiny within his party over not just whether he was capable of beating Trump in November, but also whether at 81, he was still fit for the high-pressure job.\n\nBiden tried to outlast the skepticism and quell the concerns with interviews and tepid rallies, but the pressure to step aside only mounted from the party's political elites and from ordinary voters.\n\nOn Sunday afternoon while isolating at his Rehoboth Beach, Delaware, home with COVID-19, Biden finally bowed in a letter posted to his account on X announcing his decision to leave the race, followed up later by an endorsement of Harris.\n\nPresident Joe Biden disembarks Air Force One as he arrives Andrews Air Force Base, Md., Tuesday, July 23, 2024. Biden is returning to the White House from his Rehoboth Beach home recovering from COVID-19 and after ending his 2024 campaign. (AP Photo/Manuel Balce Ceneta)\n\n\"I have decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation,\" Biden was set to say Wednesday. \"That is the best way to unite our nation.\"\n\nBiden's address is being carried by the major television news networks. He is set to pledge to remain focused on being president until his term expires at noon on Jan. 20, 2025.\n\nThe president was hoping to use the address to outline the stakes in the election, which both Biden and Harris have framed as a choice between freedom and chaos, but was expected to try to steer clear of overt campaigning from his official office or even mentioning Trump by name.\n\n\"The great thing about America is here, kings and dictators do not rule,\" Biden was set to say. \"The people do. History is in your hands. The power is in your hands. The idea of America - lies in your hands.\"\n\nPress secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said Wednesday that any question of Biden resigning his office - which would allow Harris to run as an incumbent - was \"ridiculous.\"\n\nJean-Pierre said Biden has \"no regrets\" about his decision to stay in the race as long as he did, or his decision to quit it over the weekend. {"uri": "8242175816", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "01:26:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T01:26:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T01:24:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://omaha.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/biden-delivers-solemn-call-to-defend-democracy-as-he-lays-out-his-reasons-for-quitting/article_98658417-7dbe-5738-989d-af52071d8654.html", "title": "Biden delivers solemn call to defend democracy as he lays out his reasons for quitting race", "body": "WASHINGTON -- President Joe Biden on Wednesday delivered a solemn call to voters to defend the country's democracy as he laid out in an Oval Office address his decision to drop his bid for reelection and throw his support behind Vice President Kamala Harris.\n\nInsisting that \"the defense of democracy is more important than any title,\" Biden used his first public address since his announcement Sunday that he was stepping aside to deliver an implicit repudiation of former President Donald Trump. He did not directly call out Trump, whom he has called an existential threat to democracy. The 10-minute address also gave Biden a chance to try to shape how history will remember his one and only term in office.\n\n\"Nothing, nothing can come in the way of saving our democracy,\" Biden said. \"And that includes personal ambition.\"\n\nIt was a moment for the history books -- a U.S. president reflecting before the nation on why he was taking the rare step of voluntarily handing off power. It hasn't been done since 1968, when Lyndon Johnson announced he would not seek reelection in the heat of the Vietnam War.\n\n\"I revere this office,\" Biden said. \"But I love my country more.\"\n\nTrump, just an hour earlier at a campaign rally, revived his baseless claims of voter fraud in the 2020 presidential election, which he lost to Biden. His refusal to concede inspired the Capitol insurrection of Jan. 6, 2021, which Biden called \"the worst attack on our democracy since the Civil War.\"\n\nBiden skirted the political reality that brought him to that point: His abysmal performance in a debate against Trump nearly a month ago, where he spoke haltingly, appeared ashen and failed to rebut his predecessor's attacks, sparked a crisis of confidence from Democrats. Lawmakers and ordinary voters questioned not just whether he was capable of beating Trump in November, but also whether, at 81, he was still fit for the high-pressure job.\n\nBiden tried to outlast the skepticism and quell the concerns with interviews and tepid rallies, but the pressure to step aside only mounted from the party's political elites and from ordinary voters.\n\n\"I have decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation,\" Biden said, saying he wanted to make room for \"fresh voices, yes, younger voices.\"\n\nHe added, \"That is the best way to unite our nation.\"\n\nIt was a belated fulfillment of his 2020 pledge to be a bridge to a new generation of leaders -- and a bow to the drumbeat of calls from within his party to step aside.\n\nBiden's address was carried live by the major broadcast and cable news networks. He spooled out an weighty to-do list for his last six months in office, pledging to remain focused on being president until his term expires at noon on Jan. 20, 2025. He said he would work to end the war between Israel and Hamas in Gaza, fight to boost government support to cure cancer and push for Supreme Court reform, among other things.\n\nThe president sought to use the address to outline the stakes in the election, which both Biden and Harris have framed as a choice between freedom and chaos, but he tried to steer clear of overt campaigning from his official office.\n\n\"The great thing about America is here, kings and dictators do not rule,\" Biden said. \"The people do. History is in your hands. The power is in your hands. The idea of America -- lies in your hands.\"\n\nBiden was also making the case for his legacy of sweeping domestic legislation and the renewal of alliances abroad. But the way history will remember his time in office and his historic decision to step aside is intertwined with Harris' electoral result in November, particularly as the vice president runs tightly on the achievements of the Biden administration.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nHis advisers say he intends to hold campaign events and fundraisers benefiting Harris, whom Biden praised as \"tough\" and \"capable,\" albeit at a far slower pace than if he had remained on the ballot himself.\n\nHarris advisers will ultimately have to decide how to deploy the president, whose popularity sagged as voters in both parties questioned his fitness for office.\n\nBiden, aides say, knows that if Harris loses, he'll be criticized for staying in the race too long and not giving her or another Democrat time to effectively mount a campaign against Trump. If she wins, she'll ensure his policy victories are secured and expanded, and he'll be remembered for a Washingtonian decision to step aside for the next generation of leadership.\n\nBiden said he's grateful to have served as president -- nowhere else would a kid with a stutter grow up to sit in the Oval Office.\n\n\"I've given my heart and my soul to our nation,\" he said. \"I've been blessed a million times in return.\"\n\nPress secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said Wednesday that any question of Biden resigning his office before the election -- which would allow Harris to run as an incumbent -- was \"ridiculous.\"\n\nJean-Pierre said Biden has \"no regrets\" about his decision to stay in the race as long as he did, or his decision to quit it over the weekend. She said Biden's decision had nothing to do with his health.\n\nRead more: Government-politics Harris steps into the limelight. "United States"}}}, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2020-01-", "textStart": 2746, "textEnd": 2753}], "sentiment": 0.01960784313725483, "wgt": 185, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8242188443", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "01:40:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T01:40:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T01:39:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://heraldcourier.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/biden-delivers-solemn-call-to-defend-democracy-as-he-lays-out-his-reasons-for-quitting/article_c90ae1f3-9b84-5ca9-9898-bf91d82353a0.html", "title": "Biden delivers solemn call to defend democracy as he lays out his reasons for quitting race", "body": "WASHINGTON -- President Joe Biden on Wednesday delivered a solemn call to voters to defend the country's democracy as he laid out in an Oval Office address his decision to drop his bid for reelection and throw his support behind Vice President Kamala Harris.\n\nInsisting that \"the defense of democracy is more important than any title,\" Biden used his first public address since his announcement Sunday that he was stepping aside to deliver an implicit repudiation of former President Donald Trump. He did not directly call out Trump, whom he has called an existential threat to democracy. The 10-minute address also gave Biden a chance to try to shape how history will remember his one and only term in office.\n\nPeople are also reading... National Ice Cream Day 2024: Get cool deals and freebies at Dairy Queen, Cold Stone and more HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: All Wolves now playing at West Ridge Kilgore remembered as \"larger than life\" trailblazer Bristol Casino records solid $14.35M month during June Housing complex rehab in Saltville wins $2.4 million state loan Campus keeps tradition strong This theater season brings friendship, camaraderie and nostalgia to the stage Only the name has changed; 'The Classic' expected to become bigger and better Southern Gap Outdoor Adventure Unveils New Entrance Sign Herald Courier receives awards from Tennessee Press Association HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: Next man up part of high school football BRIEFS: VHSL to hold public forum at Abingdon on Wednesday; Top-15 finish for Adam Hooker (Lebanon) at State Open of Virginia PREP FOOTBALL: Marquee games await Northeast Tennessee teams Wise free clinics have come a long way in a quarter century Washington board updated on new cell phone directive\n\n\"Nothing, nothing can come in the way of saving our democracy,\" Biden said. \"And that includes personal ambition.\"\n\nIt was a moment for the history books -- a U.S. president reflecting before the nation on why he was taking the rare step of voluntarily handing off power. It hasn't been done since 1968, when Lyndon Johnson announced he would not seek reelection in the heat of the Vietnam War.\n\n\"I revere this office,\" Biden said. \"But I love my country more.\"\n\nTrump, just an hour earlier at a campaign rally, revived his baseless claims of voter fraud in the 2020 presidential election, which he lost to Biden. His refusal to concede inspired the Capitol insurrection of Jan. 6, 2021, which Biden called \"the worst attack on our democracy since the Civil War.\"\n\nBiden skirted the political reality that brought him to that point: His abysmal performance in a debate against Trump nearly a month ago, where he spoke haltingly, appeared ashen and failed to rebut his predecessor's attacks, sparked a crisis of confidence from Democrats. Lawmakers and ordinary voters questioned not just whether he was capable of beating Trump in November, but also whether, at 81, he was still fit for the high-pressure job.\n\nBiden tried to outlast the skepticism and quell the concerns with interviews and tepid rallies, but the pressure to step aside only mounted from the party's political elites and from ordinary voters.\n\n\"I have decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation,\" Biden said, saying he wanted to make room for \"fresh voices, yes, younger voices.\"\n\nHe added, \"That is the best way to unite our nation.\"\n\nIt was a belated fulfillment of his 2020 pledge to be a bridge to a new generation of leaders -- and a bow to the drumbeat of calls from within his party to step aside.\n\nBiden's address was carried live by the major broadcast and cable news networks. He spooled out an weighty to-do list for his last six months in office, pledging to remain focused on being president until his term expires at noon on Jan. 20, 2025. He said he would work to end the war between Israel and Hamas in Gaza, fight to boost government support to cure cancer and push for Supreme Court reform, among other things.\n\nThe president sought to use the address to outline the stakes in the election, which both Biden and Harris have framed as a choice between freedom and chaos, but he tried to steer clear of overt campaigning from his official office.\n\n\"The great thing about America is here, kings and dictators do not rule,\" Biden said. \"The people do. History is in your hands. The power is in your hands. The idea of America -- lies in your hands.\"\n\nBiden was also making the case for his legacy of sweeping domestic legislation and the renewal of alliances abroad. But the way history will remember his time in office and his historic decision to step aside is intertwined with Harris' electoral result in November, particularly as the vice president runs tightly on the achievements of the Biden administration.\n\nHis advisers say he intends to hold campaign events and fundraisers benefiting Harris, whom Biden praised as \"tough\" and \"capable,\" albeit at a far slower pace than if he had remained on the ballot himself.\n\nHarris advisers will ultimately have to decide how to deploy the president, whose popularity sagged as voters in both parties questioned his fitness for office.\n\nBiden, aides say, knows that if Harris loses, he'll be criticized for staying in the race too long and not giving her or another Democrat time to effectively mount a campaign against Trump. If she wins, she'll ensure his policy victories are secured and expanded, and he'll be remembered for a Washingtonian decision to step aside for the next generation of leadership.\n\nBiden said he's grateful to have served as president -- nowhere else would a kid with a stutter grow up to sit in the Oval Office.\n\n\"I've given my heart and my soul to our nation,\" he said. \"I've been blessed a million times in return.\"\n\nPress secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said Wednesday that any question of Biden resigning his office before the election -- which would allow Harris to run as an incumbent -- was \"ridiculous.\"\n\nJean-Pierre said Biden has \"no regrets\" about his decision to stay in the race as long as he did, or his decision to quit it over the weekend. She said Biden's decision had nothing to do with his health.\n\nRead more: Government-politics Harris steps into the limelight. {"uri": "8242189118", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "01:41:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T01:41:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T01:40:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.etonline.com/president-joe-biden-addresses-nation-for-first-time-since-dropping-out-of-2024-presidential-race", "title": "Joe Biden Addresses Nation After Dropping Out of Presidential Race", "body": "President Joe Biden announced he was dropping out of the race and endorsing Kamala Harris earlier this month.\n\nAddressing the nation on camera for the first time since announcing his decision not to run for reelection, President Joe Biden said in the Oval Office that saving democracy is more important than any title, and he acknowledged it was time to \"pass the torch\" to a new generation of leaders.\n\nYears ago, Biden called himself a transitional candidate, and listed Vice President Kamala Harris among the younger generation of leaders he saw as the future of the Democratic Party. Now is the time to make way for those newer, younger voices, he said, like that of Harris, whom he has endorsed for the nomination.\n\nThough he did not mention Republican nominee and former President Donald Trump by name, Biden has referred to Trump as a threat to democracy.\n\n\"I believe my record as president, my leadership in the world, my vision for America's future, all merited a second term,\" the president said. \"But nothing, nothing, can come in the way of saving our democracy. That includes personal ambition. So, I've decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation. That's the best way to unite our nation. You know, there is a time and a place for long years of experience in public life. But there's also a time and a place for new voices, fresh voices, yes, younger voices. And that time and place is now.\"\n\nBiden hinted that he had arrived at the decision to drop out in part because of doubts over whether he could defeat Trump.\n\n\"I revere this office, but I love my country more,\" the president said. \"It's been the honor of my life to serve as your president. But in the defense of democracy, which is at stake, I think it's more important than any title.\"\n\nBiden took a moment to reflect and marvel at where his life had begun, long before his 51-year-long political journey.\n\n\"Nowhere else on earth could a kid with a stutter from modest beginnings in Scranton and Claymont one day sit behind the Resolute Desk in the Oval Office as president of the United States,\" he said. \"But here I am. That's what's so special about America.\"\n\nThe president expressed his gratitude to the American people, and praised the country as a nation of possibilities.\n\n\"It has been the privilege of my life to serve this nation for over 50 years,\" he said, adding, \"I have given my heart and my soul to so many nation, like so many others. I'm blessed a million times in return with the love and support of the American people. I hope you have some idea of how grateful I am, to all of you.\"\n\nFor the remaining six months of his term, Biden said he plans to focus on the job of the presidency. He plans to continue to try to lower costs for families, defend personal freedoms, protect the right to vote, and fight against cancer. He said he also plans to continue to speak out against gun violence, and call for Supreme Court reform.\n\nAbroad, the president said he would continue to make NATO stronger, support Ukraine's fight for freedom, and work to end the war in Gaza.\n\nMr. Biden, who ran on the idea that democracy itself was at stake in 2020 and is again in 2024 with Trump as the Republican nominee, reminded Americans that they are the ones who will determine America's destiny: \"The great thing about America is here, kings and dictators do not rule. The people do. History is in your hands. The power is in your hands. The idea of America -- lies in your hands.\"\n\nThe president also listed what he believes are his greatest achievements, including lowering the racial wealth gap, passing bipartisan infrastructure funding, achieving wins against big Pharma, lowering the cost of prescription drugs, compensating veterans exposed to toxic materials and putting the first African American woman on the Supreme Court.\n\nWhite House staffers gathered across the White House to watch the president's remarks.\n\nDemocrats have fallen in line behind Harris, after Biden endorsed her for the nomination soon after announcing he would end his campaign. Biden cannot appoint a successor for the Democratic nomination, but since his announcement on Sunday, Harris has secured the endorsements of a majority of Democratic delegates.\n\nThe president has said little since his decision while he recovered from COVID-19 symptoms at his home in Rehoboth Beach, Delaware. The White House said Tuesday that he had tested negative, and Biden told reporters upon his return from Delaware that he's feeling \"well.\"\n\nOval Office addresses are rare for a president, including for Biden. Before last week, Biden had only delivered two Oval Office addresses in his three-and-a-half years as president. Last week, he delivered his third Oval Office address, following the assassination attempt against former President Trump.\n\nAlthough Biden plans to participate in the campaign, stepping down from the Democratic ticket allows him to focus on the task of the presidency itself, away from the physically taxing campaign trail.\n\n\"I'm not going anywhere,\" the president told his campaign staff -- who are now Harris' campaign staff -- Monday. \"I'm going to be out there on the campaign with her, with Kamala. I'm going to be working like hell, both as a sitting president, getting legislation passed, as well as -- and campaigning.\"\n\nThis Oval Office address, as well as any speech the president gives next month at the Democratic National Convention, is among the most critical of not just Biden's presidency, but of his legacy, as he completes more than five decades in public service.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8242135252", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "00:36:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T00:36:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T00:35:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://dothaneagle.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/biden-addresses-nation-on-decision-to-drop-2024-reelection-bid-democracy-is-more-important-than/article_68ed08bd-3a70-50ae-a2d1-d68d5548e122.html", "title": "Biden addresses nation on decision to drop 2024 reelection bid: 'Democracy is more important than any title'", "body": "WASHINGTON -- Insisting that \"the defense of democracy is more important than any title,\" President Joe Biden on Wednesday explained in an Oval Office address his decision to drop his bid for reelection and to throw his support behind Vice President Kamala Harris.\n\nThe address offered the public their first chance to hear directly from Biden his rationale for dropping out of the 2024 after weeks of insisting he believed himself to be the best candidate to take on former President Donald Trump, whom he has called an existential threat to the nation's democracy. It also gave Biden a chance to try to shape how history views his one and only term in office.\n\n\"The defense of democracy is more important than any title,\" Biden said. \"Nothing, nothing can come in the way of saving our democracy. And that includes personal ambition.\"\n\nSaid Biden, \"I revere this office, but I love my country more.\"\n\nBiden's candidacy faced a crisis of confidence from Democrats after his abysmal debate against Trump nearly a month ago, where he spoke haltingly, appeared ashen and failed to rebut his predecessor's attacks. It sparked a mutiny within his party over not just whether he was capable of beating Trump in November, but also whether at 81, he was still fit for the high-pressure job.\n\nBiden tried to outlast the skepticism and quell the concerns with interviews and tepid rallies, but the pressure to step aside only mounted from the party's political elites and from ordinary voters.\n\nOn Sunday afternoon, while isolating at his Rehoboth Beach, Delaware, home with COVID-19, Biden finally bowed in a letter posted to his account on X announcing his decision to leave the race, followed up later by an endorsement of Harris.\n\n\"I have decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation,\" Biden said, saying he wanted to make room for \"fresh voices, yes, younger voices.\"\n\nHe added, \"That is the best way to unite our nation.\"\n\nBiden's address was being carried by the major broadcast and cable news networks. He pledge to remain focused on being president until his term expires at noon on Jan. 20, 2025, saying he would work to end the war between Israel and Hamas in Gaza, fight to boost government support to cure cancer, and call for Supreme Court reform.\n\nThe president was hoping to use the address to outline the stakes in the election, which both Biden and Harris have framed as a choice between freedom and chaos, but he tried to steer clear of overt campaigning from his official office and never mentioned Trump by name.\n\n\"The great thing about America is here, kings and dictators do not rule,\" Biden said. \"The people do. History is in your hands. The power is in your hands. The idea of America -- lies in your hands.\"\n\nBiden was also looking to make the case for his legacy of sweeping domestic legislation and the renewal of alliances abroad. The way history will remember his time in office and his historic decision to step aside is intertwined with Harris' electoral result in November, particularly as the vice president runs tightly on the achievements of the Biden administration.\n\nHis advisers say he intends to hold campaign events and fundraisers benefiting Harris, albeit at a far slower pace than if he had remained on the ballot himself.\n\nHarris advisers will ultimately have to decide how to deploy the president, whose popularity sagged as voters in both parties questioned his fitness for office.\n\nBiden, aides say, knows that if Harris loses, he'll be criticized for staying in the race too long and not giving her or another Democrat time to effectively mount a campaign against Trump. If she wins, she'll ensure his policy victories are secured and expanded, and he'll be remembered for a Washingtonian decision to step aside for the next generation of leadership.\n\nPress secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said Wednesday that any question of Biden resigning his office -- which would allow Harris to run as an incumbent -- was \"ridiculous.\"\n\nJean-Pierre said Biden has \"no regrets\" about his decision to stay in the race as long as he did, or his decision to quit it over the weekend. She said Biden's decision had nothing to do with his health.\n\nRead more: Government-politics Harris steps into the limelight.
