{"uri": "8242170108", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "01:17:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T01:17:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T01:17:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://mcdowellnews.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/biden-delivers-solemn-call-to-defend-democracy-as-he-lays-out-his-reasons-for-quitting/article_f9497a1e-c8d0-50f5-884b-f27398c8da7f.html", "title": "Biden delivers solemn call to defend democracy as he lays out his reasons for quitting race", "body": "WASHINGTON -- President Joe Biden on Wednesday delivered a solemn call to voters to defend the country's democracy as he laid out in an Oval Office address his decision to drop his bid for reelection and throw his support behind Vice President Kamala Harris.\n\nInsisting that \"the defense of democracy is more important than any title,\" Biden used his first public address since his announcement Sunday that he was stepping aside to deliver an implicit repudiation of former President Donald Trump. He did not directly call out Trump, whom he has called an existential threat to democracy. The 10-minute address also gave Biden a chance to try to shape how history will remember his one and only term in office.\n\nPeople are also reading... Roaming Buffalo Outpost moving from Rutherford Road to Marion's North Main Street Roses Discount Store in Marion set to close in August 2 teens who died after crash during Greensboro police chase had just finished middle school. A 15-year-old also died. Expanded grocery, new mural: Remodeled Marion Walmart shows off renovations McDowell alum, WCU pitcher aims for major league draft in 2025 Catawba County mother charged in death of 9-month-old appears in court Marion's splash pad damaged in act of vandalism Young child found wandering on road in Morganton alone; mother charged McDowell County man charged with three counts of extortion Marion councilman is delegate to Republican convention in Milwaukee Two Marion women charged with drug crimes Avery County woman charged in McDowell for drug crimes Three Lenoir residents charged; More than 400 grams of meth seized Play by McDowell 14-year-old centers on Marion water treatment Art on Hickory oil tanker truck highlights efforts to prevent veteran suicide\n\n\"Nothing, nothing can come in the way of saving our democracy,\" Biden said. \"And that includes personal ambition.\"\n\nIt was a moment for the history books -- a U.S. president reflecting before the nation on why he was taking the rare step of voluntarily handing off power. It hasn't been done since 1968, when Lyndon Johnson announced he would not seek reelection in the heat of the Vietnam War.\n\n\"I revere this office,\" Biden said. \"But I love my country more.\"\n\nTrump, just an hour earlier at a campaign rally, revived his baseless claims of voter fraud in the 2020 presidential election, which he lost to Biden. His refusal to concede inspired the Capitol insurrection of Jan. 6, 2021, which Biden called \"the worst attack on our democracy since the Civil War.\"\n\nBiden skirted the political reality that brought him to that point: His abysmal performance in a debate against Trump nearly a month ago, where he spoke haltingly, appeared ashen and failed to rebut his predecessor's attacks, sparked a crisis of confidence from Democrats. Lawmakers and ordinary voters questioned not just whether he was capable of beating Trump in November, but also whether, at 81, he was still fit for the high-pressure job.\n\nBiden tried to outlast the skepticism and quell the concerns with interviews and tepid rallies, but the pressure to step aside only mounted from the party's political elites and from ordinary voters.\n\n\"I have decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation,\" Biden said, saying he wanted to make room for \"fresh voices, yes, younger voices.\"\n\nHe added, \"That is the best way to unite our nation.\"\n\nIt was a belated fulfillment of his 2020 pledge to be a bridge to a new generation of leaders -- and a bow to the drumbeat of calls from within his party to step aside.\n\nBiden's address was carried live by the major broadcast and cable news networks. He spooled out an weighty to-do list for his last six months in office, pledging to remain focused on being president until his term expires at noon on Jan. 20, 2025. He said he would work to end the war between Israel and Hamas in Gaza, fight to boost government support to cure cancer and push for Supreme Court reform, among other things.\n\nThe president sought to use the address to outline the stakes in the election, which both Biden and Harris have framed as a choice between freedom and chaos, but he tried to steer clear of overt campaigning from his official office.\n\n\"The great thing about America is here, kings and dictators do not rule,\" Biden said. \"The people do. History is in your hands. The power is in your hands. The idea of America -- lies in your hands.\"\n\nBiden was also making the case for his legacy of sweeping domestic legislation and the renewal of alliances abroad. But the way history will remember his time in office and his historic decision to step aside is intertwined with Harris' electoral result in November, particularly as the vice president runs tightly on the achievements of the Biden administration.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nHis advisers say he intends to hold campaign events and fundraisers benefiting Harris, whom Biden praised as \"tough\" and \"capable,\" albeit at a far slower pace than if he had remained on the ballot himself.\n\nHarris advisers will ultimately have to decide how to deploy the president, whose popularity sagged as voters in both parties questioned his fitness for office.\n\nBiden, aides say, knows that if Harris loses, he'll be criticized for staying in the race too long and not giving her or another Democrat time to effectively mount a campaign against Trump. If she wins, she'll ensure his policy victories are secured and expanded, and he'll be remembered for a Washingtonian decision to step aside for the next generation of leadership.\n\nBiden said he's grateful to have served as president -- nowhere else would a kid with a stutter grow up to sit in the Oval Office.\n\n\"I've given my heart and my soul to our nation,\" he said. \"I've been blessed a million times in return.\"\n\nPress secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said Wednesday that any question of Biden resigning his office before the election -- which would allow Harris to run as an incumbent -- was \"ridiculous.\"\n\nJean-Pierre said Biden has \"no regrets\" about his decision to stay in the race as long as he did, or his decision to quit it over the weekend. She said Biden's decision had nothing to do with his health.\n\nRead more: Politics Harris steps into the limelight. "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9761289", "eventUri": "eng-9761289", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Washington (state)"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": {"uri": "8242178128", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "01:28:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T01:28:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T01:28:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://siouxcityjournal.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/biden-delivers-solemn-call-to-defend-democracy-as-he-lays-out-his-reasons-for-quitting/article_9cc0381a-4c32-52b8-9c60-1a4440b020e6.html", "title": "Biden delivers solemn call to defend democracy as he lays out his reasons for quitting race", "body": "WASHINGTON -- President Joe Biden on Wednesday delivered a solemn call to voters to defend the country's democracy as he laid out in an Oval Office address his decision to drop his bid for reelection and throw his support behind Vice President Kamala Harris.\n\nInsisting that \"the defense of democracy is more important than any title,\" Biden used his first public address since his announcement Sunday that he was stepping aside to deliver an implicit repudiation of former President Donald Trump. He did not directly call out Trump, whom he has called an existential threat to democracy. The 10-minute address also gave Biden a chance to try to shape how history will remember his one and only term in office.\n\nPeople are also reading... Two dead following Sunday night two-vehicle accident in Sioux City's westside Woodbury County Court Report for July 22, 2024 Specialty dog boutique store, Urban Mutts, opens in Sioux City BNSF Railway wants to remove collapsed Big Sioux River train bridge One dead after early Saturday morning collision in Sioux City Jason's Frozen Treats open second dine-in ice cream parlor Sioux City substitute teachers to receive extra pay for outside of normal day work UPDATED: Okoboji lakes fall below target for lifting boat speeding limits High school baseball: Bleeker's walk-off lifts Crusaders over Warriors in substate final Overnight fire closes Spirit Lake Walmart Iowa nursing home resident suffocated while trapped in bed rails, state says State seeks to use Dakota Dunes homicide suspect's confession at trial Marriage licenses for Woodbury County for July 23, 2024 River-Cade crowns 2024 Queen of the River and princesses in Sioux City ceremony There's no place like the stage, The New Stage Players presents the Wizard of Oz\n\n\"Nothing, nothing can come in the way of saving our democracy,\" Biden said. \"And that includes personal ambition.\"\n\nIt was a moment for the history books -- a U.S. president reflecting before the nation on why he was taking the rare step of voluntarily handing off power. It hasn't been done since 1968, when Lyndon Johnson announced he would not seek reelection in the heat of the Vietnam War.\n\n\"I revere this office,\" Biden said. \"But I love my country more.\"\n\nTrump, just an hour earlier at a campaign rally, revived his baseless claims of voter fraud in the 2020 presidential election, which he lost to Biden. His refusal to concede inspired the Capitol insurrection of Jan. 6, 2021, which Biden called \"the worst attack on our democracy since the Civil War.\"\n\nBiden skirted the political reality that brought him to that point: His abysmal performance in a debate against Trump nearly a month ago, where he spoke haltingly, appeared ashen and failed to rebut his predecessor's attacks, sparked a crisis of confidence from Democrats. Lawmakers and ordinary voters questioned not just whether he was capable of beating Trump in November, but also whether, at 81, he was still fit for the high-pressure job.\n\nBiden tried to outlast the skepticism and quell the concerns with interviews and tepid rallies, but the pressure to step aside only mounted from the party's political elites and from ordinary voters.\n\n\"I have decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation,\" Biden said, saying he wanted to make room for \"fresh voices, yes, younger voices.\"\n\nHe added, \"That is the best way to unite our nation.\"\n\nIt was a belated fulfillment of his 2020 pledge to be a bridge to a new generation of leaders -- and a bow to the drumbeat of calls from within his party to step aside.\n\nBiden's address was carried live by the major broadcast and cable news networks. He spooled out an weighty to-do list for his last six months in office, pledging to remain focused on being president until his term expires at noon on Jan. 20, 2025. He said he would work to end the war between Israel and Hamas in Gaza, fight to boost government support to cure cancer and push for Supreme Court reform, among other things.\n\nThe president sought to use the address to outline the stakes in the election, which both Biden and Harris have framed as a choice between freedom and chaos, but he tried to steer clear of overt campaigning from his official office.\n\n\"The great thing about America is here, kings and dictators do not rule,\" Biden said. \"The people do. History is in your hands. The power is in your hands. The idea of America -- lies in your hands.\"\n\nBiden was also making the case for his legacy of sweeping domestic legislation and the renewal of alliances abroad. But the way history will remember his time in office and his historic decision to step aside is intertwined with Harris' electoral result in November, particularly as the vice president runs tightly on the achievements of the Biden administration.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nHis advisers say he intends to hold campaign events and fundraisers benefiting Harris, whom Biden praised as \"tough\" and \"capable,\" albeit at a far slower pace than if he had remained on the ballot himself.\n\nHarris advisers will ultimately have to decide how to deploy the president, whose popularity sagged as voters in both parties questioned his fitness for office.\n\nBiden, aides say, knows that if Harris loses, he'll be criticized for staying in the race too long and not giving her or another Democrat time to effectively mount a campaign against Trump. If she wins, she'll ensure his policy victories are secured and expanded, and he'll be remembered for a Washingtonian decision to step aside for the next generation of leadership.\n\nBiden said he's grateful to have served as president -- nowhere else would a kid with a stutter grow up to sit in the Oval Office.\n\n\"I've given my heart and my soul to our nation,\" he said. \"I've been blessed a million times in return.\"\n\nPress secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said Wednesday that any question of Biden resigning his office before the election -- which would allow Harris to run as an incumbent -- was \"ridiculous.\"\n\nJean-Pierre said Biden has \"no regrets\" about his decision to stay in the race as long as he did, or his decision to quit it over the weekend. She said Biden's decision had nothing to do with his health.\n\nRead more: Government-politics Harris steps into the limelight. {"uri": "8242143043", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "00:53:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T00:53:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T00:44:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/joe-biden-oval-office-address-224609105.html", "title": "Joe Biden Says That He Exited Race Because It Was Time To \"Pass The Torch\" To Next Generation: \"I Revere This Office, But I Love My Country More\"", "body": "UPDATE: President Joe Biden, in an Oval Office speech, said that he concluded in recent weeks that \"the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation.\"\n\n\"It's the best way to unite our nation,\" Biden said, elaborating on his decision to drop out of the 2024 presidential race.\n\nMore from Deadline\n\n\"You know, there is a time and a place for long years of experience in public life; there's also a time and a place for new voices, fresh voices, yes, younger voices, and that time and place is now.\"\n\nBiden said that in recent weeks, \"it became clear to me that I need to unite my party in this critical endeavor. I believe our record as president, our leadership in the world, my vision for America's future all merited a second term, but nothing, nothing can come in the way of saving our democracy.\"\n\nBiden's 11-minute of remarks was a valedictory of his accomplishments during his term. He reminded that when he took office, the country was still in the midst of \"the worst pandemic in a century, the worst economic crisis since the Great Depression\" and \"the worst attack on our democracy since the Civil War.\"\n\n\"We came together as Americans. We got through it. We emerged stronger and more prosperous and more secure,\" he said.\n\nThe president also talked of his political career, including more than 50 years in the Senate, as vice president and as president.\n\n\"No where else on earth could a kid with a stutter -- from modest beginnings in Scranton, Pennsylvania and Claymont, Delaware -- one day sit behind the Resolute Desk in the Oval Office as president of United States,\" Biden said. \"But here I am.\"\n\nBut Biden said that \"I revere this office, but I love my country more,\" as he framed the upcoming election as one that will \"choose the course of America's future.\" He reiterated his endorsement of Vice President Kamala Harris at the top of the Democratic ticket, while not mentioning the name of Donald Trump.\n\nInstead, as he outlined the stakes of the race, he quoted from Benjamin Franklin, asked if the founders had given the country a monarch or a republican. \"Franklin's response was, 'A republic -- if you can keep it.\"\n\nWith a whip round domestic and international situations, Biden laid out a fairly ambitious last few months of his administration at home and abroad. That includes what he called Supreme Court reform, with reports that he will propose setting term limits for justices rather than lifetime appointments.\n\nIn his speech, Biden did not talk of any health issues or concerns that he had slipped in recent months, culminating in a dismal debate performance on June 27. But in talking of his desire to unite the party, the president was referring to the three weeks of discord since then, as donors and lawmakers called for him to step aside given the stakes of the election.\n\nPREVIOUSLY: President Joe Biden plans to tell viewers Wednesday night that \"the defense of democracy is more important than any title,\" as he delivers an Oval Office address following his decision to drop out of the 2024 presidential race.\n\n\"I draw strength, and find joy, in working for the American people,\" Biden plans to say, according to excerpts released today by the White House. \"But this sacred task of perfecting our Union is not about me. It's about you. Your families. Your futures.\"\n\nBiden also plans to say that he \"decided that the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation. That is the best way to unite our nation.\"\n\nBiden returned to the White House on Tuesday, two days after he released a letter on X/Twitter announcing that he was standing down in the presidential campaign. Shortly after that, he endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris to take his place atop the Democratic ticket.\n\nBroadcast networks plan special reports on Biden's remarks, set to start at 8 p.m. ET/5 p.m. PT, with coverage also across cable news and streaming channels.\n\nIn his remarks, Biden also plans to say that he will be \"focused on my job as president\" in the remaining six months of his term.\n\n\"That means I will continue to lower costs for hard-working families and grow our economy. I will keep defending our personal freedoms and our civil rights - from the right to vote - to the right to choose,\" Biden plans to say.\n\n\"That means I will continue to lower costs for hard-working families and grow our economy. I will keep defending our personal freedoms and our civil rights - from the right to vote - to the right to choose,\" the president will say.\n\nEarlier today, White House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre told reporters that the suggestion that Biden should resign now was \"ridiculous.\" She said that the president's decision to drop out of the race was \"not about his health,\" and that he believed that he could serve another four years. She said that the decision to drop out was made on Saturday evening, when he met with a small group of advisers, and the decision was finalized the next day. The letter was posted to social media at 1:46 p.m. ET.\n\nThe Democratic National Committee's Rules Committee this afternoon approved plans for a virtual roll call of delegates to select the next nominee as soon as August 1. Those plans were in the works before Biden dropped out because of concerns that the Democratic National Convention, to be held August 19-22 in Chicago, would be too close to state ballot deadlines.\n\nHarris already has amassed enough pledged delegates to secure the nomination, with no major opposition challenging her so far.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8242189712", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "01:42:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T01:42:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T01:40:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.socialnews.xyz/2024/07/24/passing-the-torch-to-new-generation-says-biden-to-americans-after-exiting-presidential-race/", "title": "'Passing the torch to new generation', says Biden to Americans after exiting presidential race", "body": "Washington, July 25 (SocialNews.XYZ) US President Joe Biden has said he is \"passing the torch to a new generation\" as he explained his abrupt departure from the 2024 presidential race to Americans for the first time on Wednesday night, in an Oval Office address capping over 50 years in politics, media reported.\n\nBiden also said \"even though he reveres the office of the presidency, \"I love my country more.\"\n\n\"I have decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation,\" he added from the Oval Office, USA Today reported, adding: \"That is the best way to unite our nation.\"\n\nIn his first public remarks since dropping out of the presidential race on Sunday, Biden pledged during a sombre 10-minute address to spend his last six months in office working to make sure the US remains strong, secure and the leader of the free world.\n\n\"The defence of democracy is more important than any title,\" he said.\n\n\"I draw strength, and find joy, in working for the American people. But this sacred task of perfecting our union is not about me. It's about you. Your families. Your futures. It's about 'We the People'.\"\n\nBiden ended his campaign for a second term on Sunday after weeks of pressure from nervous Democrats and major donors, who feared he would lose to former President Donald Trump, the current Republican nominee. Biden's withdrawal threw the presidential race into unchartered territory just four months before the election, USA Today reported.\n\nVice-President Kamala Harris quickly announced that she would run for President, and Biden offered her his endorsement.\n\nHarris has since raised more than $126 million for her nascent campaign and has already secured more than enough delegates to win the Democratic Party's nomination.\n\nIn the letter announcing his decision to pull out of the race, Biden said while it had always been his intention to run for a second term, \"I believe it is in the best interest of my party and the country to stand down and to focus solely on fulfilling my duties as President for the remainder of my term.\"\n\nThe pressure on Biden to drop out started to build after a disastrous debate with Trump last month raised questions about his physical and mental acuity and his ability to serve another four-year term. But the White House insisted on Monday, just a few hours before Biden's speech, that concerns about his health had nothing to do with his decision to exit the race.\n\nIn his remarks, Biden made it clear he plans to serve out the remainder of his term, USA Today reported.\n\nHe said he plans to spend the next six months doing his job as President - working to lower costs for families, growing the economy and defending personal freedoms and civil rights, from the right to vote to the right to choose.\n\nHe added that he would continue rallying a coalition of allies to stop Russian President Vladimir Putin from taking over Ukraine and would keep working to end the war in Gaza and bring peace to the Middle East.\n\nBiden said he would also continue to pursue Supreme Court reform and his \"Moonshot\" program to end cancer.\n\nThe US remains a nation of \"promise and possibilities, of dreamers and doers,\" he added.\n\nWhile Biden spoke, First Lady Jill Biden, son Hunter Biden and other members of his family stood along the Oval Office's curved walls.\n\nIn a reference to the upcoming election, Biden gave a shoutout to Harris, saying she had been an incredible partner and a leader for the country.\n\nNow, he said, the future direction of the country is up to the American people.\n\n\"The great thing about America is, here, kings and dictators do not rule,\" he said.\n\n\"The people do. History is in your hands. The power is in your hands. "https://i0.wp.com/www.socialnews.xyz/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/25/202407253192671.webp?fit=660%2C441&quality=80&zoom=1&ssl=1", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9761289", "eventUri": "eng-9761289", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Washington (state)"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, {"uri": "2024-07-432693743", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "01:18:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T01:18:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T01:10:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.nwitimes.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/biden-delivers-solemn-call-to-defend-democracy-as-he-lays-out-his-reasons-for-quitting/article_2de07865-d8ad-5eda-8fed-8785d671450e.html", "title": "Biden delivers solemn call to defend democracy as he lays out his reasons for quitting race", "body": "In a rare Oval Office address to the nation explaining why he stepped down from the 2024 presidential race, President Joe Biden said he believes the best way to unite the nation is to \"pass the torch to a new generation.\"\n\nWASHINGTON -- President Joe Biden on Wednesday delivered a solemn call to voters to defend the country's democracy as he laid out in an Oval Office address his decision to drop his bid for reelection and throw his support behind Vice President Kamala Harris.\n\nInsisting that \"the defense of democracy is more important than any title,\" Biden used his first public address since his announcement Sunday that he was stepping aside to deliver an implicit repudiation of former President Donald Trump. He did not directly call out Trump, whom he has called an existential threat to democracy. The 10-minute address also gave Biden a chance to try to shape how history will remember his one and only term in office.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nNorthwoods Falls closes in St. John, owners hope temporarily Davich: Frankly, this is the best hot dog joint in the Region Ex-Crown Point real estate agents indicted on charges of $5 million in COVID relief fraud after allegedly spending money on Porsche and country club UPDATE: Valpo man identified as motorcyclist killed when SUV reportedly made sudden U-turn Valparaiso tornado confirmed as county calls state in for help Mascot Hall of Fame to close in September, 'going out with confetti' UPDATE: Cedar Lake woman killed in Monday's storm remembered as 'rock of the family' Crown Point man led chase, soiled police vehicle, report says Report: Man stopped from jumping to I-94 says officer was first to care for him in long time Former Lake County councilman could avoid jail time yet again in 3rd domestic battery case Valpo jewelry store burglarized; holes cut in wall, cops say Portage officers injured during high-speed chase with bikers armed with AK-47, report says Sunday night house fire draws out several departments NWI Business Ins and Outs: Royale with Cheese, Top of the Morning, Casa Blanca, Estella's Cantina, El Jimador, Jet's Pizza, Wingstop and Wing Snob opening Portage man upset over paying all the bills repeatedly fired gun in his backyard, cops say\n\n\"Nothing, nothing can come in the way of saving our democracy,\" Biden said. \"And that includes personal ambition.\"\n\nIt was a moment for the history books -- a U.S. president reflecting before the nation on why he was taking the rare step of voluntarily handing off power. It hasn't been done since 1968, when Lyndon Johnson announced he would not seek reelection in the heat of the Vietnam War.\n\n\"I revere this office,\" Biden said. \"But I love my country more.\"\n\nTrump, just an hour earlier at a campaign rally, revived his baseless claims of voter fraud in the 2020 presidential election, which he lost to Biden. His refusal to concede inspired the Capitol insurrection of Jan. 6, 2021, which Biden called \"the worst attack on our democracy since the Civil War.\"\n\nBiden skirted the political reality that brought him to that point: His abysmal performance in a debate against Trump nearly a month ago, where he spoke haltingly, appeared ashen and failed to rebut his predecessor's attacks, sparked a crisis of confidence from Democrats. Lawmakers and ordinary voters questioned not just whether he was capable of beating Trump in November, but also whether, at 81, he was still fit for the high-pressure job.\n\nBiden tried to outlast the skepticism and quell the concerns with interviews and tepid rallies, but the pressure to step aside only mounted from the party's political elites and from ordinary voters.\n\n\"I have decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation,\" Biden said, saying he wanted to make room for \"fresh voices, yes, younger voices.\"\n\nHe added, \"That is the best way to unite our nation.\"\n\nIt was a belated fulfillment of his 2020 pledge to be a bridge to a new generation of leaders -- and a bow to the drumbeat of calls from within his party to step aside.\n\nBiden's address was carried live by the major broadcast and cable news networks. He spooled out an weighty to-do list for his last six months in office, pledging to remain focused on being president until his term expires at noon on Jan. 20, 2025. He said he would work to end the war between Israel and Hamas in Gaza, fight to boost government support to cure cancer and push for Supreme Court reform, among other things.\n\nThe president sought to use the address to outline the stakes in the election, which both Biden and Harris have framed as a choice between freedom and chaos, but he tried to steer clear of overt campaigning from his official office.\n\n\"The great thing about America is here, kings and dictators do not rule,\" Biden said. \"The people do. History is in your hands. The power is in your hands. The idea of America -- lies in your hands.\"\n\nBiden was also making the case for his legacy of sweeping domestic legislation and the renewal of alliances abroad. But the way history will remember his time in office and his historic decision to step aside is intertwined with Harris' electoral result in November, particularly as the vice president runs tightly on the achievements of the Biden administration.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nHis advisers say he intends to hold campaign events and fundraisers benefiting Harris, whom Biden praised as \"tough\" and \"capable,\" albeit at a far slower pace than if he had remained on the ballot himself.\n\nHarris advisers will ultimately have to decide how to deploy the president, whose popularity sagged as voters in both parties questioned his fitness for office.\n\nBiden, aides say, knows that if Harris loses, he'll be criticized for staying in the race too long and not giving her or another Democrat time to effectively mount a campaign against Trump. If she wins, she'll ensure his policy victories are secured and expanded, and he'll be remembered for a Washingtonian decision to step aside for the next generation of leadership.\n\nBiden said he's grateful to have served as president -- nowhere else would a kid with a stutter grow up to sit in the Oval Office.\n\n\"I've given my heart and my soul to our nation,\" he said. \"I've been blessed a million times in return.\"\n\nPress secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said Wednesday that any question of Biden resigning his office before the election -- which would allow Harris to run as an incumbent -- was \"ridiculous.\"\n\nJean-Pierre said Biden has \"no regrets\" about his decision to stay in the race as long as he did, or his decision to quit it over the weekend. She said Biden's decision had nothing to do with his health.\n\nRead more:\n\nGovernment-politics\n\nHarris steps into the limelight. And the coconut trees and memes have followed\n\nMEG KINNARD and CURTIS YEE Associated Press\n\nGovernment-politics\n\nHarris has support of enough Democratic delegates to become party's presidential nominee: AP survey\n\nZEKE MILLER and SEUNG MIN KIM Associated Press\n\nGovernment-politics\n\nHarris gets a chance to press reset on the 2024 race against Trump\n\nCHRIS MEGERIAN Associated Press\n\nGovernment-politics\n\nBiden drops out of race, endorses VP Harris after disastrous debate inflamed age concerns\n\nCOLLEEN LONG, ZEKE MILLER and DARLENE SUPERVILLE Associated Press\n\nGovernment-politics\n\nTrump's campaign quickly pivots to Harris after Biden announces decision to leave the race\n\nJILL COLVIN and MICHELLE L. {"uri": "2024-07-432687507", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "01:05:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T01:05:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T00:45:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://journalstar.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/biden-explains-decision-to-quit-race-begins-to-shape-legacy-democracy-is-more-important-than/article_f0adad67-162c-5791-bd4d-209a230504d8.html", "title": "Biden explains decision to quit race, begins to shape legacy: 'Democracy is more important than any title'", "body": "President Biden spoke about his decision to step aside from the 2024 presidential election during an Oval Office address Wednesday.\n\nWASHINGTON -- Insisting that \"the defense of democracy is more important than any title,\" President Joe Biden on Wednesday explained in an Oval Office address his decision to drop his bid for reelection and to throw his support behind Vice President Kamala Harris.\n\nThe address offered the public their first chance to hear directly from Biden his rationale for dropping out of the 2024 after weeks of insisting he believed himself to be the best candidate to take on former President Donald Trump, whom he has called an existential threat to the nation's democracy. It also gave Biden a chance to try to shape how history views his one and only term in office.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nLincoln restaurant calls it quits after 15 years 'Ready to learn from this': John Cook updates Harper Murray's status for 2024 season 'Exhausting, heartbreaking, devastating': Racism at Wayne school pushes family out of Nebraska Former Nebraska Sen. Ben Sasse to resign as University of Florida president Fleet Farm backed out of northwest Lincoln development This Nebraska couple runs a senior dog sanctuary just outside of Lincoln Recruiting: New Nebraska football staffer aims for pair of 2026 four-star targets Guatemalan chicken restaurant puts Lincoln, Gretna and Crete on its expansion map Teen accused of causing train derailment near Bennet before recording it Nebraska volleyball's Harper Murray sentenced to probation for DUI Judge orders Nebraska Department of Transportation to turn over records of intersection study Is it legal to turn on red traffic arrows in Lincoln? What new Nebraska law says Pedestrian struck by car in west Lincoln dies at hospital, police say Lincoln Animal Control reports first-ever rabies case in a fox 'Death Row:' Nebraska defensive line room embracing new nickname\n\n\"The defense of democracy is more important than any title,\" Biden said. \"Nothing, nothing can come in the way of saving our democracy. And that includes personal ambition.\"\n\nSaid Biden, \"I revere this office, but I love my country more.\"\n\nBiden's candidacy faced a crisis of confidence from Democrats after his abysmal debate against Trump nearly a month ago, where he spoke haltingly, appeared ashen and failed to rebut his predecessor's attacks. It sparked a mutiny within his party over not just whether he was capable of beating Trump in November, but also whether at 81, he was still fit for the high-pressure job.\n\nBiden tried to outlast the skepticism and quell the concerns with interviews and tepid rallies, but the pressure to step aside only mounted from the party's political elites and from ordinary voters.\n\nOn Sunday afternoon, while isolating at his Rehoboth Beach, Delaware, home with COVID-19, Biden finally bowed in a letter posted to his account on X announcing his decision to leave the race, followed up later by an endorsement of Harris.\n\n\"I have decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation,\" Biden said, saying he wanted to make room for \"fresh voices, yes, younger voices.\"\n\nHe added, \"That is the best way to unite our nation.\"\n\nBiden's address was being carried by the major broadcast and cable news networks. He pledge to remain focused on being president until his term expires at noon on Jan. 20, 2025, saying he would work to end the war between Israel and Hamas in Gaza, fight to boost government support to cure cancer, and call for Supreme Court reform.\n\nThe president was hoping to use the address to outline the stakes in the election, which both Biden and Harris have framed as a choice between freedom and chaos, but he tried to steer clear of overt campaigning from his official office and never mentioned Trump by name.\n\n\"The great thing about America is here, kings and dictators do not rule,\" Biden said. \"The people do. History is in your hands. The power is in your hands. The idea of America -- lies in your hands.\"\n\nBiden was also looking to make the case for his legacy of sweeping domestic legislation and the renewal of alliances abroad. The way history will remember his time in office and his historic decision to step aside is intertwined with Harris' electoral result in November, particularly as the vice president runs tightly on the achievements of the Biden administration.\n\nHis advisers say he intends to hold campaign events and fundraisers benefiting Harris, albeit at a far slower pace than if he had remained on the ballot himself.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nHarris advisers will ultimately have to decide how to deploy the president, whose popularity sagged as voters in both parties questioned his fitness for office.\n\nBiden, aides say, knows that if Harris loses, he'll be criticized for staying in the race too long and not giving her or another Democrat time to effectively mount a campaign against Trump. If she wins, she'll ensure his policy victories are secured and expanded, and he'll be remembered for a Washingtonian decision to step aside for the next generation of leadership.\n\nPress secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said Wednesday that any question of Biden resigning his office -- which would allow Harris to run as an incumbent -- was \"ridiculous.\"\n\nJean-Pierre said Biden has \"no regrets\" about his decision to stay in the race as long as he did, or his decision to quit it over the weekend. She said Biden's decision had nothing to do with his health.\n\nRead more:\n\nGovernment-politics\n\nHarris steps into the limelight. And the coconut trees and memes have followed\n\nMEG KINNARD and CURTIS YEE Associated Press\n\nGovernment-politics\n\nHarris has support of enough Democratic delegates to become party's presidential nominee: AP survey\n\nZEKE MILLER and SEUNG MIN KIM Associated Press\n\nGovernment-politics\n\nHarris gets a chance to press reset on the 2024 race against Trump\n\nCHRIS MEGERIAN Associated Press\n\nGovernment-politics\n\nBiden drops out of race, endorses VP Harris after disastrous debate inflamed age concerns\n\nCOLLEEN LONG, ZEKE MILLER and DARLENE SUPERVILLE Associated Press\n\nGovernment-politics\n\nTrump's campaign quickly pivots to Harris after Biden announces decision to leave the race\n\nJILL COLVIN and MICHELLE L. {"uri": "8242132046", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "00:32:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T00:32:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T00:31:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://mcdowellnews.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/biden-addresses-nation-on-decision-to-drop-2024-reelection-bid-democracy-is-more-important-than/article_f9497a1e-c8d0-50f5-884b-f27398c8da7f.html", "title": "Biden addresses nation on decision to drop 2024 reelection bid: 'Democracy is more important than any title'", "body": "WASHINGTON -- Insisting that \"the defense of democracy is more important than any title,\" President Joe Biden on Wednesday explained in an Oval Office address his decision to drop his bid for reelection and to throw his support behind Vice President Kamala Harris.\n\nThe address offered the public their first chance to hear directly from Biden his rationale for dropping out of the 2024 after weeks of insisting he believed himself to be the best candidate to take on former President Donald Trump, whom he has called an existential threat to the nation's democracy. It also gave Biden a chance to try to shape how history views his one and only term in office.\n\nPeople are also reading... Roaming Buffalo Outpost moving from Rutherford Road to Marion's North Main Street Roses Discount Store in Marion set to close in August 2 teens who died after crash during Greensboro police chase had just finished middle school. A 15-year-old also died. Expanded grocery, new mural: Remodeled Marion Walmart shows off renovations McDowell alum, WCU pitcher aims for major league draft in 2025 Catawba County mother charged in death of 9-month-old appears in court Marion's splash pad damaged in act of vandalism Young child found wandering on road in Morganton alone; mother charged McDowell County man charged with three counts of extortion Marion councilman is delegate to Republican convention in Milwaukee Two Marion women charged with drug crimes Avery County woman charged in McDowell for drug crimes Three Lenoir residents charged; More than 400 grams of meth seized Play by McDowell 14-year-old centers on Marion water treatment Art on Hickory oil tanker truck highlights efforts to prevent veteran suicide\n\n\"The defense of democracy is more important than any title,\" Biden said. \"Nothing, nothing can come in the way of saving our democracy. And that includes personal ambition.\"\n\nSaid Biden, \"I revere this office, but I love my country more.\"\n\nBiden's candidacy faced a crisis of confidence from Democrats after his abysmal debate against Trump nearly a month ago, where he spoke haltingly, appeared ashen and failed to rebut his predecessor's attacks. It sparked a mutiny within his party over not just whether he was capable of beating Trump in November, but also whether at 81, he was still fit for the high-pressure job.\n\nBiden tried to outlast the skepticism and quell the concerns with interviews and tepid rallies, but the pressure to step aside only mounted from the party's political elites and from ordinary voters.\n\nOn Sunday afternoon, while isolating at his Rehoboth Beach, Delaware, home with COVID-19, Biden finally bowed in a letter posted to his account on X announcing his decision to leave the race, followed up later by an endorsement of Harris.\n\n\"I have decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation,\" Biden said, saying he wanted to make room for \"fresh voices, yes, younger voices.\"\n\nHe added, \"That is the best way to unite our nation.\"\n\nBiden's address was being carried by the major broadcast and cable news networks. He pledge to remain focused on being president until his term expires at noon on Jan. 20, 2025, saying he would work to end the war between Israel and Hamas in Gaza, fight to boost government support to cure cancer, and call for Supreme Court reform.\n\nThe president was hoping to use the address to outline the stakes in the election, which both Biden and Harris have framed as a choice between freedom and chaos, but he tried to steer clear of overt campaigning from his official office and never mentioned Trump by name.\n\n\"The great thing about America is here, kings and dictators do not rule,\" Biden said. \"The people do. History is in your hands. The power is in your hands. The idea of America -- lies in your hands.\"\n\nBiden was also looking to make the case for his legacy of sweeping domestic legislation and the renewal of alliances abroad. The way history will remember his time in office and his historic decision to step aside is intertwined with Harris' electoral result in November, particularly as the vice president runs tightly on the achievements of the Biden administration.\n\nHis advisers say he intends to hold campaign events and fundraisers benefiting Harris, albeit at a far slower pace than if he had remained on the ballot himself.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nHarris advisers will ultimately have to decide how to deploy the president, whose popularity sagged as voters in both parties questioned his fitness for office.\n\nBiden, aides say, knows that if Harris loses, he'll be criticized for staying in the race too long and not giving her or another Democrat time to effectively mount a campaign against Trump. If she wins, she'll ensure his policy victories are secured and expanded, and he'll be remembered for a Washingtonian decision to step aside for the next generation of leadership.\n\nPress secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said Wednesday that any question of Biden resigning his office -- which would allow Harris to run as an incumbent -- was \"ridiculous.\"\n\nJean-Pierre said Biden has \"no regrets\" about his decision to stay in the race as long as he did, or his decision to quit it over the weekend. She said Biden's decision had nothing to do with his health.\n\nRead more: Politics Harris steps into the limelight. {"uri": "2024-07-432674036", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "00:36:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T00:36:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T00:34:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://eu.mycentraljersey.com/story/news/politics/elections/2024/07/24/joe-biden-oval-office-2024-election/74529714007/", "title": "Joe Biden addresses nation: 'Best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation'", "body": "Joe Biden started his political career in 1970, first as a Republican. He became a lifelong Democrat when he won his Senate seat two years later.\n\nWASHINGTON - President Joe Biden said in a primetime address to the nation on Wednesday that he ended his campaign for a second term because, even though he reveres the office of the presidency, \"I love my country more.\"\n\nIn his first public remarks since ending his campaign for a second term, Biden said from the Oval Office that he decided to drop out of the presidential race because while he reveres the office, \"I love my country more.\"\n\n\"I have decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation,\" he said. \"That is the best way to unite our nation.\"\n\nThe defense of democracy is more important than any title, he said in his 10-minute address. But Biden said while he draws strength in working for the American people, \"this sacred task of perfecting our union is not about me.\"\n\n\"It's about you. Your families. Your futures,\" he said. \"It's about 'We the People.'\"\n\nBiden ended his campaign for a second term on Sunday after weeks of pressure from nervous Democrats and major donors, who feared he would lose to former President Donald Trump, the Republican nominee. Biden's withdrawal threw the presidential race into unchartered territory just four months before the election.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris quickly announced that she would run for president, and Biden offered her his endorsement. Harris has since raised more than $126 million for her nascent campaign and has already secured more than enough delegates to win the party's nomination.\n\nFull-blown crisis: An inside look at Biden campaign's pitfalls.\n\nIn the letter announcing his decision to pull out of the race, Biden said while it had always been his intention to run for a second term, \"I believe it is in the best interest of my party and the country to stand down and to focus solely on fulfilling my duties as president for the remainder of my term.\"\n\nThe pressure on Biden to drop out started to build after a disastrous debate with Trump last month raised questions about his physical and mental acuity and his ability to serve another four-year term. But the White House insisted Monday, just a few hours before Biden's speech, that concerns about his health had nothing to do with his decision to exit the race.\n\nIn his remarks, Biden made it clear he plans to serve out the remainder of his term.\n\nBiden said he plans to spend the next six months doing his job as president - working to lower costs for families, growing the economy and defending personal freedoms and civil rights, from the right to vote to the right to choose.\n\nHe said he would continue rallying a coalition of allies to stop Russian President Vladimir Putin from taking over Ukraine and would keep working to end the war in Gaza and bring peace to the Middle East.\n\n'A brave act': Americans react to President Biden's historic decision\n\nThe United States remains a nation of \"promise and possibilities, of dreamers and doers.\"\n\n\"The great thing about America is here, kings and dictators do not rule,\" he said. \"The people do. History is in your hands. The power is in your hands. The idea of America - lies in your hands.\"\n\nMichael Collins covers the White House. He became a lifelong Democrat when he won his Senate seat two years later.\n\nWASHINGTON - President Joe Biden said in a primetime address to the nation on Wednesday that he ended his campaign for a second term because, even though he reveres the office of the presidency, \"I love my country more.\"\n\n\"I have decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation,\" he said from the Oval Office. \"That is the best way to unite our nation.\"\n\nIn his first public remarks since dropping out of the presidential race on Sunday, Biden pledged during a somber 10-minute address to spend his last six months in office working to make sure the United States remains strong, secure and the leader of the free world.\n\n\"The defense of democracy is more important than any title,\" he said. \"I draw strength, and find joy, in working for the American people. But this sacred task of perfecting our union is not about me. It's about you. Your families. Your futures. It's about 'We the People.'\"\n\nBiden ended his campaign for a second term on Sunday after weeks of pressure from nervous Democrats and major donors, who feared he would lose to former President Donald Trump, the Republican nominee. Biden's withdrawal threw the presidential race into unchartered territory just four months before the election.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris quickly announced that she would run for president, and Biden offered her his endorsement. Harris has since raised more than $126 million for her nascent campaign and has already secured more than enough delegates to win the party's nomination.\n\nFull-blown crisis: An inside look at Biden campaign's pitfalls.\n\nIn the letter announcing his decision to pull out of the race, Biden said while it had always been his intention to run for a second term, \"I believe it is in the best interest of my party and the country to stand down and to focus solely on fulfilling my duties as president for the remainder of my term.\"\n\nThe pressure on Biden to drop out started to build after a disastrous debate with Trump last month raised questions about his physical and mental acuity and his ability to serve another four-year term. But the White House insisted Monday, just a few hours before Biden's speech, that concerns about his health had nothing to do with his decision to exit the race.\n\nIn his remarks, Biden made it clear he plans to serve out the remainder of his term.\n\nBiden said he plans to spend the next six months doing his job as president - working to lower costs for families, growing the economy and defending personal freedoms and civil rights, from the right to vote to the right to choose.\n\nHe said he would continue rallying a coalition of allies to stop Russian President Vladimir Putin from taking over Ukraine and would keep working to end the war in Gaza and bring peace to the Middle East.\n\n'A brave act': Americans react to President Biden's historic decision\n\nThe United States remains a nation of \"promise and possibilities, of dreamers and doers.\"\n\n\"The great thing about America is here, kings and dictators do not rule,\" he said. \"The people do. History is in your hands. The power is in your hands. The idea of America - lies in your hands.\"\n\nMichael Collins covers the White House. {"uri": "8242196805", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "01:52:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T01:52:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T01:50:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://expressdigest.com/biden-mumbles-as-he-reveals-why-he-decided-to-pass-the-torch-and-insists-he-could-have-served-four-more-years-as-president-in-address-to-nation/", "title": "Biden mumbles as he reveals why he decided to 'pass the torch' and insists he could have served four more years as president in address to nation", "body": "President Joe Biden mumbled his way through an 11-minute farewell address to the nation and claimed he could have served another four years if he wanted to.\n\nBiden, 81, spoke quietly, at times haltingly, and his voice was scratchy as he explained his stunning decision not to seek re-election.\n\nThe President said he had chosen to 'pass the torch' to Vice President Kamala Harris because it was time for 'younger voices' and he believed that would 'unite' the country and 'save' democracy.\n\nBiden looked intently into the camera during the primetime address for which he was seated behind the Resolute Desk in the Oval Office.\n\nHe said: 'I believe my record as president, my leadership in the world, my vision for America's future all merited a second term.\n\n'But nothing, nothing, can come in the way of saving our democracy, and that includes personal ambition, so I decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation.'\n\nHe added: 'There is a time and a place for long years of experience in public life. There's also a time and a place for new voices fresh voices. Yes, younger voices.'\n\nBiden did not address questions over his own age, health and mental acuity, which have undermined his presidency from the start.\n\nDoubts about his ability to do the job intensified following a disastrous debate performance last month, which led senior Democrats to call for him to leave the 2024 presidential race.\n\nPresident Joe Biden, in an Oval Office address, revealed why he decided to step down as the Democratic nominee\n\nFrom right: Jill Biden, Ashley Biden and husband Howard Krein, and Hunter Biden and his daugther Finnegan listen to Joe Biden speak\n\nAs Biden spoke his wife Jill Biden, and children Hunter and Ashley, sat to his left along a wall watching his valedictory.\n\nAlso present were several of his grandchildren including Naomi Biden and Maisy Biden.\n\nThe family broke into applause when the president finished speaking. Jill Biden joined him at the Resolute Desk, and Hunter Biden hugged his father.\n\nBiden, who has just recovered from a bout of COVID fumbled briefly in his delivery, mumbling at times.\n\nHe used the address to outline his legacy and said he has more work to do in the six months he has left in office.\n\nHunter Biden gives his dad a hug\n\nHe said: 'I revere this office but I love my country more.\n\n'It's been the honor of my life to serve as your president but the defense of democracy, which is at stake, I think is more important than a title.'\n\nBiden made it clear he is stepping down voluntarily, drawing a stark contrast with his predecessor.\n\nHe did not mention Donald Trump by name but talked about how the country is more important than ambition to stay in the Oval Office.\n\n'America is an idea - an idea stronger than any army, bigger than any ocean, more powerful than any dictator,' Biden said.\n\nAs the president spoke, his staff were gathered one floor up, on the state floor of the White House, to watch his remarks with wine and pizza.\n\nBefore the speech began, staffers were spotted walking in from the Eisenhower Executive Office Building, which is across the street of the West Wing, into the White House proper for the event.\n\nBiden's decision to step down sent shock waves throughout the world and ended his political career that has lasted more than 50 years.\n\nHe has already endorsed Harris and turned over his campaign infrastructure to her. The campaign has renamed itself 'Harris for President.'\n\nWithin 30 hours of Biden announcing on Sunday that he was stepping aside Harris had pledges from enough delegates to win the Democratic Party's presidential nomination.\n\nIn his speech on Wednesday night, Biden did not explicitly endorse Harris but noted he had 'made my views known.'\n\nHe said: 'I made my choice. I've made my views known. I'd like to thank our great Vice President Kamala Harris. She's experienced. She's tough. She's capable. She's been an incredible partner to me and a leader for our country.\n\n'Now the choice is up to you, the American people.'\n\nHunter Biden, his daughter Finnegan, Howard Krein, Ashley Biden and Jill Biden in the Oval\n\nJill Biden joined Joe Biden at the Resolute Desk when he finished his speech\n\nPresident Joe Biden returning to Delaware after being diagnosed with COVID\n\nDemocratic delegates will nominate their presidential ticket virtually in early August ahead of the Democratic National Convention, which kicks off August 19th in Chicago.\n\nThe president returned to the White House on Tuesday after spending six days isolating in his beach house in Delaware, where he was suffering from COVID.\n\nHe has canceled a West Coast fundraising swing scheduled for the end of the week.\n\nHe will meet with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu at the White House on Thursday.\n\nBiden spent weeks rebuffing pressure from senior figures in his party to step down as its nominee. But, on Sunday, he bowed to the inevitable.\n\nHe is the first incumbent president not to seek re-election since 1968 when Lyndon Johnson, under fire for his handling of the Vietnam War, abruptly pulled out of the campaign on March 31.\n\nThe president also joins James K. Polk, James Buchanan, Rutherford B. Hayes, Calvin Coolidge and Harry Truman as presidents who all decided not to stand for a second term.\n\nMeanwhile, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre on Wednesday denied there was a 'cover-up' of Biden's declining health and mental capabilities by staff and Biden family members.\n\nBiden's top spokesperson was grilled repeatedly about his apparent change of heart when it came to a second term and denied his health had anything to do with the decision.\n\nDuring her press briefing - the first since Biden's historic decision to step down as the Democratic nominee - Fox News' Peter Doocy asked her: 'It would seem that people in this White House knew that President Biden was slipping and it was hidden from the American people - so who ordered White House officials to coverup a declining president?'\n\n'There's been no coverup,' she replied.\n\nFor weeks Jean-Pierre and other aides had denied Biden was considering leaving the presidential race.\n\nThey had denied reports his health was on the decline.\n\nBut, in the June 26th presidential debate, Biden repeatedly fumbled for words and froze on camera, leading to questions from his own party about his ability to serve a second term in the White House.\n\nWhite House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre denied there was a 'coverup' of President Joe Biden 's health and mental capabilities\n\nJean-Pierre said the president made his decision in 'very short period of time.'\n\nShe pushed back against reports that aides, lawmakers and Democratic officials had noticed for months that Biden was on the decline.\n\nShe also said his health was not a factor in his decision to exit the presidential race.\n\n'It has nothing to do with his health,' she said. 'I can say, no, that's not the reason.'\n\nShe also called calls for the president to resign from office 'ridiculous.'\n\nThere have been questions as to why, if Biden can't serve four more years, he can serve six more months.\n\nJean-Pierre argued that Biden was capable of serving out a full second term.\n\n'He didn't step down from from campaigning or from running because he didn't believe he can serve in a second term. {"uri": "8242134300", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "00:35:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T00:35:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T00:33:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/business/money-report/biden-to-say-defense-of-democracy-drove-his-exit-in-oval-office-address/3602482/", "title": "Biden says 'defense of democracy' drove his exit in Oval Office address", "body": "\"I draw strength, and find joy, in working for the American people,\" Biden said from the Oval Office.\n\n\"But this sacred task of perfecting our union is not about me. It's about you. Your families. Your futures. It's about 'We the People.' \"\n\n\"I gave my heart and my soul to our nation,\" Biden said. \"I hope you have some idea how grateful I am to all of you.\"\n\nBiden's speech comes three days after the 81-year-old president quit the race against former President Donald Trump, the Republican nominee, and threw his full support behind Harris.\n\n\"I have decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation,\" Biden said.\n\n\"That is the best way to unite our nation.\"\n\nBiden, without mentioning Trump by name, nodded to the threat he believes the Republican represents to the United States if he is elected in November, and to the risk Biden would have run if he remained in the race.\n\n\"I ran for president four years ago because I believed and still do, that the soul of America was a stake,\" said Biden, who defeated Trump in 2020. \"The very nature of who we are was a stake. And that's still the case.\"\n\nBut, the president said that in recent weeks it had been made clear to him that \"I need to unite my party in this critical endeavor.\"\n\nBiden said his record \"merited a second term.\"\n\n\"But nothing, nothing can come in the way of saving our democracy,\" the president said. \"That includes personal ambition.\"\n\nBiden, who plans to serve out the remainder of his first term, which ends in January, returned to Washington on Tuesday after several days of isolating at his Delaware beach house, recovering from Covid-19.\n\nBiden's decision to exit the race on Sunday during that Covid quarantine came after a weeks-long pressure campaign from Democratic lawmakers, donors and strategists calling on him to step aside after his stumbling June debate performance against Trump.\n\nThe debate fumble escalated lingering concerns regarding Biden's age and fitness to wage a successful campaign against Trump, much less complete a second presidential term.\n\nSince Sunday, the Biden-turned-Harris campaign has been in a honeymoon phase.\n\nHarris has secured the endorsements of hundreds of Democratic lawmakers and governing officials, including those who were previously floated as potential contenders to replace Biden at the top of the ticket.\n\nThose names have now been ruled out as potential Harris challengers and instead are on the list to become her running mate.\n\nHarris has also raked in record levels of donations online and from high-dollar donors. Her first several campaign rallies have seen more attendees than any the campaign has seen this election cycle. And she is starting to catch up to Trump in the polls, according to initial voter surveys.\n\nBiden in his speech Wednesday gave his vice president another full-throated endorsement\n\n\"I made my choice. I made my views known. I'd like to thank our great Vice President Kamala Harris,\" he said. \"She experienced. She's tough, she's capable. She's been an incredible partner to me. And the leader for our country. Now, the choice is up to you, the American people. \"\n\nBiden then reminded Americans about their power in the election.\n\n\"The great thing about America is here, kings and dictators do not rule,\" the president said.\n\n\"The people do. History is in your hands. The power is in your hands. The idea of America - lies in your hands.\"\n\nThere were about 40 people watching Biden in the Oval Office as he delivered his speech, including members of his family.\n\nWhen he finished speaking, {"uri": "8242196531", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "01:52:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T01:52:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T01:50:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://ktar.com/story/5584956/bidens-speech-warnings-about-trump-without-naming-him-a-hefty-to-do-list-and-a-power-handoff/", "title": "Biden's speech: Warnings about Trump without naming him, a hefty to-do list, and a power handoff", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- President Joe Biden delivered a solemn Oval Office address Wednesday that laid out in the clearest terms yet why he abandoned his reelection campaign.\n\nHe wanted to send an unmistakable warning about Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump while anointing Vice President Kamala Harris as his natural successor, without invoking an overtly political tone that would have been out of step in the official setting of the White House. He was determined to show that he would not act like a lame-duck president, outlining an ambitious agenda that underscored his resolve to continue building on his legacy.\n\nBiden did not mention Trump, his former Republican opponent, in his 10-minute Oval Office address -- but he didn't have to. The remarks were imbued with a deep sense of urgency about what the outgoing president saw as the stakes of the election.\n\nThe early part of his address sketched the choices that faces voters in November -- a contrast Biden himself had hoped to make during a reelection campaign that he ultimately decided he could not continue.\n\n\"Americans are going to have to choose between moving forward or backward, between hope and hate, between unity and division,\" Biden said. \"We have to decide -- do we still believe in honesty, decency, respect, freedom, justice and democracy.\"\n\nThat last item -- democracy -- and defending it is \"more important than any title,\" Biden said.\n\nThe president says he's going to keep working over his final six months in office. He's seeking to make the case for his legacy of sweeping domestic legislation and the renewal of alliances abroad.\n\nHis to-do list was full of weighty issues. He said he'd work to end the war in Gaza, bring home the hostages and try \"to bring peace and security to the Middle East and end this war.\" Biden meets Thursday with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.\n\nHe's going to continue to work to lower costs for families and defend personal freedoms, keep calling out \"hate and extremism\" and push to end gun violence.\n\nHe also said he would continue to work on his initiative to end cancer as we know it and push for Supreme Court reforms.\n\n\"I'm going to keep working,\" he said.\n\nBiden finally understood what Democrats had been telling him -- that it was time to hand off power to a younger generation -- and he embraced it, calling for \"fresh voices, yes, younger voices\" in politics.\n\n\"I've decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation. It's the best way to unite our nation,\" he said, even as he believed his presidency was deserving of a second term.\n\nFor months, Biden insisted that only he could go up against Trump and win. But that changed following his debate with Trump on June 27, when he spoke haltingly, lost his train of thought and failed to fact-check the former president's falsehoods. The performance raised a chorus of questions about his age and ability to do the job another four years and pushed Democrats to increasingly call for him to step aside. The standoff dragged for 24 days before Biden yielded, saying he needed to unify his party.\n\nBiden is not a stranger to the sober address, delivering remarks on weighty matters such as the fate of democracy and voting rights at historically significant landmarks across the country and around the globe.\n\nBut Biden has used the formal trappings of an Oval Office address -- a tool used by presidents in times of national crisis or to capture a key moment in history -- sparsely, with Wednesday's speech marking just the fourth time that he has sat behind the Resolute Desk to speak directly to the nation.\n\nHis tone was solemn, the delivery careful and deliberate. He was surrounded by family and close aides as he gave an address willingly relinquishing power -- one that no politician wants to make.\n\n\"The great thing about America is here, kings and dictators do not rule -- that people do,\" Biden said as he closed his address. \"History is in your hands. The power is in your hands. The idea of America lies in your hands.\"\n\nIn the official setting of the Oval Office, Biden steered clear of overt political talk. But he still praised Vice President Kamala Harris as \"tough\" and \"capable,\" and gave a not-so-subtle push to voters.\n\n\"She's been an incredible partner for her leadership, for our country,\" he said. \"Now the choice is up to you, the American people. \"\n\nFirst lady Jill Biden posted a hand-written note after the president's speech thanking \"those who never wavered, who refused to doubt.\" She thanked supporters for putting their trust in the president. \"Now it's time to put that trust in Kamala.\"\n\nBiden, aides say, knows that if Harris loses, he'll be criticized for staying in the race too long and not giving her or another Democrat time to effectively mount a campaign against Trump. If she wins, she'll ensure his policy victories are secured and expanded, and he'll be remembered for a decision to step aside for the next generation of leadership.", "source": {"uri": "ktar.com", {"uri": "8242143758", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "00:45:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T00:45:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T00:44:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/world-news/biden-uses-oval-office-address-to-explain-his-decision-to-quit-2024-race/a891246727.html", "title": "Biden uses Oval Office address to explain his decision to quit 2024 race", "body": "The address offered the public their first chance to hear directly from Mr Biden his rationale for dropping out of the 2024 presidential race after weeks of insisting he believed himself to be the best candidate to take on former president Donald Trump, whom he has called an existential threat to the nation's democracy.\n\nIt also gave Mr Biden a chance to try to shape how history views his only term in office.\n\n\"The defence of democracy is more important than any title,\" Mr Biden said. \"Nothing, nothing can come in the way of saving our democracy. And that includes personal ambition.\n\n\"I revere this office, but I love my country more.\"\n\nMr Biden's candidacy faced a crisis of confidence from Democrats after his debate against Mr Trump nearly a month ago, where he spoke haltingly, appeared ashen and failed to rebut his predecessor's attacks.\n\nIt sparked a mutiny within his party over not just whether he was capable of beating Mr Trump in November, but also whether at 81, he was still fit for the high-pressure job.\n\nMr Biden tried to outlast the scepticism and quell the concerns with interviews and tepid rallies, but the pressure to step aside only mounted from the party's political elites and from ordinary voters.\n\nOn Sunday afternoon, while isolating at his Rehoboth Beach, Delaware, home with Covid-19, Mr Biden finally bowed in a letter posted to his account on X announcing his decision to leave the race, followed by an endorsement of Ms Harris.\n\n\"I have decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation,\" Mr Biden said, saying he wanted to make room for \"fresh voices, yes, younger voices\".\n\nHe added: \"That is the best way to unite our nation.\"\n\nMr Biden pledged to remain focused on being president until his term expires at noon on January 20 2025, saying he would work to end the war between Israel and Hamas in Gaza, fight to boost government support to cure cancer and call for Supreme Court reform.\n\nThe president was hoping to use the address to outline the stakes in the election, which both Mr Biden and Ms Harris have framed as a choice between freedom and chaos, but he tried to steer clear of overt campaigning from his official office and never mentioned Mr Trump by name.\n\n\"The great thing about America is here, kings and dictators do not rule,\" Mr Biden said. \"The people do. History is in your hands. The power is in your hands. The idea of America -- lies in your hands.\"\n\nMr Biden was also looking to make the case for his legacy of sweeping domestic legislation and the renewal of alliances abroad.\n\nThe way history will remember his time in office and his historic decision to step aside is intertwined with Ms Harris' electoral result in November, particularly as the vice president runs tightly on the achievements of the Biden administration.\n\nHis advisers say he intends to hold campaign events and fundraisers benefiting Ms Harris, albeit at a far slower pace than if he had remained on the ballot himself.\n\nMs Harris's advisers will ultimately have to decide how to deploy the president, whose popularity sagged as voters in both parties questioned his fitness for office.\n\nMr Biden, aides say, knows that if Ms Harris loses, he will be criticised for staying in the race too long and not giving her or another Democrat time to effectively mount a campaign against Mr Trump.\n\nIf she wins, she will ensure his policy victories are secured and expanded, and he will be remembered for a Washingtonian decision to step aside for the next generation of leadership.", "source": {"uri": "belfasttelegraph.co.uk",
