{"uri": "2024-07-432664026", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "00:15:05", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T00:15:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T00:09:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://qctimes.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/biden-addressing-nation-on-his-decision-to-drop-his-2024-democratic-reelection-bid/article_e7334300-bc1a-559d-a00b-510384875ad0.html", "title": "Biden addressing nation on his decision to drop his 2024 Democratic reelection bid", "body": "ZEKE MILLER, SEUNG MIN KIM and WILL WEISSERT Associated Press\n\nWASHINGTON -- Insisting that \"the defense of democracy is more important than any title,\" President Joe Biden on Wednesday explained in an Oval Office address his decision to drop his bid for reelection and to throw his support behind Vice President Kamala Harris.\n\nThe address offered the public their first chance to hear directly from Biden his rationale for dropping out of the 2024 after weeks of insisting he believed himself to be the best candidate to take on former President Donald Trump, whom he has called an existential threat to the nation's democracy. It also gave Biden a chance to try to shape how history views his one and only term in office.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nNew business coming to Davenport's former Bed Bath & Beyond Deere held employee meeting Wednesday, no word yet on potential layoffs for Quad-Cities Two injured in shooting at NorthPark Mall in Davenport Monday Witnesses describe gunfire at NorthPark Mall that injured 2 Quad-Cities business openings: New furniture store coming to Davenport, other happenings Davenport code enforcement officer quits after argument with boss over Wold-owned duplex Teen arrested in relation to shooting at NorthPark Mall in Davenport Deere rolls back diversity, equity, inclusion initiatives after conservative backlash Several Davenport teens accused of gang crimes; police report group violence down overall Timeless Tickets: East Moline-raised rapper Torrian Ball remembers opening for Lil Durk in 2021 Second person dies after Friday house fire in Riverdale One injured in Scott County motorcycle crash Davenport developer pulls 16-unit central city development at Sixth and Sylvan Iowa nursing home resident suffocated while trapped in bed rails, state says One person found dead during Riverdale house fire early Friday morning\n\n\"The defense of democracy is more important than any title,\" Biden said. \"I draw strength, and find joy, in working FOR the American people. But this sacred task of perfecting our Union is not about me. It's about you. Your families. Your futures. It's about 'We the People.'\"\n\nBiden's candidacy faced a crisis of confidence from Democrats after his abysmal debate against Trump nearly a month ago, where he spoke haltingly, appeared ashen and failed to rebut his predecessor's attacks. It sparked a mutiny within his party over not just whether he was capable of beating Trump in November, but also whether at 81, he was still fit for the high-pressure job.\n\nBiden tried to outlast the skepticism and quell the concerns with interviews and tepid rallies, but the pressure to step aside only mounted from the party's political elites and from ordinary voters.\n\nOn Sunday afternoon, while isolating at his Rehoboth Beach, Delaware, home with COVID-19, Biden finally bowed in a letter posted to his account on X announcing his decision to leave the race, followed up later by an endorsement of Harris.\n\n\"I have decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation,\" Biden said. \"That is the best way to unite our nation.\"\n\nBiden's address was being carried by the major television news networks. He pledge to remain focused on being president until his term expires at noon on Jan. 20, 2025.\n\nThe president was hoping to use the address to outline the stakes in the election, which both Biden and Harris have framed as a choice between freedom and chaos, but was expected to try to steer clear of overt campaigning from his official office or even mentioning Trump by name.\n\n\"The great thing about America is here, kings and dictators do not rule,\" Biden said. \"The people do. History is in your hands. The power is in your hands. The idea of America -- lies in your hands.\"\n\nBiden was also looking to make the case for his legacy of sweeping domestic legislation and the renewal of alliances abroad. The way history will remember his time in office and his historic decision to step aside is intertwined with Harris' electoral result in November, particularly as the vice president runs tightly on the achievements of the Biden administration.\n\nHis advisers say he intends to hold campaign events and fundraisers benefiting Harris, albeit at a far slower pace than if he had remained on the ballot himself.\n\nHarris advisers will ultimately have to decide how to deploy the president, whose popularity sagged as voters in both parties questioned his fitness for office.\n\nBiden, aides say, knows that if Harris loses, he'll be criticized for staying in the race too long and not giving her or another Democrat time to effectively mount a campaign against Trump. If she wins, she'll ensure his policy victories are secured and expanded, and he'll be remembered for a Washingtonian decision to step aside for the next generation of leadership.\n\nPress secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said Wednesday that any question of Biden resigning his office -- which would allow Harris to run as an incumbent -- was \"ridiculous.\"\n\nJean-Pierre said Biden has \"no regrets\" about his decision to stay in the race as long as he did, or his decision to quit it over the weekend. She said Biden's decision had nothing to do with his health.\n\nRead more:\n\nGovernment-politics\n\nHarris steps into the limelight. And the coconut trees and memes have followed\n\nMEG KINNARD and CURTIS YEE Associated Press\n\nGovernment-politics\n\nHarris has support of enough Democratic delegates to become party's presidential nominee: AP survey\n\nZEKE MILLER and SEUNG MIN KIM Associated Press\n\nGovernment-politics\n\nHarris gets a chance to press reset on the 2024 race against Trump\n\nCHRIS MEGERIAN Associated Press\n\nGovernment-politics\n\nBiden drops out of race, endorses VP Harris after disastrous debate inflamed age concerns\n\nCOLLEEN LONG, ZEKE MILLER and DARLENE SUPERVILLE Associated Press\n\nGovernment-politics\n\nTrump's campaign quickly pivots to Harris after Biden announces decision to leave the race\n\nJILL COLVIN and MICHELLE L. {"uri": "2024-07-432678014", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "00:43:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T00:43:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T00:15:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.thescottishsun.co.uk/news/13217488/joe-biden-presidential-address-oval-office/", "title": "Biden vows to 'pass the torch' in first address after suspending campaign", "body": "PRESIDENT Joe Biden addressed the nation from the Oval Office for the first time announcing his decision to drop out of the race for the White House.\n\nBiden, 81, explained his rationale for dropping out after weeks of believing that he was the only candidate to beat former President Donald Trump.\n\n\"The defense of democracy is more important than any title,\" Biden said.\n\n\"I draw strength, and find joy, in working for the American people. But this sacred task of perfecting our Union is not about me. It's about you. Your families. Your futures. It's about 'We the People.'\"\n\nHe spoke for barely 15 minutes, his voice still hoarse after testing positive for Covid-19 last week.\n\nBiden listed his goals for the rest of his presidency including lowering prices, growing the economy, and defending the rights of Americans.\n\n\"I have decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation,\" he said.\n\n\"That is the best way to unite our nation.\"\n\nHe added that he will continue to speak out against gun violence and work on his Cancer Moonshot initiative while calling for reforms to the Supreme Court.\n\n\"I'll keep defending our personal freedoms and our civil rights from the right to vote to the right to choose,\" said Biden.\n\n\"I'll keep calling out hate and extremism and make it clear there is no place, no place it's in America for political violence or any violence.\"\n\nHe reflected on his presidency and spoke briefly on his bid for a second term but decided that it was in the best interest of the country to end his campaign.\n\n\"I revere this office but I love my country more,\" he said.\n\n\"It's been the honor of my life to serve as your president but the defense of democracy, which has a stake, I think is more important than a title.\"\n\nHarris secured enough delegate endorsements to become the presumptive presidential nominee for the Democratic party on July 22, just a day after Biden withdrew his bid.\n\n\"In just a few months, the American people choose the course of America's future,\" Biden said in his address.\n\n\"I made my choice. This was the first speech Biden has made since he announced his withdrawal from the race on Sunday.\n\nMost notably, the 81-year-old president, who was recovering from Covid-19 this week, highlighted the importance of passing the torch to a new generation, referring to his endorsement for Kamala Harris as the new contender for November's elections.\n\nIn a roughly 10-minute speech, Biden pointed to the threat that he says Donald Trump poses to democracy in the US.\n\n\"When Ben Franklin was asked,\" Biden said, \"as he emerged from the convention going on, whether the founders have given America a monarchy or a Republic, Franklin's response was: a republic, if you can keep it.\"\n\n\"Whether we keep our republic is now in your hands,\" Biden said.\n\nHere are the key takeaways:\n\nBiden started his speech on Wednesday by noting that he was sitting at the Resolute Desk in the Oval Office. He then referenced former presidents who have held the office.\n\n\"In this sacred space, I'm surrounded by portraits of extraordinary American presidents,\" he said in the beginning of his speech. \"Thomas Jefferson wrote the immortal words that guide this nation. George Washington showed us presidents are not kings.\"\n\nBiden questioned, notably, if the character of a president still matters, and without naming Donald Trump, asked voters to question whether the Republican nominee would uphold the sanctity of the presidency or US democracy.\n\nIn the much-awaited address, Biden explained his decision to withdraw his re-election campaign. \"This sacred task of perfecting our union is not about me, it's about you,\" Biden said, and then turned the focus to his vice-president, who is now the most likely Democratic nominee.\n\nBiden commended Harris for her work, calling her an \"experienced\", \"tough\" and \"capable\" candidate. \"I have decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation. That is the best way to unite our nation,\" he said. Biden had endorsed Harris soon after his announcement on Sunday.\n\nBiden said that over the next six months, he will focus on \"lowering costs\", growing the economy, and fighting against gun violence and the climate crisis. He also said that he will call for a supreme court reform, calling it \"critical to our democracy\".\n\n\"I'll keep fighting for my cancer moonshot,\" he said, referring to his efforts to find a cure for cancer that began years before his presidency.\n\nHe ended on a personal message to his voters. \"I hope you have some idea of how grateful I am,\" Biden said. \"History is in your hands.\"", {"uri": "2024-07-432664755", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "00:15:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T00:15:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T00:13:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://missoulian.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/biden-addressing-nation-on-his-decision-to-drop-his-2024-democratic-reelection-bid/article_d9da59dd-bd0a-5052-be98-a7d7c6b73f87.html", "title": "Biden addressing nation on his decision to drop his 2024 Democratic reelection bid", "body": "ZEKE MILLER, SEUNG MIN KIM and WILL WEISSERT Associated Press\n\nWASHINGTON -- Insisting that \"the defense of democracy is more important than any title,\" President Joe Biden on Wednesday explained in an Oval Office address his decision to drop his bid for reelection and to throw his support behind Vice President Kamala Harris.\n\nThe address offered the public their first chance to hear directly from Biden his rationale for dropping out of the 2024 after weeks of insisting he believed himself to be the best candidate to take on former President Donald Trump, whom he has called an existential threat to the nation's democracy. It also gave Biden a chance to try to shape how history views his one and only term in office.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nMan kills grizzly, hospitalized after encounter in Flathead National Forest UPDATED: Evacuations ordered for new Butler Creek wildfire; Red Flag Warning The Stables: New restaurant in downtown Missoula next to Cranky Sam Fire, reported explosions prompt Missoula officials to close Lions Park Forest Service aware of interested buyer for Holland Lake Lodge Missoula police urge caution after reported downtown sexual assaults Missoula looks to build sidewalks in Westside neighborhood to avoid gentrification USPS to suspend air service delivery in Montana in favor of ground transportation Fire restrictions for county, forests, reservation, as fires start and Miller Peak grows Miller Peak fire near Missoula barely grows ahead of Friday public meeting Fire danger extreme, restrictions ordered as Miller Peak blaze grows Man shot and killed by Mineral County officers was from Missoula NorthWestern monitoring Thursday's weather for possible rare power shutoff 1 dead after officer-involved shooting in Mineral County 3 Montana inmates die in Cascade County Detention Center in 2 weeks\n\n\"The defense of democracy is more important than any title,\" Biden said. \"I draw strength, and find joy, in working FOR the American people. But this sacred task of perfecting our Union is not about me. It's about you. Your families. Your futures. It's about 'We the People.'\"\n\nBiden's candidacy faced a crisis of confidence from Democrats after his abysmal debate against Trump nearly a month ago, where he spoke haltingly, appeared ashen and failed to rebut his predecessor's attacks. It sparked a mutiny within his party over not just whether he was capable of beating Trump in November, but also whether at 81, he was still fit for the high-pressure job.\n\nBiden tried to outlast the skepticism and quell the concerns with interviews and tepid rallies, but the pressure to step aside only mounted from the party's political elites and from ordinary voters.\n\nOn Sunday afternoon, while isolating at his Rehoboth Beach, Delaware, home with COVID-19, Biden finally bowed in a letter posted to his account on X announcing his decision to leave the race, followed up later by an endorsement of Harris.\n\n\"I have decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation,\" Biden said. \"That is the best way to unite our nation.\"\n\nBiden's address was being carried by the major television news networks. He pledge to remain focused on being president until his term expires at noon on Jan. 20, 2025.\n\nThe president was hoping to use the address to outline the stakes in the election, which both Biden and Harris have framed as a choice between freedom and chaos, but was expected to try to steer clear of overt campaigning from his official office or even mentioning Trump by name.\n\n\"The great thing about America is here, kings and dictators do not rule,\" Biden said. \"The people do. History is in your hands. The power is in your hands. The idea of America -- lies in your hands.\"\n\nBiden was also looking to make the case for his legacy of sweeping domestic legislation and the renewal of alliances abroad. The way history will remember his time in office and his historic decision to step aside is intertwined with Harris' electoral result in November, particularly as the vice president runs tightly on the achievements of the Biden administration.\n\nHis advisers say he intends to hold campaign events and fundraisers benefiting Harris, albeit at a far slower pace than if he had remained on the ballot himself.\n\nHarris advisers will ultimately have to decide how to deploy the president, whose popularity sagged as voters in both parties questioned his fitness for office.\n\nBiden, aides say, knows that if Harris loses, he'll be criticized for staying in the race too long and not giving her or another Democrat time to effectively mount a campaign against Trump. If she wins, she'll ensure his policy victories are secured and expanded, and he'll be remembered for a Washingtonian decision to step aside for the next generation of leadership.\n\nPress secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said Wednesday that any question of Biden resigning his office -- which would allow Harris to run as an incumbent -- was \"ridiculous.\"\n\nJean-Pierre said Biden has \"no regrets\" about his decision to stay in the race as long as he did, or his decision to quit it over the weekend. She said Biden's decision had nothing to do with his health.\n\nRead more:\n\nGovernment-politics\n\nHarris steps into the limelight. And the coconut trees and memes have followed\n\nMEG KINNARD and CURTIS YEE Associated Press\n\nGovernment-politics\n\nHarris has support of enough Democratic delegates to become party's presidential nominee: AP survey\n\nZEKE MILLER and SEUNG MIN KIM Associated Press\n\nGovernment-politics\n\nHarris gets a chance to press reset on the 2024 race against Trump\n\nCHRIS MEGERIAN Associated Press\n\nGovernment-politics\n\nBiden drops out of race, endorses VP Harris after disastrous debate inflamed age concerns\n\nCOLLEEN LONG, ZEKE MILLER and DARLENE SUPERVILLE Associated Press\n\nGovernment-politics\n\nTrump's campaign quickly pivots to Harris after Biden announces decision to leave the race\n\nJILL COLVIN and MICHELLE L. But this sacred task of perfecting our Union is not about me. It's about you. Your families. Your futures. It's about 'We the People',\" Biden said.\n\nHe encouraged voters to take the power of the future in their hands and vote for a democratic future - something he has continuously warned Trump will not respect.\n\nBoth Biden and Harris have raised concerns that Trump will implement drastic changes to the executive branch, consolidating power and installing loyalists over civil servants - an aspect of Project 2025.\n\n\"The defense of democracy is more important than any title,\" Biden said during his primetime address.\n\nBiden has already endorsed Harris as the Democratic presidential nominee. Since announcing his withdrawal, Democratic leaders such as Chuck Schumer, Hakeem Jeffries, Nancy Pelosi, Elizabeth Warren, Hillary Clinton and more have also endorsed Harris.\n\nWithin 24 hours, Harris surpassed the 1,976 delegates needed for the nomination in a first round of voting among Democratic delegates.\n\nBiden also addressed his plans for the next six months of his presidency, {"uri": "8242156792", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "01:02:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T01:02:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T01:01:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://www.india.com/news/world/i-revere-this-office-but-love-my-country-more-joe-biden-explains-decision-to-quit-us-presidential-race-7111896/", "title": "I Revere This Office, But Love My Country More: Joe Biden Explains Decision To Quit Us Presidential Race", "body": "Washington: In a solemn address marking the end of his political career, US President Biden on Thursday said the nation's democracy lies in the hands of voters. During his Oval Office address, Biden said he ended 2024 bid because 'I revere this office, but I love my country more.'\n\n\"I revere this office, but I love my country more. It's been the honour of my life to serve as your president. But in the defense of democracy, which is at stake, it's more important than any title. I draw strength and I find joy in working,\" he said.\n\nPresident Joe Biden started his Oval Office address by explaining his decision to 'pass the torch' and end 2024 candidacy.\n\nEarlier this week, Biden called on his supporters to back Vice President Kamala Harris in his first remarks after announcing his decision to not seek re-election. He called his decision to drop out of the presidential race \"the \"right thing to do,\" CNN reported.\n\nBiden made the remarks during a phone call he made into his former campaign's headquarters to thank the staff and praise Kamala Harris, who visited the Wilmington office on Monday (local time) to visit with staff.\n\nDuring the phone call, Biden directly addressed Harris and the team, saying, \"embrace her, she's the best.\"\n\nOn his announcement to drop out of the presidential race, he called it \"suprising news\" and emphasised that it's his belief it was the \"right thing to do,\" CNN reported.\n\n\"I know it's hard because you poured your heart and soul into me,\" Biden told the campaign staffers and added, \"You're an amazing team.\"\n\nThe US President expressed gratitude to the staffers for uprooting their lives for him and his now ended campaign. He said that they have built the \"best\" campaign organisation in history. He said, \"I've been honoured and humbled.\"\n\nBiden said, \"I'm going to be on the road and I'm not going anywhere.\" He stated, \"I won't be on the ticket but I am still going to be fully, fully engaged. I've got six months left in my presidency. I'm determined to get as much done as I possibly can both foreign policy and domestic policy,\" according to CNN report.\n\nEarlier on Sunday, Biden announced his decision to not seek re-election in the \"best interest\" of the Democratic Party and the country. He has endorsed US Vice President Kamala Harris as the presidential nominee for the Democratic Party and called on Democrats to \"come together and beat\" Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump.\n\nIn a letter posted on X, Biden stated, \"And while it has been my intention to seek reelection, I believe it is in the best interest of my party and the country for me to stand down and to focus solely on fulfilling my duties as President for the remainder of my term. I will speak to the nation later this week in more detail about my decision.\"\n\nHe also expressed gratitude to US Vice President Kamala Harris for being an \"extraordinary partner\" for him. {"uri": "2024-07-432661878", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "00:10:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T00:10:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T00:09:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://journalstar.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/biden-addressing-nation-on-his-decision-to-drop-his-2024-democratic-reelection-bid/article_f0adad67-162c-5791-bd4d-209a230504d8.html", "title": "Biden addressing nation on his decision to drop his 2024 Democratic reelection bid", "body": "ZEKE MILLER, SEUNG MIN KIM and WILL WEISSERT Associated Press\n\nWASHINGTON -- Insisting that \"the defense of democracy is more important than any title,\" President Joe Biden on Wednesday explained in an Oval Office address his decision to drop his bid for reelection and to throw his support behind Vice President Kamala Harris.\n\nThe address offered the public their first chance to hear directly from Biden his rationale for dropping out of the 2024 after weeks of insisting he believed himself to be the best candidate to take on former President Donald Trump, whom he has called an existential threat to the nation's democracy. It also gave Biden a chance to try to shape how history views his one and only term in office.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nLincoln restaurant calls it quits after 15 years 'Ready to learn from this': John Cook updates Harper Murray's status for 2024 season 'Exhausting, heartbreaking, devastating': Racism at Wayne school pushes family out of Nebraska Former Nebraska Sen. Ben Sasse to resign as University of Florida president Fleet Farm backed out of northwest Lincoln development This Nebraska couple runs a senior dog sanctuary just outside of Lincoln Recruiting: New Nebraska football staffer aims for pair of 2026 four-star targets Guatemalan chicken restaurant puts Lincoln, Gretna and Crete on its expansion map Teen accused of causing train derailment near Bennet before recording it Nebraska volleyball's Harper Murray sentenced to probation for DUI Judge orders Nebraska Department of Transportation to turn over records of intersection study Is it legal to turn on red traffic arrows in Lincoln? What new Nebraska law says Pedestrian struck by car in west Lincoln dies at hospital, police say Lincoln Animal Control reports first-ever rabies case in a fox 'Death Row:' Nebraska defensive line room embracing new nickname\n\n\"The defense of democracy is more important than any title,\" Biden said. \"I draw strength, and find joy, in working FOR the American people. But this sacred task of perfecting our Union is not about me. It's about you. Your families. Your futures. It's about 'We the People.'\"\n\nBiden's candidacy faced a crisis of confidence from Democrats after his abysmal debate against Trump nearly a month ago, where he spoke haltingly, appeared ashen and failed to rebut his predecessor's attacks. It sparked a mutiny within his party over not just whether he was capable of beating Trump in November, but also whether at 81, he was still fit for the high-pressure job.\n\nBiden tried to outlast the skepticism and quell the concerns with interviews and tepid rallies, but the pressure to step aside only mounted from the party's political elites and from ordinary voters.\n\nOn Sunday afternoon, while isolating at his Rehoboth Beach, Delaware, home with COVID-19, Biden finally bowed in a letter posted to his account on X announcing his decision to leave the race, followed up later by an endorsement of Harris.\n\n\"I have decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation,\" Biden said. \"That is the best way to unite our nation.\"\n\nBiden's address was being carried by the major television news networks. He pledge to remain focused on being president until his term expires at noon on Jan. 20, 2025.\n\nThe president was hoping to use the address to outline the stakes in the election, which both Biden and Harris have framed as a choice between freedom and chaos, but was expected to try to steer clear of overt campaigning from his official office or even mentioning Trump by name.\n\n\"The great thing about America is here, kings and dictators do not rule,\" Biden said. \"The people do. History is in your hands. The power is in your hands. The idea of America -- lies in your hands.\"\n\nBiden was also looking to make the case for his legacy of sweeping domestic legislation and the renewal of alliances abroad. The way history will remember his time in office and his historic decision to step aside is intertwined with Harris' electoral result in November, particularly as the vice president runs tightly on the achievements of the Biden administration.\n\nHis advisers say he intends to hold campaign events and fundraisers benefiting Harris, albeit at a far slower pace than if he had remained on the ballot himself.\n\nHarris advisers will ultimately have to decide how to deploy the president, whose popularity sagged as voters in both parties questioned his fitness for office.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nBiden, aides say, knows that if Harris loses, he'll be criticized for staying in the race too long and not giving her or another Democrat time to effectively mount a campaign against Trump. If she wins, she'll ensure his policy victories are secured and expanded, and he'll be remembered for a Washingtonian decision to step aside for the next generation of leadership.\n\nPress secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said Wednesday that any question of Biden resigning his office -- which would allow Harris to run as an incumbent -- was \"ridiculous.\"\n\nJean-Pierre said Biden has \"no regrets\" about his decision to stay in the race as long as he did, or his decision to quit it over the weekend. She said Biden's decision had nothing to do with his health.\n\nRead more:\n\nGovernment-politics\n\nHarris steps into the limelight. {"uri": "8242153520", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "00:59:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T00:59:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T00:57:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://dnyuz.com/2024/07/24/biden-says-it-is-time-to-step-aside-for-a-fresh-younger-voice/", "title": "Biden Says It Is Time to Step Aside for a Fresh, Younger Voice", "body": "President Biden told the American public in an Oval Office address on Wednesday that he had abandoned his re-election campaign because there is \"a time and a place for new voices, fresh voices -- yes, younger voices.\"\n\nHis words, lasting 11 minutes in all, were the first extensive ones from Mr. Biden since his decision to step aside, and expanded on his initial announcement, delivered in a post on social media on Sunday, that he was dropping out of the race. His tone was wistful and his speech was an early farewell.\n\n\"It's been the privilege of my life to serve this nation for over 50 years,'' he said\n\nSitting behind the Resolute Desk and surrounded by photos of his family, Mr. Biden ticked through the accomplishments of his term, ranging from the choice of the first Black woman to be a Supreme Court justice to pulling the country out of a paralyzing pandemic. He expressed gratitude to the American people for allowing a \"kid with a stutter\" from modest beginnings in Scranton, Pa., to reach the pinnacle of American politics.\n\nJust beyond the camera, dozens of aides and several members of his family, including Jill Biden, the first lady, watched as Mr. Biden said he would walk away from the office they had worked to help him reach for decades.\n\n\"I revere this office,\" he said, \"but I love my country more.\"\n\nUltimately, Mr. Biden said, he concluded that \"the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation.\" The president praised Vice President Kamala Harris -- \"she's experienced, she's tough, she's capable\" -- but warned, as he has for years, that Americans faced a choice between preserving democracy and allowing it to backslide.\n\n\"History is in your hands,\" Mr. Biden said. \"The power is in your hands. The idea of America lies in your hands. We just have to keep faith, keep the faith, and remember who we are.\"\n\nMr. Biden, who spent the first part of the week recovering from Covid at his beach house in Delaware, spoke with a rasp and slight slur in his voice, speaking sometimes haltingly as he promised that he would defend his legacy and do what he could to help Ms. Harris win the election against former President Donald J. Trump. He stared straight ahead into the camera and seldom blinked.\n\n\"Over the next six months I will be focused on doing my job as president,\" Mr. Biden said. \"That means I will continue to lower costs for hard-working families, grow our economy. I will keep defending our personal freedoms and civil rights, from the right to vote to the right to choose.\"\n\nThis speech was the fourth Oval Office address of Mr. Biden's presidency and the second just this month. Ten days ago, Mr. Biden urged Americans to lower the political temperature after a gunman opened fire at a Trump rally in Pennsylvania, wounding the former president and killing one of his supporters.\n\nOther than saying it was time to pass the torch to someone young, Mr. Biden offered no other reason for his decision to step down. He did not mention the three-week pressure campaign from his own party to get him out of the race after his faltering and at times incoherent debate performance with Mr. Trump in June 27.\n\nMr. Biden and his advisers, aides said, still believed that he had a path to victory, but that he had been unable to flip the focus from his debate showing back onto the policies espoused by Mr. Trump. His decision to turn the race over to Ms. Harris ultimately overrode some of his private concerns about her ability to be able to win in a general election.\n\nThe drafting of his Wednesday address began on Sunday after Mr. Biden made the decision to drop out. Mike Donilon, one of the president's senior aides, helped Mr. Biden fashion the remarks. Jon Meacham, the presidential historian, contributed to the speech, as well as Vinay Reddy, a White House speechwriter.\n\nMr. Biden now has six months to bolster a legacy that he is proud of but that gained little traction among Democratic voters, who had long registered their concerns in polls about his age and ability to do the job. Over the last three-and-a-half years, Mr. Biden worked to repair frayed relations with American allies in the West, passed a raft of landmark legislation and helped lead the country out of a crippling pandemic.\n\nBut Mr. Biden, a former senator who spent 36 years priding himself in his ability to find compromise on legislation, now has little hope to deliver on unfulfilled promises he has made on issues ranging from women's rights to voting protections.\n\nIn recent days, Ms. Harris has blazed onto the campaign trail, surfing a wave of hope and enthusiasm from Democratic voters that was absent during much of Mr. Biden's presidency. Though Mr. Biden has promised to campaign vigorously for the vice president, his schedule for next week remains relatively clear, beyond a trip to Austin on Monday to speak at the presidential library of President Lyndon B. Johnson -- the last Democratic president who decided not to seek re-election.\n\nMr. Biden is also facing heightened pressure from Republicans -- including Mr. Trump's new running mate, Senator JD Vance of Ohio -- who argue that he must resign if he does not think he would be able to serve a second term.\n\nIn a press briefing on Wednesday, Karine Jean-Pierre, the White House press secretary, said that Mr. Biden would not resign and, in fact, still believes that he would be able to fulfill his duties four years into a second term.\n\nHe did not say any of that in the Oval Office. Instead, he said repeatedly that he had put the good of the country before his political aspirations.\n\n\"Nothing can come in the way of saving our democracy,\" Mr. Biden said. \"That includes personal ambition.\"", "source": {"uri": "dnyuz.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "DNyuz"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Biden", "type": "person", "score": 5, {"uri": "8242191447", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "01:44:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T01:44:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T01:43:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.masslive.com/politics/2024/07/in-bidens-speech-a-challenge-are-americans-up-to-it-john-l-micek.html", "title": "In Biden's speech, a challenge. Are Americans up to it? | John L. Micek", "body": "In just 11 minutes on Wednesday night, President Joe Biden framed his exit from the 2024 presidential campaign as a fight for the future -- and for a republic, if Americans can keep it.\n\n\"The defense of democracy is more important than any title,\" Biden said. \"I draw strength and find joy in working for the American people. But this sacred task of perfecting our union is not about me. It's about you. Your families. Your futures. It's about 'We the People.'\"\n\nIt was Biden's first public appearance since dropping out of the race on Sunday. And one freighted with meaning.\n\nSpeaking from the Oval Office, the 81-year-old chief executive nodded to his predecessors who had been called upon to defend the union: George Washington, Abraham Lincoln and Franklin D. Roosevelt.\n\n\"I revere this office, but I love my country more,\" Biden said.\n\nHe explicitly passed the torch only days after he endorsed his vice president, Kamala Harris, to replace him and as Democrats surged to her banner.\n\n\"There is a time and a place for long years of experience in public life. There's also a time and a place for new voices,\" Biden said. \"Fresh voices? Yes. Younger voices. And that time and place is now.\"\n\nHarris, 59, of California, is \"experienced,\" \"tough\" and \"capable,\" Biden said.\n\nStill, as he looked forward, Biden looked back, recounting his accomplishments in office, marveling that a \"kid with a stutter\" who came from humble beginnings in northeastern Pennsylvania and Delaware could ascend to the highest elected office in the country.\n\nAll of it was a vintage Joe Biden performance.\n\nBut it took a while to get here -- perhaps too long for some Democrats, and for those thousands of Americans who were dreading his rematch with former President Donald Trump.\n\nAnd it was not without its moments of pain and awkwardness.\n\nDemocrats exerted increasing pressure on Biden to exit the race after his faltering debate performance against Trump in Atlanta last month. Biden, in return, dug in, insisting he would not leave.\n\nThe calls grew louder over the ensuing weeks. They temporarily went quiet in the hours after Trump, now the Republicans' presidential nominee, survived an attempted assassination during a rally in Western Pennsylvania two weeks ago.\n\nBut on Sunday, gradually and then suddenly, as they say, Biden was out of the race.\n\nYou could almost hear the collective exhale from Democrats as they effectively delivered Harris the nomination, and filled her campaign coffers with more than $100 million in contributions.\n\nThere have been some, over the last few days, who have compared Biden's decision to exit the race to Washington's announcement in 1796 that he would not seek a third term, positioning it as an act of heroic self-sacrifice.\n\nIt's a nice sentiment that falls a little short of the mark.\n\nWashington, forever a reluctant leader, left office by choice. Biden had been running for the White House his entire life.\n\nIn truth, the president's departure feels a bit more like a manager finally convincing a fading veteran pitcher to leave the mound after he's stayed in the game an inning or two too long.\n\nStill, listening to Biden on Wednesday night, it was clear that the standard set by the nation's first president, who warned against factionalism at home, was on his mind, as he took a thinly veiled swipe at Trump.\n\n\"The great thing about America is here, kings and dictators do not rule,\" Biden said, without mentioning the competition by name. \"The people do. History is in your hands. The power is in your hands. The idea of America lies in your hands.\"\n\nThough some Republicans have called on him to resign and leave office early, Biden has shown no such inclination. And on Wednesday, he sketched his priorities for his last six months in office.\n\nHe ticked off a list that included continuing his efforts to lower drug prices, protect abortion rights, fight gun violence and push for a \"cancer moonshot.\" He also called for Supreme Court reform.\n\nBiden ended his brief remarks the way he began them -- indeed, much the way he has spent his presidency -- calling on Americans to heed their better angels and to work together.\n\n\"Whether we keep our republic is now in your hands,\" Biden said. \"Let's act together to preserve our democracy.\"", "source": {"uri": "masslive.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "MassLive"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Biden", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Joe Biden"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Democratic Party (United States)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kamala_Harris", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Kamala Harris"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump_2016_presidential_campaign", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump 2016 presidential campaign"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Washington", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "George Washington"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oval_Office", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Oval Office"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Abraham Lincoln"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Franklin D. {"uri": "2024-07-432682708", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "00:54:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T00:54:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T00:50:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://thehill.com/homenews/administration/4791617-joe-biden-democrats-unite-kamala-harris/", "title": "Biden in Oval Office speech says he dropped out to unite Democrats", "body": "President Biden, in an address from the Oval Office, said he decided to end his reelection bid when it became clear that was how he could unite Democrats after weeks of intra-party chaos and mounting pressure to step aside.\n\nThe president had firmly declared there was nothing short of a higher power that could get him to change his mind about running again. But he eventually caved, particularly after hearing from congressional leadership, who implored him to drop out or risk Democrats also losing both chambers of Congress in November.\n\n\"In recent weeks it has become clear to me that I need to unite my party in this critical endeavor,\" he said.\n\n\"Nothing, nothing can come in the way of saving our democracy. That includes personal ambition. So, I decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation. It's the best way to unite our nation,\" the president added.\n\n\"The cause of the nation is larger than any one of us,\" he said.\n\nHe was joined in the Oval Office by first lady Jill Biden, his children, their spouses and children and some of his longtime political advisers along with White House staff.\n\nBiden has thrown his support behind Vice President Harris who Democrats say has revitalized their energy and has potential to boost their chances at beating former President Trump. Harris watched Biden's speech from Houston, Texas, according to reporters traveling with her.\n\nIn a letter posted to social media on Sunday, Biden announced he would drop his bid. It came after reports suggested that some of the highest-profile Democrats, including former President Obama and former Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif) had tried to convince him his chances of winning against Trump were disappearing.\n\n\"There is a time and a place for long years of experience in public life,\" Biden said in his address. \"There's also a time and a place for new voices, fresh voices. Yes, younger voices. And that time is now.\"\n\nThe calls for him to step aside followed a poor debate performance in late June, during which Biden, 81, struggled to finish his thoughts and spoke in a low, raspy voice. He spent three weeks insisting he was staying in the race and campaigning up until he dropped out.\n\nThe president in his address made a plea for preserving democracy, which was an ongoing theme of his administration, after he beat Trump in 2020.\n\n\"In this moment, we can see those we disagree with not as enemies but as... friends, fellow Americans. Can we do that? Does character in public life still matter?\" he said.\n\nHe referred to words he has hanging in his office from Benjamin Franklin that describe that the founders gave America \"a Republic, if you can keep it.\"\n\n\"Whether we keep our Republic is now in your hands,\" he said.\n\n\"History is in your hands, the powers' in your hands. The idea of America lies in your hands,\" Biden added.\n\nHe made clear he would not be stepping down from the office of the presidency and will serve out his term for the next six months.\n\nThe president outlined his plans until he leaves office in January, which includes ending the Israel-Hamas war in Gaza, Supreme Court reform, and continuing to work for reproductive rights and his Cancer Moonshot initiative, among other priorities.\n\nHe also touted Harris, calling her \"experienced,\" \"tough,\" and \"capable.\" The president never mentioned Trump by name.\n\nAdditionally, he expressed gratitude for the 50 years he has served in government.\n\n\"No one else on Earth can a kid with a shutter from modest beginnings in Scranton, Pennsylvania and Claymont, Delaware, one day sit behind the Resolute Desk in the Oval Office,\" Biden said. \"I've given my heart and my soul to the nation, like so many others... Those who champion that cause cherish it so much. We must unite to protect it. In recent weeks, it's become clear to me that I need to unite my party in this critical endeavor. I believe my record as president, my leadership in the world, my vision for America's future -- all merited a second term,\" Biden said, with his wife, Jill, and children, Hunter and Ashley Biden, looking on. \"Nothing can come in the way of saving our democracy. That includes personal ambition.\"\n\n\"I have decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation. That is the best way to unite our nation,\" the president explained in his second address from behind the Resolute Desk this month, and fourth overall.\n\nJill and Hunter were two figures who reportedly had an intimate involvement in the president's decision-making process over the turbulent past few weeks. The latter was joined by his wife, Melissa Biden, while the president's daughter, Ashley, was also present alongside husband Howard Krein. The president's granddaughter, Finnegan, was seen wiping away a tear after Biden had concluded his remarks and stood up to embrace his family.\n\n\"Over the next six months I will be focused on doing my job as President,\" Biden added. That means I will continue to lower costs for hard-working families and grow our economy. I will keep defending our personal freedoms and our civil rights -- from the right to vote, to the right to choose,\" he added.\n\nHarris, Biden went on to say, was fully equipped to pick up where he left off.\n\n\"She is experienced. She is tough. She is capable. She has been an incredible partner for me and a leader for our country,\" he told viewers.\n\nBiden, who portrayed Trump as a threat to democratic institutions during his campaign, continued to emphasize that point, without naming him.\n\n\"The defense of democracy is more important than any title. I draw strength, and find joy, in working for the American people. But this sacred task of perfecting our Union is not about me. It's about you. Your families. Your futures. {"uri": "8242178936", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "01:30:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T01:30:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T01:29:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.newsdrum.in/international/i-have-decided-the-best-way-forward-is-to-pass-the-torch-to-a-new-generation-says-biden-6694939", "title": "I have decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation, says Biden", "body": "Washington, Jul 25 (PTI) Telling his fellow countrymen that America is at an inflection point, US President Joe Biden on Wednesday said he has decided that the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation.\n\n\"I've decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation. That's the best way to unite our nation. I there is a time and a place for long years of experience in public life, but there's also a time and a place for new voices, fresh voices, yes, younger voices, and that time and place is now,\" Biden said in his Oval Office address to the nation.\n\nThe much anticipated address to the nation came three days after he announced that he was withdrawing from the presidential race and endorsing his deputy Kamala Harris as the nominee for the Democratic Party.\n\nHarris, who is of Indian and African origin, has now emerged as the presumptive presidential nominee.\n\n\"I've made it clear that I believe America is at an inflection point, one of those rare moments in history when the decisions we make now will determine our fate of our nation and the world for decades to come,\" he said from the Oval Office.\n\nHe was surrounded by the First Lady, Dr Jill Biden, son Hunter Biden and several members of his family. Toward the end of remarks, Ashley Biden reached for the hand of her mother, Jill Biden, who was seated next to her.\n\nAfter the president concluded his remarks, Jill Biden walked to the Resolute Desk and stood next to her husband. \"This has been the honor of a lifetime,\" Biden said, followed by other words of gratitude.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris watched Biden's Address to the Nation from Houston, where she is spending the night after visiting the city's Emergency Operations Center to receive a briefing on the ongoing recovery efforts following Hurricane Beryl.\n\nBiden in his remarks said that America is going to have to choose between moving forward or backward, between hope and hate, between unity and division.\n\n\"We have to decide, do we still believe in honesty, decency, respect, freedom, justice and democracy. In this moment, we can see those we disagree with not as enemies, but as fellow Americans,\" he said.\n\nOver the next six months, Biden said, he will be focused on doing his job as the president.\n\n\"That means I'll continue to lower costs for hard working families, grow our economy, and I'll keep defending our personal freedoms and our civil rights from the right to vote to the right to choose. I'll keep calling out hate and extremism, make it clear there is no place, no place in America for political violence or any violence ever, period. I'm going to keep speaking out to protect our kids from gun violence, our planet from climate crisis, is the existential threat,\" he said.\n\nBiden said he is the first president in this century to report to the American people that the United States is not at war anywhere in the world.\n\n\"We'll keep rallying a coalition of proud nations to stop Putin from taking over Ukraine and doing more damage. We'll keep NATO stronger, and I'll make it more powerful and more united than at any time in all of our history,\" he said.\n\n\"I'll keep doing the same for allies in the Pacific. You know, when I came to office, the conventional wisdom was that China would inevitably surpass the United States. That's not the case anymore. I'm going to keep working to end the war in Gaza, bring home all the hostages and bring peace and security to the Middle East and end this war,\" said the president.\n\nBiden said in just a few months, the American people will choose the course of America's future.\n\n\"I made my choice. I made my views known. I would like to thank our great Vice President Kamala Harris. She's experienced, she's tough, she's capable. She's been an incredible partner to me and a leader for our country. Now the choice is up to you, the American people,\" he said. {"uri": "8242160976", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "01:08:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T01:08:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T01:07:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://rollcall.com/?p=757692", "title": "'Presidents are not kings': Biden issues warning as he explains campaign decision - Roll Call", "body": "'Younger voices' needed for goal of 'saving our democracy,' president says\n\nPresident Joe Biden on Wednesday said he ended his bid for a second term to unify the Democratic Party and warned voters to avert a slide toward dictatorship, as the sun began to set on a political career that spanned five decades.\n\n\"I have decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation. That is the best way to unite our nation,\" Biden said from behind the storied Resolute Desk. \"The defense of democracy ... I think it's more important than any title.\n\n\"It's about 'We the people.' We can never forget that and I never have,\" the 81-year-old president added, his voice still raspy after a bout with COVID-19. \"I revere this office, but I love my country more.\"\n\nWithout naming former President Donald Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, Biden appeared to issue a warning about him to American voters, who will head to the ballot box in just over four months.\n\n\"Nothing can come in the way of saving our democracy. That includes personal ambition,\" he said. \"The great thing about America is ... kings and dictators do not rule. The people do. History is in your hands. The power is in your hands. ... George Washington showed us that presidents are not kings.\n\n\"Whether we keep the republic is now in your hands,\" Biden said, pointing into the television camera. \"I've given my heart and my soul for our country,\" he added, calling himself \"grateful.\"\n\nWhile he did not directly address concerns about his age, Biden did say it was time to pass the torch to \"fresh voices, and yes, younger voices.\"\n\nNational and swing-state polls had shown Biden losing ground to Trump in recent weeks, and he had said in one interview that \"data\" and his higher power were the only two things that could force him from the race. But big-money donors said they were withholding contributions to his campaign and late last week threatened to cut off Democratic congressional candidates.\n\nAmong the issues Biden vowed to work on during his last months in office was \"Supreme Court reform,\" but he did not offer any specific policy proposals.\n\nBiden ran in 2020 on unifying the country amid the COVID-19 pandemic and after four years of Trump's brash style and hard-line policies, which offended Democrats. But a variety of forces hindered that lofty goal as Republicans simultaneously cast him as the leader of a corrupt family and crooked political operation -- and too senile and frail for his office.\n\nHis presidency also was hamstrung by needing to bring the pandemic to an end; skyrocketing interest rates; high prices of food, gasoline and other everyday items; then wars in Ukraine and Gaza that followed a chaotic and violent U.S. withdrawal from Afghanistan that he green-lighted. Team Biden's messaging about what Democrats still call legislative and policy accomplishments never resonated with voters -- and his low poll numbers showed it.\n\n\"I draw strength, and find joy, in working for the American people. But this sacred task of perfecting our union is not about me,\" he said. \"It's about you. Your families. Your futures.\"\n\nKarine Jean-Pierre, the White House press secretary, earlier Wednesday described a scenario that played out over 24 historic hours over last weekend, culminating in the release of a letter from Biden announcing he would end his campaign. Shortly after that, Biden endorsed his vice president, Kamala Harris, who has since secured enough delegates for next month's Democratic convention to become the party's nominee.\n\n\"He met with a small group of advisers on Saturday evening and with his family,\" Jean-Pierre told reporters. \"Sunday afternoon, he made that decision.\"\n\nRepublicans, who finished their party convention last week feeling they had momentum against a sagging rival party, reacted to Biden's decision by accusing Democrats of covering up the president's infirmity, and some called on Biden to resign immediately.\n\nJean-Pierre rejected questions suggesting White House aides withheld information from the public and press about his health and cognitive state. \"There's been no cover-up,\" she told a Fox News reporter before declining to answer his question about whether Biden feels like Democratic lawmakers \"stabbed him in the back\" by calling for his departure.\n\n\"The president is going to continue to do what he set out to do [over] the next six months ... building on the accomplishments he was able to get done,\" she said.\n\nBiden said that during his remaining time in office he will focus on working to \"continue to lower costs for hard-working families and grow our economy. I will keep defending our personal freedoms and our civil rights - from the right to vote - to the right to choose.\" He also cited unspecified efforts to lower health care costs.\n\nBiden made a \"personal, difficult decision,\" Jean-Pierre said, adding, \"The president has no regrets.\"", "source": {"uri": "rollcall.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Roll Call"}, "authors": [{"uri": "john_t_bennett@rollcall.com", "name": "John T. But this sacred task of perfecting our Union is not about me. It's about you. Your families. Your futures. It's about 'We the People,'\" he added.\n\nMarking the end of his political career, Biden said nation's democracy lies in the hands of voters.\n\nSumming up his political journey, Biden, 81, said, \"Nowhere else on Earth could a kid with a stutter from modest beginnings in Scranton, Pennsylvania and Claymont, Delaware, one day sit behind the resolute desk in the Oval Office as president of the United States. But here I am.\"\n\nHe expressed gratitude for the love and support of the American people, saying he has given his heart and soul to the country and has been blessed many times in return.\n\nIn his {"uri": "8242140555", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "00:46:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T00:46:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T00:42:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/joe-biden-delivers-historic-address-003516022.html", "title": "Joe Biden Delivers Historic Address on His Decision to Exit 2024 Election: 'Best Way Forward Is to Pass the Torch'", "body": "\"America is at an inflection point,\" Biden, 81, said in his primetime remarks. \"America is going to have to choose between moving forward or backward\"\n\nPresident Joe Biden offered his first televised comments about his decision to suspend his reelection campaign in a primetime address delivered on Wednesday, July 24.\n\nSitting at the historic Resolute Desk in the Oval Office of the White House, Biden, 81, used his remarks to affirm that he plans to remain in office until his term ends in January, saying, \"over the next six months, I will continue to focus on doing my job as president.\"\n\nThe president also elaborated on his decision to end his 2024 campaign -- which he first announced in a statement issued on Sunday, July 21.\n\n\"This sacred task of protecting our Union is not about me,\" he said. \"It's about you. Your families. Your futures.\"\n\nBiden alluded to recent concerns over his age -- which were amplified in the wake of his performance during the first 2024 presidential debate against former President Donald Trump -- and highlighted his endorsement of his vice president, Kamala Harris, who is 22 years his junior.\n\nSpeaking of Harris, 59, he said, \"I decided that the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation . . . It's the best way to unite our nation. There is a time and place for new voices, fresh voices, yes, younger voices, and that time and place is now.\"\n\nHarris, he added, is \"experienced, she's tough, she's capable . . . she's been an incredible partner to me and a leader for our country.\"\n\nHe never spoke Republican nominee and former President Donald Trump's name, but he repeatedly addressed the stakes of the November 2024 election as he sees them.\n\n\"I've made it clear that I believe America is at an inflection point . . . America is going to have to choose between moving forward or backward,\" he said. \"Between hope and hate. Between unity and division. Do we still believe in honestly, decency, respect, freedom, justice and democracy?\n\n\"Does character in public life still matter? I believe we know the answer to these questions, because I know you, the American people. And I know we are a great nation because we are good people.\n\n\"When you elected me to this office, I promised to always level with you, to tell you the truth . . . in recent weeks it's become clear to me that I need to unite my party . . . I believe my record as president, my leadership in the world, my vision for the future, all merited a second term. But nothing can come in the way of our democracy.\"\n\nLater, he said, \"We're nation of ordinary Americans doing extraordinary things . . . The great thing about America is here, kings and dictators do not rule, the people do. History is in your hands. The power is in your hands. The idea of America is in your hands. Keep the faith, and remember who we are. We're the United States of America, and there is nothing beyond our capacity if we do it together.\"\n\nSpeaking further, he said, \"America is an idea . . . the most powerful idea in the history of the world: We hold these truths to be self evident. We're all created equal . . . we've never fully lived up to this sacred idea, but we've never walked away from it either, and I do not believe the American people will walk away from it now.\"\n\n\"Now the choice is up to the American people,\" he said. \"When you make that choice, remember the words of Benjamin Franklin . . . asked whether the Founders have given Americans a monarchy or a republic, his answer was, 'a Republic, if you can keep it.' \"\n\nRelated: Joe Biden Addresses Presidential Debate Performance: 'Don't Speak as Smoothly as I Used to'\n\nIn announcing he was leaving the 2024 race on July 21, Biden said, \"It has been the greatest honor of my life to serve as your President. And while it has been my intention to seek reelection, I believe it is in the best interest of my party and the country for me to stand down and to focus solely on fulfilling my duties as President for the remainder of my term.\"\n\nNever miss a story -- sign up for PEOPLE's free daily newsletter to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer, from celebrity news to compelling human interest stories.\n\nIn a follow-up statement, Biden offered his first official endorsement of Harris, saying, \"My very first decision as the party nominee in 2020 was to pick Kamala Harris as my Vice President. And it's been the best decision I've made. Today I want to offer my full support and endorsement for Kamala to be the nominee for our party this year. Democrats -- it's time to come together and beat Trump. Let's do this.\"\n\nRelated: Biden-Harris Campaign Officially Retitled 'Harris for President' After Joe Biden Exits Presidential Race\n\nIn her own statement, Harris said she was \"honored to have the President's endorsement and my intention is to earn and win this nomination.\"\n\n\"Over the past year, I have traveled across the country, talking with Americans about the clear choice in this momentous election. And that is what I will continue to do in the days and weeks ahead,\" Harris stated. \"I will do everything in my power to unite the Democratic Party -- and unite our nation -- to defeat Donald Trump and his extreme Project 2025 agenda.\"\n\n\"We have 107 days until Election Day,\" she concluded. \"Together, we will fight. And together, we will win.\"\n\nRelated: Who Will Kamala Harris Pick as Her 2024 Running Mate? Possible VP Candidates to Fill Out New Democratic Ticket\n\nDocuments filed with the Federal Election Commission in the hours after the announcement reflected the change, and retitled the campaign to \"Harris for President.\"\n\nHarris' campaign took in more than $81 million in the 24 hours following the announcement, making it the largest 24-hour haul by any candidate in presidential history.", {"uri": "8242223303", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "02:21:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T02:21:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T02:21:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://amgreatness.com/2024/07/24/biden-says-he-dropped-out-of-race-to-pass-the-torch-to-a-new-generation-white-house-claims-it-had-nothing-to-do-with-his-health/", "title": "Biden Says He Dropped Out of Race to 'Pass the Torch to a New Generation;' White House Claims It Had 'Nothing to Do With His Health' \" American Greatness", "body": "Joe Biden gave an Oval Office address to the nation Wednesday evening to explain why he dropped out of the presidential race -- and as White House Press Secretary Karine Jean insisted earlier in the day, the reason had \"nothing to do with his health.\"\n\nRather, it was allegedly his dedication to a country that \"still believes in \"honesty, decency, respect, freedom, justice and democracy\" that convinced him it was the right thing to do. [Not Nancy Pelosi's threat that \"we can do this the easy way or the hard way\" because he was losing big in the polls].\n\nBiden delivered his speech in the Oval Office while his son Hunter Biden, Hunter's daughter Finnegan Biden, Biden's daughter Ashley Biden, Ashley's husband Howard Krein, and Jill Biden sat nearby and listened solemnly.\n\n\"This sacred task of protecting our union is not about me, it's about you, your families, your futures. It's about 'we the people,'\" Biden intoned. \"I've made it clear that I believe America as at an inflection point, one of those rare moments in history when the decisions we make now will determine the fate of our nation and the world to decades to come,\" he said.\n\nIn a throwback to his 2020 campaign rhetoric, Biden continued: \"America's going to have to choose between moving forward or backward, between hope and hate, between unity and division. We have to decide, do we still believe in honesty, decency, respect, freedom, justice and democracy*.\"\n\nInsisting he would \"always level with\" the American people and tell the truth, Biden tried to explain why he stepped down from the presidential race without admitting that it was health-related, or due to his massive unpopularity.\n\n\"In recent weeks, it's become clear to me that I need to unite my party in this critical endeavor,\" he said.\n\nJean Pierre told skeptical reporters earlier Wednesday that Biden believed he could serve another four years, and in his speech, Wednesday night, Biden indicated that he thought he deserved a second term.\n\n\"I believe my record as president, my leadership in the world, my vision for America's future all merited a second term, but nothing -- nothing can come in the way of saving our democracy -- that includes personal ambition,\" Biden said.\n\nWithout explaining why, he asserted that the time to \"pass the torch\" to a new generation was now.\n\n\"You know, there is a time and a place for long years of experience in public life. But there's also a time and a place for new voices, fresh voices, yes, younger voices. And that time and place is now,\" he said.\n\nBiden went on to outline what he hopes to achieve in his remaining six months in office, citing a long litany of left-wing policies he would continue to push, including \"the right to vote and the right to choose.\" And he vowed to keep speaking out against \"hate and extremism,\" \"gun violence\" and the existential threat of \"climate crisis.\"\n\nBiden also said he would keep fighting for his Cancer Moonshot boondoggle that was launched in 2016 when he was vice president \"so we can end cancer as we know it.\"\n\nAnd he ominously added, \"I'm going to call for Supreme Court reform because this is critical to out democracy.\"\n\nBiden went on to assert that he ran for president four years ago because he believed \"the soul of America was at stake,\" and claimed that is still the case.\n\nHe concluded his speech without taking any questions from the media.\n\n*When Democrats say \"Democracy,\" they mean their hold on {"uri": "8242176195", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "01:27:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T01:27:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T01:25:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://dnyuz.com/2024/07/24/biden-backs-harris-pushes-supreme-court-reform-in-pass-the-torch-speech-about-ending-2024-bid/", "title": "Biden backs Harris, pushes Supreme Court 'reform' in 'pass the torch' speech about ending 2024 bid", "body": "President Biden addressed the nation for the first time on Wednesday since bowing out of the 2024 election, saying he is passing the torch to \"a new generation\" while again throwing his support behind Vice President Kamala Harris in her campaign to secure the Democratic Party's nomination.\n\n\"I decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation. It's the best way to unite our nation. You know, there is a time and a place for long years of experience in public life. There's also a time and place for new voices, fresh voices, yes, younger voices. And that time and place is now,\" Biden said.\n\nThe speech lasted roughly 11 minutes, with the president sitting at the Resolute Desk in the Oval Office while touting his years in political office and decision to bow out. Members of the president's family were in attendance for the speech, including first lady Jill Biden, daughter Ashley Biden, son Hunter Biden and others.\n\nThe president said he looks forward to the work before him in his final six months in office, including pushing for Supreme Court reforms.\n\n\"I'm gonna call for Supreme Court reform, because this is critical to our democracy,\" he said. Media reports recently surfaced that Biden is considering supporting legislation that would attempt to impose term limits on Supreme Court justices and a new enforceable ethics code.\n\nBiden announced his exit from the presidential race on Sunday evening in an X post while self-isolating in Rehoboth Beach, Delaware, following a COVID-19 diagnosis last Wednesday. After suffering \"mild symptoms\" and \"general malaise\" after his diagnosis, he received a negative diagnosis on Tuesday of this week and returned to the White House.\n\nHis trip back to the nation's capital on Tuesday marked the first time Biden was seen in public since suspending his re-election bid on Sunday and the first time since being diagnosed with COVID-19 on July 17.\n\nHis speech Wednesday evening included citing American forefathers and political leaders while arguing \"democracy is at stake\" this election cycle as the Democratic Party squares up against former President Donald Trump.\n\n\"Thomas Jefferson wrote the immortal words that guide this nation. George Washington showed us presidents are not kings. Abraham Lincoln implored us to reject malice. Franklin Roosevelt, who inspired us to reject fear. I revere this office, but I love my country more,\" he said.\n\n\"It's been the honor of my life to serve as your president, but in the defense of democracy, which is at stake, I think is more important than any title. I draw strength and I find joy in working for the American people. But this sacred task of perfecting our union, it's not about me. It's about you.\"\n\nTrump responded to the speech on Truth Social, saying it was \"was barely understandable, and sooo bad!\"\n\nThe 46th president had faced mounting pressure from his Democrat allies and legacy media outlets to bow out of the race since June 27, when he delivered a botched debate performance against Trump that was riddled with garbled remarks and where the president lost his train of thought and appeared more subdued than during other recent public events.\n\nThe debate reignited concern among conservatives and critics that Biden's mental acuity had slipped, while it marked the beginning of a pressure campaign among Democrats to oust Biden in favor of a candidate they believed is better suited to take on Trump.\n\nNow that the president has dropped out of the election cycle, conservative lawmakers and others have called on Biden to resign from the White House, arguing that if he is unable to run for re-election, he's unfit to run the nation for the roughly six months left of his tenure.\n\n\"If Joe Biden is not fit to run for President, he is not fit to serve as President. He must resign the office immediately. November 5 cannot arrive soon enough,\" House Speaker Mike Johnson, R-La., said in a statement on Sunday.\n\nOthers have called on Harris to invoke the 25th Amendment while concerns mount over Biden's health. Tennessee Rep. Andy Ogles sent a letter to Harris on Thursday requesting she invoke the 25th Amendment, exclusively telling Fox News Digital that Biden left the race \"because he isn't up for the job of president, and everyone in America knows it.\"\n\n\"I've said for over a year that Biden's ever-declining health has rendered him incapable of leading the nation. With his recent reclusion following a supposed COVID diagnosis, it is now more apparent than ever that he must resign or be forced out. Since Biden has made it clear he will not resign, it is imperative that Vice President Harris move forward with invoking the provisions of the 25th Amendment to remove him forcibly. The safety and well-being of the American people and our nation depend upon it,\" Ogles said.\n\nBiden's announcement on dropping out was made just more than a week after an assassination attempt on Trump's life during a rally in Pennsylvania and just days after the Republican National Convention wrapped up in Milwaukee, where Trump was officially declared to be the Republican Party's nominee.", Sign up for NBC Boston's newsletters.\n\n\"I draw strength, and find joy, in working for the American people,\" Biden said from the Oval Office.\n\n\"But this sacred task of perfecting our union is not about me. It's about you. Your families. Your futures. It's about 'We the People.' \"\n\n\"I gave my heart and my soul to our nation,\" Biden said. \"I hope you have some idea how grateful I am to all of you.\"\n\nBiden's speech comes three days after the 81-year-old president quit the race against former President Donald Trump, the Republican nominee, and threw his full support behind Harris.\n\n\"I have decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation,\" Biden said.\n\n\"That is the best way to unite our nation.\"\n\nBiden, without mentioning Trump by name, nodded to the threat he believes the Republican represents to the United States if he is elected in November.\n\n\"I ran for president four years ago because I believed and still do, that the soul of America was a stake,\" said Biden, who defeated Trump in 2020. \"The very nature of who we are was a stake. And that's still the case.\"\n\nBiden, who plans to serve out the remainder of his first term, which ends in January, returned to Washington on Tuesday after several days of isolating at his Delaware beach house, recovering from Covid-19.\n\nBiden's decision to exit the race on Sunday during that Covid quarantine came after a weeks-long pressure campaign from Democratic lawmakers, donors and strategists calling on him to step aside after his stumbling June debate performance against Trump.\n\nThe debate fumble escalated lingering concerns regarding Biden's age and fitness to wage a successful campaign against Trump, much less complete a second presidential term.\n\nSince Sunday, the Biden-turned-Harris campaign has been in a honeymoon phase.\n\nHarris has secured the endorsements of hundreds of Democratic lawmakers and governing officials, including those who were previously floated as potential contenders to replace Biden at the top of the ticket.\n\nThose names have now been ruled out as potential Harris challengers and instead are on the list to become her running mate.\n\nHarris has also raked in record levels of donations online and from high-dollar donors. Her first several campaign rallies have seen more attendees than any the campaign has seen this election cycle. And she is starting to catch up to Trump in the polls, according to initial voter surveys.\n\nBiden in his speech Wednesday gave his vice president another full-throated endorsement\n\n\"I made my choice. I made my views known. I'd like to thank our great Vice President Kamala Harris,\" he said. \"She experienced. She's tough, she's capable. She's been an incredible partner to me. And the leader for our country. Now, the choice is up to you, the American people. \"\n\nBiden then reminded Americans about their power in the election.\n\n\"The great thing about America is here, kings and dictators do not rule,\" the president said.\n\n\"The people do. History is in your hands. The power is in your hands.
