{"uri": "2024-07-432687555", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "01:05:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T01:05:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T01:04:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4313725531101227, "url": "https://www.bnd.com/news/nation-world/national/article290403579.html", "title": "Biden Says the Idea of America 'Lies in Your Hands'", "body": "President Joe Biden said he abandoned his reelection bid despite believing that his record and leadership deserved a second term, declaring that it is time for \"new voices, fresh voices, yes, younger voices\" led by a new generation of leadership in America.\n\n\"I revere this office, but I love my country more,\" he said during a prime-time address from behind the Resolute Desk in the Oval Office. \"Nothing, nothing can come in the way of saving our democracy. That includes personal ambition.\"\n\nThe speech was the president's first public comments since passing the torch to Vice President Kamala Harris as the Democratic Party's presumptive nominee. He did not dwell on the concerns about his age or health that caused him to relent to pressure from within his own party after a listless and halting debate performance.\n\nInstead, he pledged to continue working on foreign and domestic policy, seeking to advance his agenda even as a lame duck president for the next 180 days. He said of Harris that she is \"experienced, she's tough; she's capable\" and urged voters to pick her over former President Donald Trump.\n\nHere's what to know:\n\nBiden's future: The president still has six months -- or roughly an eighth of his term -- to cement his legacy and assist Harris on the campaign trail. Traditionally, a lame-duck president -- one who is assuredly on his way out of office -- is in a frustrating position, with fewer opportunities to pass major legislation or capture the attention of the public. But Biden has already vowed that he's \"not going anywhere,\" declaring that he will continue to advance his own agenda until January.\n\nTrump assails Harris: Trump called Harris a \"radical-left lunatic\" who would destroy the country in his first campaign rally since Biden dropped out. Repeatedly mispronouncing her first name and calling her \"Lyin' Kamala,\" Trump accused her of helping conceal what he described as Biden's unfitness for the presidency and falsely claimed she had \"headed up\" the four criminal cases against him.\n\nHarris' fast start: Harris continued an energetic sprint around the country, blasting Trump as a candidate who wants to return America to a \"dark past,\" with cuts to Medicare and the elimination of the Education Department and popular programs like Head Start. At an appearance in Indianapolis a day after her first rally in Milwaukee, she repeated her vow that \"we are not going back. We are not going back.\"\n\nNetanyahu's visit: Earlier in the day, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel delivered an address to a joint session of Congress in which he defiantly defended Israel's war in the Gaza Strip. Netanyahu is scheduled to meet with Biden and Harris on Thursday, before traveling to Florida for a meeting with Trump on Friday. Among the most urgent concerns are American support for Israel and efforts to bring home the remaining 120 living and dead hostages and end the fighting in Gaza, where Palestinian health officials say {"uri": "8242204307", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "02:02:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T02:02:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T02:01:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4274509847164154, "url": "https://thespectator.com/politics/joe-biden-delivers-own-eulogy-white-house-address/", "title": "Joe Biden delivers his own eulogy", "body": "Convince the country that he is still fit to serve the remaining months of his term; and\n\nJoe Biden delivered a eulogy for his presidency and his political career from the Oval Office Wednesday evening. It was a sad, sluggish ending to a life in politics, decades in the Senate, two terms as vice president, and finally a single term as president.\n\nPresident Biden needed to accomplish three things in the speech:\n\nHe certainly promoted Harris and indirectly attacked Donald Trump, effectively calling him a threat to democracy. But he did nothing to explain why he withdrew from the race and nothing to convince a worried country that he was still fit to serve as president.\n\nHe didn't even try to explain why he withdrew. He simply quoted John F. Kennedy's inaugural speech that it \"was time to pass the torch a new generation.\" But quoting JFK doesn't explain why Joe suddenly reached that epiphany last weekend, rather than a year ago, before he chose to run and cleared the field of other Democratic candidates. What changed? Biden's speech evaded the question.\n\nThere are lots of plausible answers. It might have been his catastrophic debate performance, which convinced many Americans that he no longer had the cognitive capacity to lead the country. It might have been his dismal poll numbers, the lowest of any president since modern polling began (even before the debate performance). It might have been polling in swing states, which showed he was unlikely to win the electoral votes he needs. It might have been the intense pressure from elected Democrats and unhappy donors, some of it in public, much of it behind closed doors.\n\nThe best reporting says Biden didn't jump, he was pushed. He was ousted in a back-room coup, led by Nancy Pelosi and Barack Obama. We still don't know which carrots and sticks they used to convince Biden to step down. Reports are that Pelosi told Biden, \"We can do this the easy way, or we can do it the hard way.\" We don't know what \"the hard way\" was, but we do know the former speaker of the House was working the phones aggressively to remove Biden. She gave him a couple of weeks to do it the easy way -- and he resisted ferociously.\n\nThen, over the weekend, Biden caved. We don't know why. His press secretary, Karine Jean-Pierre, said it was not a health problem. He's perfectly fine, she said, an answer that continues the cover-up about Biden's condition the White House has maintained for months. But if poor health wasn't the reason, then what was? Biden won't say. He certainly didn't in his Oval Office speech.\n\nBiden's health wasn't just a reelection problem. It's a governing problem now. His frailty raises serious questions about whether he is fit to serve until mid-January 2025. It is not correct to say, as many Republicans do, that if he is not fit to serve another four years, then he is not fit to serve now. It is possible to be healthy enough to serve now but doubtful about the future.\n\nBiden needed to address these health issues, but made no effort to do so. None. Polls show most Americans are genuinely concerned about the president's fail health and cognitive decline and wonder if he can continue leading the country for another four and half months. Indeed, they wonder if he is really running things now and, if he isn't, who is? Biden's brief speech won't reassure them. Although he didn't make any major gaffes, he hardly gave a strong performance. He simply read the teleprompter in a soft, gravelly voice for eleven minutes and said he would continue to serve.\n\nThe most forceful portion of the speech was its partisan conclusion, which was less about Kamala Harris and more about the looming \"threat to democracy\" -- and we all know who Biden meant. He never mentioned Donald Trump's name, but he was the obvious target. Even when he condemned political violence, Biden refused to mention the assassination attempt on Trump.\n\nGenerosity was not the theme of the speech. The theme was that he had saved our union from Trump and that the threat was the central issue of this campaign. Without ever mentioning Trump's name, he told the nation that failing to elect Kamala Harris would endanger our democracy. The country was at \"an inflection point,\" he said, before stumbling through Benjamin Franklin's famous quote about our form of government. As Franklin exited the Continental Congress, a woman asked him whether we had a monarchy or republic. \"A republic,\" he replied, \"if you can keep it.\"\n\nFranklin was right that our republic must be sustained, not taken for granted and allowed to decay, to be replaced by tyranny. Biden's speech clearly implied that a Trump presidency would usher in that tyranny and end our constitutional republic. The Harris campaign will run with that theme until November.\n\nOn that somber note, Joe Biden ended his political career. He spoke in soft, faltering tones that did little to answer Americans' question or reassure them our nation is in capable hands until January 20, 2025.", "source": {"uri": "thespectator.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Spectator World"}, "authors": [{"uri": "charles_lipson@thespectator.com", "name": "Charles Lipson", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Biden", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Joe Biden"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oval_Office", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Oval Office"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "John F. He reminded his audience that the only reason he came out of retirement in 2020 to run for President was because he personally felt that democracy itself was threatened by the autocratic Trump. He reminded the audience that George Washington voluntarily gave up the reins of power, that Lincoln gave his life to unite the American people during the Civil War, and that FDR reminded the American people that \"The only thing to fear is fear itself\". {"uri": "8242220016", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "02:17:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T02:17:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T02:16:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.407843142747879, "url": "https://nypost.com/2024/07/24/opinion/in-his-farewell-joe-biden-shows-exactly-why-he-had-to-go/", "title": "In his 'farewell,' Joe Biden shows exactly why he had to go", "body": "Joe Biden said his farewell to the nation Wednesday night, and it was the same old malarkey.\n\nHe didn't even leave.\n\nIf you watched this speech not knowing what led up to it, you'd have no idea why Biden was not running for re-election.\n\nThere wasn't a word about his age, his recent public stumbles, or the pressure from his party.\n\nInstead, Biden sermonized on the importance of character and telling the truth, as if he and his White House hadn't spent years misleading the public about the president's capacity to do the job.\n\nIf you watched waiting for an explanation of why he thinks he can still do that job and doesn't need to resign, you didn't get that, either.\n\nBiden talked about what he still wants to do, but not how this old man, slurring his cliches for 13 minutes off a TelePrompter, is supposed to do it.\n\nIf Donald Trump tested the nation's patience by speaking for 92 minutes at the Republican convention, Biden demonstrated why he couldn't go a fraction of that distance even if he needed to.\n\nIf you watched looking for a warm endorsement of Kamala Harris, you didn't get much.\n\nBiden gave her a generic shout-out that said nothing about what she actually contributed to his administration.\n\nBut then, what is there to say?\n\nOf course, an Oval Office speech to the nation isn't supposed to be a campaign speech.\n\nBut this was still a campaign speech, and nothing else.\n\nBiden rehashed the supposed highlights of his presidency, and insulted the intelligence of his listeners with claims to have defeated crime and secured the border.\n\nHis main message was that he was stepping aside because to \"save our democracy,\" by which he means winning the next election - as if democracy is over if the voters change who's in charge.\n\nHe won't stop touting that message even though Trump was nominated by 17 million Republican primary voters, while Harris was handed her nomination after Nancy Pelosi and George Clooney led a revolt of donors and elites.\n\nBiden wants Americans to believe that he's a unifier who stands against \"hate and extremism\" and \"political violence,\" but at every turn his entire argument depends upon demonizing his opponents and blaming them for all of those things.\n\nIn a telling slip, borrowing the words of Abraham Lincoln, he started to say that we are \"not enemies but friends,\" but caught himself midway through \"friends\" and said \"fellow Americans\" instead.\n\nLincoln, in his first inaugural address on the eve of civil war, could still call the Confederates who had already declared secession \"friends.\"\n\nBiden couldn't quite manage it.\n\nThe most ominous part of the speech, however, was when he announced that he still intends to pursue \"Supreme Court reform\" and that it is vital to \"democracy.\"\n\nBiden is reportedly preparing a plan for \"limiting\" the Supreme Court with term limits and other schemes aimed at ousting several of the conservative justices.\n\nThis is Court-packing by another name. It would demolish 235 years of unbroken tradition of securing an independent judiciary through life tenure.\n\nThat's bad for democracy. Judges are supposed to enforce the Constitution and laws as they were written precisely because they were written by the elected representatives of the people.\n\nIf you change the judges, you can change the laws without winning elections.\n\nFranklin D. Roosevelt's 1937 Court-packing plot was so dangerous that the Senate Judiciary Committee, run by his own party, warned that it \"should be so emphatically rejected that its parallel will never again be presented to the free representatives of the free people of America.\"\n\nBiden himself once said that FDR's plan showed that he'd been \"corrupted by power.\"\n\nIf we judge Joe Biden by his last act, he won't be leaving the Oval Office a moment too soon.", "source": {"uri": "nypost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "New York Post"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-430114358", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-22", "time": "19:27:13", "dateTime": "2024-07-22T19:27:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-22T19:25:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.3803921639919281, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/news/biden-legacy-president/", "title": "Joe Biden's legacy after historic decision to give up 2024 reelection campaign", "body": "President Joe Biden on Sunday became the first presumptive nominee to give up the nomination at this point in the process, weeks before the convention and months after he had won enough delegates to clinch the nomination.\n\nHis presidency began on the steps of the U.S. Capitol, where days before insurrectionists overran the U.S. Capitol, on Jan. 6, 2021.\n\n\"We will press forward with speed and urgency,\" he said in his inaugural speech, \"for we have much to do in this winter of peril and possibility.\"\n\nThe day before his inauguration, Mr. Biden marked 400,000 COVID deaths, and less than five weeks later, the toll had risen to half a million.\n\n\"That's more lives lost to this virus than any other nation on Earth,\" Mr. Biden said.\n\nMr. Biden's gesture bore the habitual empathy that has been the hallmark of his political life, an emotive approach fit for the unease of the time.\n\n\"To heal, we must remember,\" he said in marking the 500,000 deaths. \"I know it's hard. I promise you, I know it's hard.\"\n\nThe coronavirus pandemic posed an even more difficult challenge than Mr. Biden imagined, as variants and vaccine resistance led to over 700,000 deaths on his watch. During the toughest stretch of his 2024 reelection campaign, the virus sent him into isolation, and its symptoms were the reason he made the surprise announcement that he would not seek a second term on social media, rather than in person.\n\nJoseph Robinette Biden Jr. was born in 1942, the first pre-baby boom president since 1993.\n\nWhen the economy collapsed in Scranton, Pennsylvania, and his father lost his job, the Biden family moved to Delaware.\n\n\"My dad had an expression,\" Mr. Biden often said. \"He said, Joey, it's not a question of succeeding, whether you get knocked down, it's how quickly you get up.\"\n\nThe president played football at the University of Delaware and attended law school at Syracuse University.\n\nIn 1972, he ran for the U.S. Senate, as a long-shot tell-it-like-it-is 29-year-old.\n\n\"If you like what you see help me out, if you don't, vote for the other fella,\" he told voters on the campaign trail.\n\n\"I think one of the reasons I won is that they have more confidence in me that I will say what I think,\" Mr. Biden said at the time.\n\nWeeks later, his wife Neilia and year-old daughter Naomi were killed in a traffic accident that also injured his sons, Beau and Hunter.\n\n\"I felt like a piece of me died,\" Mr. Biden said. He took the oath of office in a hospital.\n\nAs a single father and U.S. senator, Mr. Biden commuted from Wilmington to Washington every day to be home with his children at night.\n\nIn 1975, he met Jill Jacobs, a teacher, on a blind date, and two years later, they married.\n\n\"Everyone knows I love her more than she loves me,\" he often says.\n\nMr. Biden first ran for president in 1987, but he dropped out after he was accused of plagiarism. A year later, he suffered two brain aneurysms but would later write that he had no fear of dying.\n\nAs chair of the powerful Senate Judiciary Committee, Mr. Biden presided over the confirmation hearings of Supreme Court Justice nominee Clarence Thomas. During the hearings, Anita Hill accused Thomas of sexually harassing her years earlier when they worked together. Her testimony was received with hostility from the panel composed entirely of White men, and Mr. Biden weathered criticism at the time and later for the way she was treated. Thomas has consistently said the charges were untrue. Mr. Biden declared an FBI investigation into the accusations inconclusive.\n\nIn 2019, Mr. Biden said, \"To this day I regret I couldn't come up with a way to get her the kind of hearing she deserved.\" Speaking at the Biden Courage awards, Biden said Hill \"paid a terrible price\" when she testified before a \"bunch of white guys.\"\n\nDuring his Senate career, one of Mr. Biden's greatest points of pride was the 1994 crime bill, which he drafted. It pushed crime down, but incarceration rates increased. The measure also included a ban on assault weapons.\n\nHe ran again for president in 2008, when Barack Obama won the primary and the presidency. But Obama chose him as his running mate, and during two terms, Mr. Biden oversaw stimulus spending and famously got ahead of the president in endorsing gay marriage.\n\n\"What this is all about is a simple proposition: who do you love,\" he said on NBC's \"Meet the Press\" in May 2012.\n\nMr. Biden also advised President Obama to wait for better confirmation before launching the raid that killed al Qaeda leader Osama bin Laden.\n\nMemorably, he also said of the passage of Obamacare, the national health care law, \"This is a big f****** deal.\"\n\nHe's always been known for verbal gaffes. Some were innocent. \"We choose truth over facts,\" he said at the Iowa State Fair in 2019.\n\nAnd others were less so.\n\n\"They're gonna put y'all back in chains,\" he told voters in Virginia, referring to the Republican-backed budget.\n\nIn 2016, he passed up a presidential run after his son Beau died of brain cancer in 2015.\n\nIn 2020, Mr. Biden's presidential campaign began inauspiciously with distant losses in both Iowa and New Hampshire. But he was able to consolidate support after a decisive victory in South Carolina.\n\n\"To all those who have been knocked down, counted out, left behind, let me say to you: this is your campaign,\" he declared.\n\nFor months, as the pandemic worsened, Mr. Biden stumped virtually -- from his basement. \"This is a war against this virus,\" he said.\n\nMr. Biden made history by picking California Sen. Kamala Harris as his running mate, the first woman of color to be nominated by a major party.\n\n\"Kamala knows how to govern. She knows how to make the hard calls,\" he said in August 2020. \"She's ready to do this job on Day One.\"\n\nThat November, Mr. Biden defeated Donald Trump by 7 million votes. He brushed aside Trump's false claims of fraud and prepared to bring the pandemic under control. In his first 100 days, he accelerated vaccine distribution and strong-armed a $2 trillion COVID relief plan through Congress with slim Democratic majorities.\n\nMr. Biden pitched his candidacy as that of a soft-spoken healer, but he governed more progressively than Obama. He has made his presidency a transition between the nation's older, racially calloused past and its softer, youthful and more inclusive future.\n\nHe appointed the first Black woman to the Supreme Court -- Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson is his only Supreme Court nominee so far, and he signed a $1.2 trillion infrastructure bill into law\n\nHis presidency was hampered by low approval ratings, an outcome of concerns about high inflation, comparatively lenient border policies and the chaotic withdrawal of U.S. forces from Afghanistan.\n\nThroughout his reelection bid, Mr. Biden fought hard and spent tens of millions just to try to stay even with Trump.\n\nBut a disastrous presidential debate against Trump, in which he struggled with hoarseness, keeping his train of thought and finishing sentences, and failed to effectively refute Trump's false claims, raised immediate doubts among Democrats about his ability to finish another four-year term.\n\nHe was unable to stop the erosion of support among lawmakers and top donors, and after defying pressure to drop out for over three weeks, he suddenly announced his exit from the race in a social media post.\n\n\"[W]hile it has been my intention to seek reelection, I believe it is in the best interest of my party and the country for me to stand down and to focus solely on fulfilling my duties as president for the remainder of my term,\" he wrote Sunday afternoon.\n\nEven as president and the presumptive nominee of his party, he saw that the political tides had turned against him. In the end, Mr. Biden was persuaded to preserve his legacy, rather than risk defeat for himself and Democrats nationwide.", "source": {"uri": "cbsnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CBS News"}, {"uri": "8242120525", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "00:16:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T00:16:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T00:16:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.3568627536296844, "url": "https://abc7.com/live-updates/election-2024-live-updates-president-biden-says-best-to-pass-torch-a-new-generation-during-oval-office-address-nation/15078184/", "title": "Election live updates: Biden says best to pass 'torch to a new generation'", "body": "Click here for a look at how the Biden campaign reached this historic decision to end his candidacy for a second term.\n\nDuring his speech, the president talked about his reflecting on saving democracy and his bid for a second term.\n\nUltimately he decided it was in the best interest to end his campaign.\n\n\"Nothing can come in the way of saving our democracy, that includes personal ambition. So I've decided the best way forward is the pass the torch to the new generation,\" he said.\n\n\"There is a time and a place for long years of experience in public life. There's also a time and a place for new voices, fresh voices and yes, younger voices. And that time and place is now,\" he added.", "source": {"uri": "abc7.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ABC7"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Biden", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Joe Biden"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democracy", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Democracy"}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Advice", "label": "dmoz/Society/Advice", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Paranormal/Prophecies", "label": "dmoz/Society/Paranormal/Prophecies", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://cdn.abcotvs.com/dip/images/15085927_072324-cc-ap-biden-thumbs-up-img.jpg?w=1600", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9761289", "eventUri": "eng-9761289", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.2705882352941176, "wgt": 91, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8236959975", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-22", "time": "03:43:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-22T03:43:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-22T03:43:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.3333333432674408, "url": "https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-07-22/joe-biden-reelection-hope-ended-by-age-worries-after-long-career/101359570", "title": "Joe Biden spent a lifetime working towards the White House. His age ultimately caught up with him", "body": "Joe Biden's decision not to contest this year's US election will bring a decades-long political career to an end.\n\nAmerica's oldest-ever president started out as one of its youngest senators, winning his seat just before his 30th birthday -- the minimum age to enter.\n\n\"I expect these fellas are going to eventually judge me on my merit, not on my age,\" he said in a television interview shortly after his victory.\n\nBut more than half a century on, concerns about the 81-year-old's age -- and his capacity to do the job -- became too loud to ignore.\n\n\"It has been the greatest honour of my life to serve as your president,\" Biden wrote in a statement.\n\n\"And while it has been my intention to seek re-election, I believe it is in the best interest of my party and the country for me to stand down and to focus solely on fulfilling my duties as president for the remainder of my term.\"\n\nPerseverance in the face of adversity has been a hallmark of Mr Biden's political and personal life, and initially he'd remained defiant after his disastrous debate against Donald Trump.\n\nBut less than four months out from the November election, the United States' 46th president will step aside for another Democrat to fight for the chance to become its 47th.\n\nWhen Mr Biden won his spot in the US Senate in 1972, he was a married father of three young children.\n\n\"The doors were just beginning to swing open on the rest of our lives,\" he wrote in his 2008 memoir, Promises to Keep.\n\nWithin weeks, he would receive news that would change everything.\n\nMr Biden was in Washington interviewing staff for his new office with his sister Val when she took a phone call that turned her face white.\n\n\"She's dead, isn't she,\" Mr Biden recalled asking his sister about his wife.\n\nNeilia Biden had been driving their children to buy a Christmas tree when their car was hit by a truck.\n\nShe was killed, alongside their baby daughter Naomi, while sons Beau and Hunter were seriously injured.\n\nMr Biden considered ending his federal political career before it had started.\n\nBut he was convinced by fellow Democrats to stay on, and took the oath of office by his son Beau's bedside.\n\nBarbara Perry, a presidential scholar at the University of Virginia, said the tragedy helped to make the future president the \"most empathetic politician imaginable\".\n\n\"Joe Biden, when people would speak to him about a tragedy, and he would commiserate with them, they knew that he had felt this horrible tragedy and pain,\" Ms Perry said.\n\n\"And so, he's become the expert -- the consoler-in-chief.\"\n\nTwo and a half years after losing his wife and daughter, Mr Biden met Jill Jacobs, an aspiring teacher studying English at the University of Delaware.\n\nIn Mr Biden's re-telling, he proposed marriage multiple times before she agreed.\n\nHe even offered her a deal -- marry him and he'd leave the Senate.\n\nBut she stopped him from doing so, saying: \"If I denied you your dream ... I would not be marrying the man I fell in love with.\"\n\nDespite the difficult start, Mr Biden proved to be a solid negotiator and legislator in the Senate, often seeking bipartisan consensus and compromise over the objections of his more progressive colleagues.\n\nHe was well-liked on both sides of the political aisle but some contentious elements of his otherwise moderate 36-year record clung to him on the presidential campaign trail.\n\nAs chair of the Senate Judiciary Committee, which he sat on for 17 years, Mr Biden oversaw the near-unanimous confirmations of justices Antonin Scalia and Ruth Bader Ginsburg to the Supreme Court.\n\nBut his handling of the confirmation hearing of Justice Clarence Thomas in 1992 was far from smooth.\n\nThomas was accused of sexually harassing his former colleague, Anita Hill, who reluctantly agreed to testify during the hearing.\n\nHill, an African American law professor, faced a panel of white men and had her claims publicly dissected and sometimes outright dismissed.\n\nAhead of his 2020 presidential bid, Mr Biden expressed \"regret\" over the treatment she received, but never fully reconciled his role in it.\n\n\"I cannot be satisfied by simply saying, 'I'm sorry for what happened to you,'\" Professor Hill told the New York Times.\n\n\"I will be satisfied when I know that there is real change and real accountability and real purpose.\"\n\nMr Biden also faced ongoing criticism for sections of his 1994 crime law -- considered to be one of his key legislative achievements.\n\nHis opponents labelled the law overly punitive, arguing it led to the disproportionate incarceration of black men.\n\nBut even some staunch objectors to the bill's \"tough on crime\" bent have acknowledged the merits of inclusions such as the Violence Against Women Act and a 10-year ban on the sale of some assault weapons.\n\nMr Biden also voted to authorise his predecessor George W Bush's move to invade Iraq in 2002, though he later argued he was misled.\n\nMore than 16 years on, as a frontrunner to win his party's presidential nomination, he claimed to have opposed the war from the \"moment it started\".\n\nThe assertion was roundly rejected by his anti-war colleagues and fact-checkers alike.\n\nMr Biden first ran for president ahead of the 1988 election, but his campaign sank due to a plagiarism scandal.\n\n\"I made some mistakes,\" he told reporters as he withdrew from the race.\n\n\"But now the exaggerated shadow of those mistakes has begun to obscure the essence of my candidacy and the essence of Joe Biden.\"\n\nMonths later, he was in a hotel room in Pennsylvania after giving a speech when he woke up on the floor, fully clothed, with a \"rip of pain\" he'd never felt before.\n\nThe-then-45-year-old was diagnosed with a brain aneurysm.\n\nA priest was called to his hospital bed to give him the last rites.\n\nBut surgeons were able to remove the aneurysm, as well as a second, smaller one, and he returned to the Senate later that year.\n\n\"I had had a lot of time to think about my past and my future, and I wanted to be in the senate for years to come,\" he wrote.\n\n\"For good or ill, I was a public man.\"\n\nTwo decades after his first attempt at running for president, Mr Biden tried again in 2008, ultimately losing to a rising star from a new generation of politicians, Barack Obama.\n\nMr Biden went on to become Mr Obama's vice-president and, after a frosty start, the pair famously formed a close bond.\n\n\"This is an extraordinary man with an extraordinary career in public service,\" Mr Obama said while awarding Biden the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 2017.\n\n\"Behind the scenes, Joe's candid, honest counsel has made me a better president and a better commander-in-chief.\"\n\nMr Biden decided to rule out another bid for the presidency in 2016 while grieving the loss of his son Beau, an Iraq veteran and former Delaware attorney-general who died of brain cancer.\n\n\"To lose his wife and baby daughter at such a young age in 1972 would have been enough for anyone for one lifetime, but then to lose his son Beau, in 2015, to brain cancer ... He was the apple of his eye,\" Ms Perry said.\n\n\"He was what Joe Biden called 'the perfect Joe Biden' -- if Joe Biden had perfected himself, he said it would be Beau. He called him Joe 2.0.\"\n\nIt was Beau, Mr Biden said, who had urged him to stay involved in public life.\n\n\"He's the one who made me stay engaged, made me promise. 'Promise me Dad, promise me Dad,'\" he told NBC News.\n\nIn 2020, he fulfilled that promise, taking on then-president Donald Trump.\n\nMr Biden pointed to a violent white supremacist rally in Charlottesville, Virginia, in 2017, during Trump's presidency, as a motivating factor in his decision to run.\n\nHe campaigned on a promise to unite the country against a backdrop of the COVID-19 pandemic and a reckoning with racial violence following the murder of George Floyd.\n\nMr Biden won with 81 million votes, more than any other US president in history -- and more than 51 per cent of the total number cast.\n\nBut Trump falsely claimed the election was stolen, prompting a group of his supporters to storm the US Capitol on January 6, 2021 -- the day Mr Biden's victory was to be certified.\n\n\"We have learned again that democracy is precious,\" Mr Biden told the crowd at his inauguration later that month.\n\n\"Democracy is fragile. And at this hour, my friends, democracy has prevailed.\"\n\nMr Biden set about trying to move the US past the pandemic, even as COVID-19 continued to claim hundreds of thousands of lives.\n\nInflation soared to its highest level in four decades, intensifying cost of living pressures that many Americans are still struggling with.\n\nAnd a historic surge in the number of migrants entering the US over its border with Mexico made immigration one of the top concerns for many voters.\n\nMr Biden chalked up legislative victories on infrastructure spending and manufacturing, and successfully pushed for the most significant package of gun control laws in decades following the Uvalde school shooting.\n\nHe chose Kamala Harris to be America's first female vice-president and nominated the first black woman to the US Supreme Court, Ketanji Brown-Jackson.\n\nAnd when the court overturned Roe v Wade, ending the constitutional right to an abortion, Mr Biden made reproductive rights a major political focus.\n\nDemocrats defied predictions of a so-called \"red wave\" to maintain control of the Senate in the 2022 midterm elections.\n\nAnd while they lost the House of Representatives, Republicans took control with a razor-thin margin.\n\nTrump's hand-picked candidates largely failed to deliver in the midterms, prompting questions about his ongoing influence.\n\nBut he announced his 2024 candidacy soon after and went on to dominate the Republican primaries, easily securing enough support to become the party's presumptive nominee.\n\nMr Biden had regularly pointed to his foreign policy experience on the campaign trail, both as a former vice-president and the chair of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.\n\nBut his approval ratings slumped after the chaotic withdrawal of US troops from Afghanistan in 2021.\n\nThe pace of the fall of Kabul shocked US intelligence officials, as Taliban fighters swept through the capital and the government collapsed within days.\n\nThe domestic political fallout for the Biden administration was swift and severe, with a Republican-led House Foreign Affairs Committee launching an investigation in the aftermath of the withdrawal.\n\nMr Biden promised to step up US engagement in the Indo-Pacific region in the face of China's increasing aggression, agreeing to the AUKUS deal to provide Australia with nuclear-powered submarines, and strengthening ties with Pacific Island leaders.\n\nAnd he rallied the West in the wake of Russia's invasion of Ukraine, helping to expand the NATO alliance and pledging to support Kyiv for \"as long as it takes\".\n\nHowever as the war dragged on, support for Ukraine in Congress fell, and passing further financial aid became more difficult.\n\nMr Biden also faced intense scrutiny over his support for Israel after Hamas' October 7 attacks sparked a months-long bombardment of Gaza.\n\nThe president approved billions of dollars worth of military support for the country at the same time it deployed assistance for Gaza's worsening humanitarian crisis.\n\nPro-Palestinian protests engulfed US college campuses, and Mr Biden's public appearances were regularly interrupted by demonstrators.\n\nHe faced protest votes in some of his 2024 primary elections, with tens of thousands of people in the swing state of Michigan voting \"uncommitted\" rather than for the president.\n\nWithout any serious challengers though, Mr Biden's path to the Democratic presidential nomination seemed to be in no doubt.\n\nRepublican control of the House of Representatives increased political pressure on the president, with the launch of an impeachment inquiry and probes into his son Hunter's foreign business dealings.\n\nHunter Biden was also the subject of federal investigations which resulted in the now-54-year-old being charged with tax and firearms offences.\n\nHis criminal trial on the gun charges earlier this year exposed damaging details about his drug addiction, and led to the first-ever conviction of a child of a sitting president.\n\nHis father sought to sharpen his attack over another historic court case, after Trump was found guilty of falsifying business records in New York.\n\nMr Biden started referring to Trump as a \"convicted felon\" and repeatedly criticised his handling of the January 6 attack, arguing he was not fit for the White House.\n\nBut the president's own capacity to do the job came under increasing scrutiny, with concerns about his age -- which had been aired since his 2020 campaign -- taking on new urgency.\n\nMr Biden has been open about a stutter he experienced as a child, recalling in his memoir that he spoke \"like Morse code. Dot-dot-dot-dot-dash-dash-dash-dash\".\n\nWhile he improved the stutter by reciting long poems in the mirror, he said earlier this year that he had \"struggled\" with it his whole life.\n\nThe president has a long history of verbal slip-ups, and once described himself as a \"gaffe machine\".\n\nBut not all of his stumbles could be easily explained.\n\nAt a public event in 2022, he asked \"Where's Jackie\", appearing to forget that Republican representative Jackie Walorski had died the previous month.\n\nThe White House argued he made the comment because she was \"top of mind\".\n\nQuestions around Mr Biden's mental acuity also intensified after a federal prosecutor investigating his handling of classified documents wrote that he would likely present to a jury as a \"sympathetic, well-meaning, elderly man with a poor memory\".\n\nThe president called a snap press conference to hit back at the report, only to confuse the presidents of Egypt and Mexico.\n\nMr Biden's physical fitness was also queried.\n\nFootage of the president falling on the stairs to Air Force One, and on stage at a graduation ceremony, were watched around the world.\n\nAnd he reportedly changed his routine around arriving at and leaving the White House to draw less attention to his \"halting and stiff gait\".\n\nHowever, the turning point came when Mr Biden faced off against Trump in their first debate of the 2024 campaign.\n\nThe president's team had called for the unusually early showdown and spent days helping him to prepare at the Maryland retreat Camp David.\n\nConcerns in the Democratic Party were raised from the moment he walked out.\n\nMr Biden spoke with a hoarse voice, appeared to stare blankly at times while Trump was speaking, and trailed off to the point where some of his answers did not make sense.\n\nThe White House blamed a cold, and then jet lag, with the president telling donors in the aftermath that he \"nearly fell asleep on stage\".\n\nHe later conceded he had a bad night, but insisted he was still the best person for the job and would not withdraw from the race.\n\nThe president hit out at what he called \"elites\" within the party calling for him to step aside, arguing Democratic voters had endorsed him overwhelmingly to be the candidate in the party's primary elections.\n\nUltimately, though, the pressure on Mr Biden only increased.\n\nAs dozens of Democrats publicly called on him to step aside, the president was diagnosed with COVID-19 on July 18.\n\nIsolated at his Delaware home, he decided to call time on his political career, although he insisted he would finish his presidential term.\n\nHe threw his endorsement behind his 59-year-old deputy Kamala Harris.\n\nMr Biden once suggested he'd serve as a \"bridge\" to a new generation of leaders, and his decision to seek another four years in office raised questions from the beginning.\n\nAfter so many years spent in public life, his legacy extends beyond his one term in the White House.\n\nBut the timing of his exit, and the way in which he did so, could have a profound impact on the outcome of this election and who Americans choose to take over in 2025.", "source": {"uri": "abc.net.au", "dataType": "news", "title": "Australian Broadcasting Corporation"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/.mr", "type": {"uri": "8241691534", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "17:23:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T17:23:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T17:23:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.3098039329051971, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/wilmington-delaware-joe-glad-quit-171116761.html", "title": "In Wilmington, They Like 'Delaware Joe.' But They're Glad He Quit.", "body": "WILMINGTON, Del. -- As President Joe Biden met with confidants last week to discuss whether he should end his reelection campaign, John Flaherty, a retired government employee, was seated in a booth at Angelo's Luncheonette in Wilmington, Delaware, the small city that has been Biden's political home base for more than 50 years.\n\nWearing a Philadelphia Phillies cap, Flaherty, 73, who worked as a staff assistant to Biden in the 1980s, invoked the song \"The Gambler\" to express his opinion of what the president should do.\n\n\"As Kenny Rogers said, 'You got to know when to hold 'em, know when to fold 'em,'\" he said.\n\nSign up for The Morning newsletter from the New York Times\n\nShortly after Biden announced that he had put an end to his bid, Flaherty weighed in by phone. \"I'm glad,\" he said. \"I think he should enjoy his life after January and spend time with his family.\"\n\nHe added that he was \"happy\" that Biden's withdrawal had left Donald Trump as the oldest major-party presidential nominee. \"Biden might be the oldest president,\" he said, but now \"Trump will be the oldest candidate\" for president.\n\nWilmington, a city of roughly 71,000, is the site of the Joseph R. Biden Railroad Station, one of the busiest Amtrak stops along the Northeast Corridor, and Biden's main residence is in a nearby suburb. But even here, in the world's most Biden-friendly enclave, Flaherty was just one of many who believed the president had made the right call.\n\nMost people I spoke with for this article seemed fond of the president but pessimistic about his reelection prospects. And everybody, it seemed, had a Biden story.\n\nAt Angelo's, where Biden used to stop in for meals, I heard about a poster from his 1988 presidential campaign that had pride of place on a wall near the booths. For years, a smiling Biden, surrounded by his wife and children, looked down on the customers.\n\nEarly in Trump's presidency, the poster prompted occasional anti-Biden remarks, according to Nina, a server at the restaurant who did not want to share her last name. And then, at some point, the bickering among the customers over politics grew more heated. Finally, the staff had enough and took the poster down.\n\n\"People are jerks,\" Nina said softly, as if not wanting to provoke more arguing.\n\nEven in Wilmington, which propelled a 29-year-old Biden to the U.S. Senate in 1972, local pride has met political reality.\n\nBiden moved with his family from Scranton, Pennsylvania, to Wilmington in 1953, at age 10. For 70 years, he has been rooted in this place, and he has shaken thousands of hands in its neighborhoods, from Little Italy to Trolley Square.\n\nOne of his most ardent local supporters is Eunice LaFate, an artist who operates LaFate Gallery on Market Street, where she sells her paintings.\n\nBorn and raised in Jamaica, LaFate, 77, moved to Wilmington in 1983 after meeting her husband, a city native who worked for Amtrak. \"I saw a banner in a park on a yellow board,\" she said, sitting amid her colorful paintings last week. \"It said, 'Wilmington -- A Place to Be Somebody.'\"\n\nLaFate spent 12 years working for a bank in town, she said. The shift to becoming a full-time artist and gallerist was inspired, in part, by an encouraging letter she received from then-Sen. Biden after one of her paintings had adorned the cover of Out & About, a local entertainment publication.\n\nLaFate's Biden story has to do with his son Beau, who died in May 2015, shortly after the death of her husband.\n\n\"When his son passed, I stood five hours in a line at the church, waiting to greet him,\" LaFate said. \"After the five hours waiting in line, I went up and expressed my condolences. And I mentioned to him I am going through grief myself. The man took time out to console me. It was just -- what should I say -- so moving. The crowd was waiting, but he took time out.\"\n\nThere was no portrait of Biden on the walls of LaFate's gallery, but she went into the back to show me another one she had done -- of Kamala Harris, painted after the 2020 election, wearing a white shirt and a black blazer against a pink background.\n\nIn an interview the day after Biden's announcement, LaFate seemed happy with the turn of events. \"This is where our salad bowl of culture comes into play,\" she said. \"And Kamala Harris is a very dynamic ingredient in that salad. And she has Jamaican heritage! Her father is Jamaican. So all of this combined, this is pretty dynamic for me.\"\n\nJerry duPhily, the publisher of Out & About, spoke fondly of the president over lunch last week at the Kozy Korner, another Wilmington spot that Biden has been known to frequent.\n\n\"People go, 'Why does he come back so much?'\" duPhily, 66, said. \"I think he likes it here. He's comfortable.\" But he added that there were concerns. \"I think a lot of people are cognizant of, 'You're 81, and you lost a step, and we see it,'\" he said.\n\nAfter the announcement, duPhily said that Biden had made the right decision, in his view. \"Maybe he could have made it a few weeks earlier,\" he said. \"But someone who has the history he does, which is being a fighter and determined, isn't just going to walk away from it.\"\n\nDuPhily added that he hoped Biden would build his presidential library in Wilmington, saying, \"OK, he's from Scranton -- but he's Delaware Joe.\"\n\nPerhaps more than anyone else, Mike Purzycki, Wilmington's 57th mayor, a Democrat who ran unopposed by any Republican to win his second term in 2020, knows what Biden has been going through. A few months ago, he announced that he would not be seeking a third term. (Local term-limit laws allow the city's mayor to serve 12 years.)\n\n\"I'm 79,\" Purzycki said over lunch at Kid Shelleen's Charcoal House and Saloon, a onetime biker bar turned elevated saloon at the corner of 14th and Scott streets. \"I took a look and said, 'Can I do this four more years?'\"\n\nA native of New Jersey, Purzycki came to the state on a football scholarship to the University of Delaware, where he lived in the same dormitory as Biden. He worked for IBM, became a real estate developer and served as the executive director of the Riverfront Development Corp., which turned Wilmington's blighted riverfront into an area of parks, walking trails, restaurants, stores, nightclubs and new housing.\n\nOnce considered a corporate town where the sidewalks roll up at 5 o'clock, Wilmington now has buzzy restaurants downtown. Transplants from out of state are discovering the beautiful architecture, ample parks and relative affordability, all within an easy drive to bigger cities and beaches. This is the Wilmington to which Biden will return.\n\nHe will have to figure out how to spend the days after he leaves office. Purzycki has no easy advice about that.\n\n\"I'm struggling,\" he said of his own post-retirement plans. \"I'm struggling mightily.\"\n\nIn a statement Monday, the mayor showed his support for Biden's decision to withdraw, writing that the president \"has shown himself to be someone who courageously put the welfare of his fellow citizens above personal ambition.\"\n\nThe headquarters of the now defunct Biden-Harris campaign occupied a nondescript high-rise office building downtown. Last week, there were no big signs out front, no staff members scurrying in and out, nothing to suggest an operation running at full steam. That may change soon.\n\n\"It's the first full day of our campaign,\" Harris posted on social media Monday morning, \"so I'm heading up to Wilmington, DE later to say 'hello' to our staff in HQ. One day down. 105 to go. Together, we're going to win this.\"", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Biden", "type": {"uri": "8239415085", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-23", "time": "12:33:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-23T12:33:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T12:31:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.2980392277240753, "url": "https://dnyuz.com/2024/07/23/in-wilmington-they-like-delaware-joe-but-theyre-glad-he-quit/", "title": "In Wilmington, They Like 'Delaware Joe.' But They're Glad He Quit", "body": "As President Biden met with confidants last week to discuss whether he should end his re-election campaign, John Flaherty, a retired government employee, was seated in a booth at Angelo's Luncheonette in Wilmington, Del., the small city that has been Mr. Biden's political home base for more than 50 years.\n\nWearing a Philadelphia Phillies cap, Mr. Flaherty, 73, who worked as a staff assistant to Mr. Biden in the 1980s, invoked the song \"The Gambler\" to express his opinion of what the president should do.\n\n\"As Kenny Rogers said, 'You got to know when to hold 'em, know when to fold 'em,'\" he said.\n\nShortly after Mr. Biden announced that he had put an end to his bid, Mr. Flaherty weighed in by phone. \"I'm glad,\" he said. \"I think he should enjoy his life after January and spend time with his family.\"\n\nHe added that he was \"happy\" that Biden's withdrawal had left Donald Trump as the oldest major-party presidential nominee. \"Biden might be the oldest president,\" he said, but now, \"Trump will be the oldest candidate\" for president.\n\nWilmington, a city of roughly 71,000, is the site of the Joseph R. Biden Railroad Station, one of the busiest Amtrak stops along the Northeast Corridor, and Mr. Biden's main residence is in a nearby suburb. But even here, in the world's most Biden-friendly enclave, Mr. Flaherty was just one of many who believed the president had made the right call.\n\nMost people I spoke with for this article seemed fond of the president, but pessimistic about his re-election prospects. And everybody, it seemed, had a Joe Biden story.\n\nAt Angelo's, where Mr. Biden used to stop in for meals, I heard about a poster from his 1988 presidential campaign that had pride of place on a wall near the booths. For years, a smiling Mr. Biden, surrounded by his wife and children, looked down on the customers.\n\nEarly in the presidency of Donald J. Trump, the poster prompted occasional anti-Biden remarks, according to Nina, a server at the restaurant who did not want to share her last name. And then, at some point, the bickering among the customers over politics grew more heated. Finally, the staff had enough and took the poster down.\n\n\"People are jerks,\" Nina said, softly, as if not wanting to provoke more arguing.\n\nEven in Wilmington, which propelled a 29-year-old Mr. Biden to the United States Senate in 1972, local pride has met political reality.\n\nHe moved with his family from Scranton, Pa., to Wilmington in 1953, at age 10. For 70 years, he has been rooted in this place, and he has shaken thousands of hands in its neighborhoods, from Little Italy to Trolley Square.\n\nOne of his most ardent local supporters is Eunice LaFate, an artist who operates LaFate Gallery on Market Street, where she sells her paintings.\n\nBorn and raised in Jamaica, Ms. LaFate, 77, moved to Wilmington in 1983 after meeting her husband, a city native who worked for Amtrak. \"I saw a banner in a park on a yellow board,\" she said, sitting amid her colorful paintings last week. \"It said, 'Wilmington -- A Place to Be Somebody.'\"\n\nMs. LaFate spent 12 years working for a bank in town, she said. The shift to becoming a full-time artist and gallerist was inspired, in part, by an encouraging letter she received from then-Senator Biden after one of her paintings had adorned the cover of Out & About, a local entertainment publication.\n\nMs. LaFate's Joe Biden story has to do with his son Beau, who died in May 2015, shortly after the death of her husband.\n\n\"When his son passed, I stood five hours in a line at the church, waiting to greet him,\" Ms. LaFate said. \"After the five hours waiting in line, I went up and expressed my condolences. And I mentioned to him I am going through grief myself. The man took time out to console me. It was just, what should I say, so moving. The crowd was waiting, but he took time out.\"\n\nThere was no portrait of Mr. Biden on the walls of Ms. LaFate's gallery, but she went into the back to show me another one she had done -- of Kamala Harris, painted after the 2020 election, wearing a white shirt and a black blazer against a pink background.\n\nIn an interview the day after Mr. Biden's announcement, Ms. LaFate seemed happy with the turn of events. \"This is where our salad bowl of culture comes into play,\" she said. \"And Kamala Harris is a very dynamic ingredient in that salad. And she has Jamaican heritage! Her father is Jamaican. So, all of this combined, this is pretty dynamic for me.\"\n\nJerry duPhily, the publisher of Out & About, spoke fondly of the president over lunch last week at the Kozy Korner, another Wilmington spot that Mr. Biden has been known to frequent.\n\n\"People go, 'Why does he come back so much?'\" Mr. duPhily, 66, said. \"I think he likes it here. He's comfortable.\" But he added that there were concerns. \"I think a lot of people are cognizant of, 'You're 81, and you lost a step, and we see it,'\" he said.\n\nAfter the announcement, Mr. duPhily said that Mr. Biden had made the right decision, in his view. \"Maybe he could have made it a few weeks earlier,\" he said. \"But someone who has the history he does, which is being a fighter and determined, isn't just going to walk away from it.\"\n\nMr. duPhily added that he hoped Mr. Biden would build his presidential library in Wilmington, saying, \"OK, he's from Scranton -- but he's Delaware Joe.\"\n\nPerhaps more than anyone else, Mike Purzycki, Wilmington's 57th mayor, a Democrat who ran unopposed by any Republican to win his second term in 2020, knows what Mr. Biden has been going through. A few months ago, he announced that he would not be seeking a third term. (Local term-limit laws allow the city's mayor to serve 12 years.)\n\n\"I'm 79,\" Mr. Purzycki said over lunch at Kid Shelleen's Charcoal House and Saloon, a onetime biker bar turned elevated saloon at the corner of 14th and Scott streets. \"I took a look and said, 'Can I do this four more years?'\"\n\nA native of New Jersey, Mr. Purzycki came to the state on a football scholarship to the University of Delaware, where he lived in the same dormitory as Mr. Biden. He worked for IBM, became a real estate developer and served as the executive director of the Riverfront Development Corporation, which turned Wilmington's blighted riverfront into an area of parks, walking trails, restaurants, stores, nightclubs and new housing.\n\nOnce considered a corporate town where the sidewalks roll up at five o'clock, Wilmington now has buzzy restaurants downtown. Transplants from out of state are discovering the beautiful architecture, ample parks and relative affordability, all within an easy drive to bigger cities and beaches. This is the Wilmington to which Mr. Biden will return.\n\nHe will have to figure out how to spend the days after he leaves office. Mr. Purzycki has no easy advice about that.\n\n\"I'm struggling,\" he said of his own post-retirement plans. \"I'm struggling mightily.\"\n\nIn a statement on Monday, the mayor showed his support for Mr. Biden's decision to withdraw, writing that the president \"has shown himself to be someone who courageously put the welfare of his fellow citizens above personal ambition.\"\n\nThe headquarters of the now defunct Biden-Harris campaign occupied a nondescript high-rise office building downtown. Last week, there were no big signs out front, no staff members scurrying in and out, nothing to suggest an operation running at full steam. That may change soon.\n\n\"It's the first full day of our campaign,\" Ms. Harris posted on social media on Monday morning, \"so I'm heading up to Wilmington, DE later to say 'hello' to our staff in HQ. One day down. 105 to go. {"uri": "2024-07-431317470", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-23", "time": "20:12:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-23T20:12:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T15:50:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.2431372553110123, "url": "https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2024/jul/23/rod-blagojevich-says-barack-obama-is-playing-role-/", "title": "Rod Blagojevich says Obama is playing the role of Chicago ward-boss", "body": "Former Illinois Gov. Rod Blagojevich denounced former President Barack Obama as a \"threat to democracy\" and blamed him for President Biden dropping out of the presidential race.\n\nIn an op-ed in the Wall Street Journal, Mr. Blagojevich said Mr. Biden was the victim of the \"old-school way of Chicago backroom politics.\"\n\n\"Mr. Obama was the conductor of the band that successfully orchestrated the removal of the presidential candidate chosen by more than 14 million Democratic primary voters -- to be replaced by someone he and the party bosses choose instead. It's classic ward-boss tactics,\" he said.\n\n\"It isn't Donald Trump who is an existential threat to our democracy,\" he said. \"It's Barack Obama.\"\n\nMr. Blagojevich, a Democrat who served as governor from 2003 to 2009, said he's known Mr. Obama for nearly 30 years, and they both grew up in Chicago politics.\n\n\"We understand how it works -- with the bosses over the people. Mr. Obama learned the lessons well,\" he said. \"And what he just did to Mr. Biden is what political bosses have been doing in Chicago since the 1871 fire -- selections masquerading as elections.\"\n\nIn the column, the former Illinois governor related the dynamic between Mr. Obama and Mr. Biden to what he experienced in 2009 when the state legislature impeached him and removed him from office, which he said was orchestrated from \"conversations initiated by Mr. Obama himself.\"\n\n\"A common element in my case and now Mr. Biden's is Mr. Obama's involvement,\" he said. \"He's the central figure who played a behind-the-scenes role in both stories.\"\n\nMr. Blagojevich was impeached and removed on corruption charges related to his solicitation of bribes to try to \"sell\" the U.S. Senate seat Mr. Obama left open when he was elected president.\n\nHe was sentenced to 14 years in prison on related federal bribery charges in 2011. Former President Trump commuted Mr. Blagojevich's prison sentence in 2020.\n\nIn his Monday op-ed, Mr. Blagojevich said rich donors such as Mr. Obama, former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, and Hollywood and Silicon Valley elites, \"are the new bosses of today's Democratic Party.\"\n\n\"All along, Mr. Biden and the Democratic politicians have been claiming that this year's presidential race is about 'saving democracy.' They are the biggest hypocrites in American political history,\" he wrote. \"The party that says it is running to save democracy has already deployed the criminal-justice system against the leading candidate of the opposition party. And now they have successfully maneuvered to dump their duly elected candidate for president.\"\n\nHe also accused Democrats of covering up Mr. Biden's unfitness for \"a long time.\"\n\nHe said the Democratic National Convention next month \"will provide the perfect backdrop and place for Mr. Obama to finish the job and choose his candidate, not the voters' candidate.\"\n\n\"Democracy, no. Chicago ward-boss politics, yes,\" he said.\n\nMr. Biden stepped down from the presidential race Sunday and endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris to take over his spot on the Democratic ticket.\n\nA growing number of lawmakers and well-known Democrats had been calling on him to pass the torch ever since his shaky debate performance in Georgia last month.\n\nThe Washington Times has reached out to Mr. Obama for comment.", "source": {"uri": "washingtontimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Washington Times"}, "authors": [{"uri": "mallory_wilson@washingtontimes.com", "name": "Mallory Wilson", That's the best way to unite our nation.\"\n\n\"There is a time and a place for long years of experience in public life. But there's also a time and a place for new voices, fresh voices, yes, younger voices,\" Biden said, adding he will be focused on fulfilling his duties as president over the next six months.\n\nBiden, who endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris as the Democratic candidate for the race, said those duties include lowering living costs for hardworking people, growing the economy, ending Russia's war against Ukraine and ensuring that the United States remains \"strong, secure and the leader of the free world.\"\n\nIn addition, the 81-year-old president said he would keep NATO strong and would be \"doing the same for our allies in the Pacific.\"\n\n\"You know, when I came to office, the conventional wisdom was that China would inevitably surpass the United States. That's not the case anymore,\" he said.\n\nBiden abandoned his reelection bid on Sunday amid mounting pressure from Democrats following his shaky performance during a television debate with Donald Trump, his predecessor and the Republican nominee for president, in late June.\n\nHis poor performance raised concerns in his party about the incumbent's fitness to run an effective campaign for the November presidential election and serve another term.\n\nAt a campaign rally in North Carolina, Trump said, \"As you know, three days ago, we officially defeated the worst president in the history of our country,\" as he unleashed a torrent of attacks on Harris, the country's first female, first Black and first Asian American vice president.\n\nHarris, 59, has already earned the support of a majority of party delegates ahead of the Democratic Party's nominating convention, which is due to begin in Chicago on Aug. 19.\n\nThe party could make Harris its nominee as early as Aug. 1 in an online vote and could formalize the pick of her running mate soon after, according to the Associated Press.\n\nOn Wednesday, Biden said Harris is \"experienced...tough...(and) capable.\"\n\n\"The great thing about America is here, kings and dictators do not rule. {"uri": "8243828383", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "23:59:13", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T23:59:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T23:58:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4823529422283173, "url": "https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-07-26/joe-biden-vp-kamala-harris-sharpening-attacks-on-donald-trump/104144446", "title": "As Biden pledges to 'pass the torch', his VP is sharpening her attacks on Trump", "body": "By North America bureau chief Jade Macmillan in Washington DC\n\nWelcome back to your weekly update on US politics, where North America bureau chief Jade Macmillan catches you up on the biggest developments in America as we hurtle towards election day in November.\n\nFrom a nearly 150-year-old desk in the Oval Office, surrounded by portraits of presidents' past, Joe Biden began the task this week of trying to define his own place in US history.\n\nThe 81-year-old had finally come round to the same conclusion that many voters, and party insiders, reached in the aftermath of last month's disastrous debate performance.\n\nAfter roughly half a century in federal politics, and one term as president, it was time to step aside in favour of a new Democratic candidate to contest this year's election.\n\n\"I know there is a time and a place for long years of experience in public life,\" Biden said in a televised address to the nation.\n\n\"But there is also a time and place for new voices, fresh voices -- yes, younger voices. And that time and place is now.\"\n\nBiden talked up his record in the White House and made clear that he still believes he deserves a second term.\n\nAside from referring to a need to \"unite\" his party, he didn't provide any detail on what had eventually changed his mind after weeks of defiance.\n\nBut in echoing language used against his candidacy in the days leading up to his announcement, declaring it was now time to \"pass the torch\", Biden pointed to his previous but later abandoned pledge of being a \"bridge\" candidate to a new generation.\n\nAnd in an election in which he argues democracy itself is on the line, the president sought to frame his decision as being bigger than \"personal ambition\".\n\nBiden will join a relatively small group of US presidents who opted out of running for a second term.\n\nHistory will judge how the manner and timing of his exit affects his party's chances in November.\n\nFor all the excitement now building within Democratic circles about Vice-President Kamala Harris, some would argue Biden should have bowed out sooner.\n\nBut with six months still to go until his successor takes over, the president is now focused on trying to cement his legacy with the time he has left in the White House.\n\nRepublicans have called on Biden to quit altogether, arguing that if the president isn't up to serving for another four years, he shouldn't be the commander-in-chief now.\n\nBut Biden again insisted in his address that he'd serve out the remainder of his term, and singled out several priorities for the months ahead.\n\nThe president has foreshadowed controversial changes to the Supreme Court, reportedly involving term limits and an enforceable ethics code, at a time when conservative justices are in the majority.\n\nHe promised a continued focus on strengthening the NATO alliance following Russia's invasion of Ukraine, and vowed \"to keep doing the same for our allies in the Pacific\".\n\nAnd he said he'd \"keep working\" to end the war in Gaza, nine months into a conflict that has claimed tens of thousands of lives.\n\nBiden followed up by meeting Israel's prime minister, a day after Benjamin Netanyahu told Congress he would settle for nothing less than \"total victory\" against Hamas.\n\nThe US remains Israel's most important ally and has sent the country billions of dollars of military assistance, even as Biden has at times criticised Netanyahu's approach to the war.\n\nSpeaking as the two leaders met, White House spokesman John Kirby said the president would be pressing Netanyahu for progress towards an agreement for a ceasefire and the release of the remaining hostages.\n\n\"We are closer now, we believe, than we've been before,\" Kirby said.\n\n\"We believe that they are of a nature where they can be closed, and that we can achieve a deal, but it's going to require as it always does, some leadership, some compromise and an effort to get there.\"\n\nNetanyahu also sat down with Harris, who'd skipped his congressional address, citing a scheduling clash.\n\nIn remarks delivered after the meeting, which she described as \"frank and constructive\", she said Israel had a right to defend itself, but \"how it does so matters\", adding that she had \"serious concern about the scale of human suffering\".\n\n\"We cannot look away in the face of these tragedies,\" she said.\n\nAsked whether Harris would approach the conflict differently to Biden, Kirby earlier insisted the vice-president had been a \"full partner\" in the administration's Middle East policies.\n\nBut she appears to have at least signalled a shift in how she'll discuss the conflict, and seemed to try to appeal to voters who've abandoned the president over his handling of the war.\n\n\"To everyone who has been calling for a ceasefire, and to everyone who yearns for peace, I see you and I hear you,\" she said.\n\n\"Let's get the deal done.\"\n\nNetanyahu is also looking ahead to the possibility of a second Trump administration, with plans to meet the former president at his Mar-a-lago property in Florida on his way home.\n\n\"I want him to finish up and get it done quickly,\" Trump told Fox News of his message to Netanyahu ahead of his visit.\n\n\"You know Israel is not very good at public relations, I'll tell you that.\"\n\nThings have moved quickly on the Democratic side of politics in the days since Biden's withdrawal reshaped the race.\n\nThe vice-president speedily secured the support needed to solidify her position as the expected nominee, and has started sharpening her attack against Trump.\n\nOne of Harris's central campaign messages is that of the \"prosecutor vs the felon\", contrasting her public record against the former president's criminal convictions.\n\nShe's also leaning into her relative youth, and a wave of timely gen Z memes, and will likely ramp up her focus on reproductive rights -- an issue she'd already taken the lead on as part of the Biden-Harris ticket.\n\nTrump, meanwhile, has well and truly shifted his focus onto his new opponent.\n\nAt a rally in North Carolina, held just before Biden's national address, the former president repeatedly pronounced her name incorrectly (for the record, it's KAHM-uh-luh), and branded Harris a \"radical left lunatic\".\n\nAnd in that same Fox interview on Thursday, he hit back at the vice-president's criticisms as \"disgusting\".\n\n\"They say, 'Sir, be nice, you just got hit with a bullet, maybe he's changed, be nice,'\" he said.\n\n\"And I'd love to be nice but I'm dealing against real garbage.\"\n\nTrump's campaign is making several key arguments against Harris -- that her background in the liberal city of San Francisco shows she's too far to the left, that she botched an immigration role assigned to her in the early days of the Biden administration, and that she helped to cover up concerns about Biden's age.\n\nIt will take some time before opinion polls paint a picture of where voters might be sitting following the Biden/Harris switch, but early surveys suggest Americans are still in for a close race.\n\nAnd in the meantime, it appears calls to dial down the political rhetoric since Trump's attempted assassination have all but evaporated.\n\nElevating Harris to the top spot means the vice-president now needs to choose her own running mate.\n\nSome analysts are sceptical of the idea that a vice-presidential pick can influence the outcome in particular states, instead arguing they help to shape perceptions of the candidate running for the White House.\n\nEither way, a long list of names has been floated and Harris's campaign will be weighing up how they'd fare against Trump's newly announced number two, JD Vance.\n\nAt 39 years old, the Ohio senator is much younger than Trump and has emphasised his \"Rust Belt\" upbringing in a way their campaign hopes will connect with working class voters.\n\nBut Vance is firmly in Trump's so-called MAGA camp of the Republican Party, and others have reportedly expressed \"buyer's remorse\" in the wake of Harris's ascension, given the need to appeal to independent and swing voters in critical states.\n\nVance's cause might not have been helped by the resurfacing of a 2021 interview in which he argued the US was being run \"by a bunch of childless cat ladies who are miserable at their own lives and the choices that they've made\".\n\nHe went on to name several Democrats, including Harris, asking: \"How does it make any sense that we've turned our country over to people who don't really have a direct stake in it?\"\n\nFormer secretary of state and Democrats presidential candidate Hillary Clinton shared the clip on X, sarcastically describing Vance as \"a normal, relatable guy who certainly doesn't hate women having freedoms\".\n\nWhile the actor Jennifer Aniston -- who has spoken openly about her difficulties with IVF -- posted a message on Instagram saying: \"I truly can't believe this is coming from a potential VP of the United States.\"\n\nA spokesperson for Vance hit back at the criticism, highlighting the senator's openness about his success being due \"in large part to the influence of strong female role models like his grandmother\".\n\nBut winning over American women who've mobilised in the two years since Trump's Supreme Court picks helped to end the nation-wide right to abortion has always presented a challenge for the former president.\n\nWith the election again re-set after an already tumultuous few weeks, both sides are scrambling to gain ground just a few months out from polling day.", "source": {"uri": "abc.net.au", "dataType": "news", "title": "Australian Broadcasting Corporation"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri":
